               COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE ­ Minutes of Meeting
                             May 13, 2013

The Village Board met as a Committee of the Whole in the Council Chambers of the
Village Hall at 6:00 p.m. on Monday, May 13, 2013. In attendance were:

PRESENT:

Village Board                         Staff
Harriet Rosenthal, Mayor              Kent Street, Village Manager
Robert Benton, Trustee                Andrew Lichterman, Asst. to the Village Manager
Alan Farkas, Trustee                  David Fitzgerald, Management Analyst
Thomas Jester, Trustee                John Sliozis, Police Chief
Robert Nadler, Trustee                Principal Planner, Jeff Ryckaert
William Seiden, Trustee               Matthew Weiss, Computer Systems Coordinator
Barbara Struthers, Trustee            Robert Taraszka, Computer Technician
Peter Coblentz, Village Attorney


Also Present
Mary Oppenheim

Public Comment
There was no one present for public comment.

Commercial Lease Transactions
Mayor Rosenthal stated that she had discussed with Attorney Coblentz the issue of the
Village not receiving sales tax revenues from non-retail businesses looking to locate in
retail areas. She asked Mr. Coblentz to research the issue and make a report to the
Committee of the Whole to decide whether to take the issue to the Northwest Municipal
Conference or the Illinois Municipal League to pursue in Springfield.

Mr. Coblentz reported that Florida, Kentucky and Arizona all apply a sales tax to
commercial rents. He noted that as a home rule unit of government, the Village of
Deerfield has broad taxing powers but cannot impose a tax upon occupations. He noted
that a tax on commercial rents would be an occupation tax on landlords. Because of this,
legislative action would be required at the State level.
Mr. Coblentz stated that such a tax, however, is not out of line with other occupation
taxes specifically allowed by the State, such as taxes on copy machine leases and
intellectual property.

Mr. Coblentz noted that his memo to the Board was narrowly tailored to educate
lawmakers on the issue of non-sales tax generating businesses wanting to open in
predominantly retail districts. He stated that a set policy on the matter would create a
legal policy to minimize the appearance of case-by case decision making.

Trustee Jester stated that it was important to stress that the proposal focused only on
nonretail businesses in retail business districts.
C.O.W; May 13, 2013


Mr. Coblentz noted that the application of the tax would have to show reasonable
justification and that business that are mixed retail and nonretail could have their
commercial lease tax reduced by the amount of sales tax generated.

Trustee Struthers stated that the policy would work if implemented statewide, but if it
only applied in Deerfield it could deter businesses from coming into the community.

Trustee Farkas questioned whether such a tax would apply to office uses. He also noted
that the comparison to Florida's tax structure is not equal because Florida does not have
an income tax. He stated that he would favor the policy only if it was statewide.

Attorney Coblentz noted that the policy would only apply to central business districts and
not impact office centers. Mayor Rosenthal noted that the point of the proposal would be
for a state-wide policy only.

Trustee Nadler noted that such a tax would leave the current zoning intact.

Trustee Benton stated that he would like to see it explored further.

Mayor Rosenthal stated that the policy would be presented at a regular Board meeting for
referral to the Northwest Municipal Conference.

Possible Licensing Agreement
Village Manager Street reported that a company has taken an interest in the "Kissing"
and "No Kissing" signs that were put up at the METRA station in the 1970s. He stated
that the images were copyrighted by the Village in the 1980s. He noted that the firm
representing designer Kate Spade is interested in a license agreement to use the images.


The Village Board requested that Manager Street pursue negotiations.

BYOB Liquor License Classification
Manager Street reported that Bobby's and Rhapsody Cafe have both contacted the
Village requesting a BYOB liquor license to allow patrons to bring their own beer or
wine.

Assistant to the Village Manager Lichterman reported that staff's research found that
Lake Forest, Northbrook and Northfield all have a BYOB liquor license class. He noted
that a narrowly tailored ordinance that includes safeguards, such as drink service limits,
could legalize and regulate this practice in Deerfield. He stated that an ordinance would
allow patrons to bring their own beer or wine and would require that it not leave the
premises unless in a sealed bag as required in State law. The license would be free for
restaurants that already have a Class C or Class E liquor license, which are licenses for
restaurants. It would cost $250 if the restaurant does not have a Class C or Class E
license.

Trustee Farkas noted that a BYOB liquor license could keep costs down for diners and
benefit local grocers. Trustee Seiden inquired if restaurants could charge corkage fees.
C.O.W; May 13, 2013


Mr. Lichterman noted that it would be allowed in the ordinance and be up to restaurants
to set the amount.

Trustee Nadler asked if restaurants would be in favor of such a policy. Manager Street
reported that two restaurants have specifically requested that the Village allow BYOB,
but that additional input would be sought.

Trustee Farkas asked Chief Sliozis if he was concerned about servers at BYOB-only
establishments handling liquor. Chief Sliozis noted that all servers would have to go
through the same training.

Mayor Rosenthal noted that she thought limiting the amount of alcohol that could be
brought in at one bottle of wine per person was too high. She stated that it could be more
difficult for servers to stop service to patrons who have over consumed and suggested
lowering the amount of alcohol permitted per person.


Assistant to the Village Manager Lichterman reported that BASSETT training for servers
would be required as an added safeguard. Mayor Rosenthal stated that for restaurants
with only a BYOB license, the added training could be beneficial.

It was the consensus of the Committee of the Whole that staff should perform more
research and bring a report to the Village Board.

U.S. Bank Corner Park
Mr. Lichterman reported that the Village's lease on the U.S. Bank Corner Park started on
April 1. Since that time, staff, with the assistance of a local landscape contractor and
Mary Oppenheim, has improved safety at the site by leveling the paths, pruning and
planting. He stated that staff is now looking for guidance on how to proceed at the site.
Improvements performed by the end of next year are eligible for reimbursement if the
lease is terminated early. He inquired if staff should hire a consultant to develop a site
plan to take to the various commissions. He noted a proposal from Rosbourough Partners
was included with the memo to the Board.

Mayor Rosenthal noted that Mary Oppenheim is a landscape architect and worked with
staff in determining how to perform the improvements. Ms. Oppenheim stated that with
any park it is important to keep in mind site lines and seating. With the overgrowth
cleared out more people are using the area. She noted that the corner had been neglected
for a long time and the new improvements are a short-term fix, and a more long-term
solution is needed.

Trustee Nadler inquired about the cost of such a plan. Mayor Rosenthal stated that the
Village previously looked into purchasing the property, but the lease option has greatly
lowered the cost of controlling the parcel. She noted that she would like to see how the
park is used following the recent improvements.
C.O.W; May 13, 2013


Trustee Farkas stated that he thought this would be a good opportunity to find
sponsorship partners and volunteers to help fund improvements and maintenance at the
park. Ms. Oppenheim stated that she had spoken with officials from the Lions Club who
indicated that they would be willing to offer some funds and volunteers to the park. She
suggested developing a plan first so staff would know what kind of sponsorship level
would be appropriate for the project.

Mr. Lichterman reported that two plans could be developed, one that is scaled down and
a bigger plan that would incorporate public art. He said featured artists could be brought
in to perform demonstrations to make the art installations a community event.

Trustee Nadler suggested involving high school students in the process. Ms. Oppenheim
noted that the Earth Works group at Deerfield High School could do clean ups and
plantings. She suggested developing a plan now that can be further flushed out at a later
date.

Mr. Lichterman stated that if a plan is developed during the current fiscal year it could be
funded in the 2014 budget.

Mayor Rosenthal asked staff to research plans now and monitor the park's use over the
summer. Trustee Farkas concurred and asked staff to start looking into sponsorship
opportunities.

Board Device Training
Mr. Lichterman recalled that the Board packet devices are being replaced because the
current laptops are over 6 years old, no longer under warranty and replacement parts are
difficult to find. He noted the computers have surpassed their life expectancy and they
can no longer be serviced properly. All Board members turned in their laptops and
received an iPad.

Mayor Rosenthal reminded the Trustees that the new devices are for Village use only and
are subject to the Freedom of Information Act.

Computer Systems Coordinator Weiss provided training to the Village Board regarding
packet distribution and use of the devices.

Adjournment

Trustee Benton made a motion to adjourn. The motion was seconded by Trustee Seiden.

The meeting adjourned at 7:42 p.m.

   Respectfully Submitted,
   David Fitzgerald
   Management Analyst

Trustee Farkas noticed there was a charge for Just Tires in Mt. Prospect. He questioned why a
Deerfield business was not utilized. Mr. Street indicated the local Just Tires does not carry the
size tire that was needed.

TREASURER'S REPORT                             Village Treasurer Eric Burk presented highlights
                                               from the treasurer's report, the final for fiscal year
2013. He noted he will be back with fully adjusted and audited reports later in the year. Mr.
Burk indicated the non-home rule sales tax is down slightly due to a loss of business in town.
The Village has partially been able to offset the decrease through Walgreens. The hotel tax is
up, water and sewer revenues are up. Electric utility tax is down slightly, but consistent with last
year. The state income tax shown on the report represents two months' worth of payments.

REPORT ON DEPARTMENTAL                        Assistant to the Village Manager Andrew
OBJECTIVES ­ ADMINISTRATION                   Lichterman presented the administrative
                                              departmental objectives report. He highlighted
significant changes over the past six months. There have been some personnel changes and the
Village is currently recruiting for a Human Resources Coordinator. They will begin negotiations
with the Public Works union, Local 150, on a new contract. The first year of municipal
aggregation was a great success with Village residents saving approximately $2.3 million. The
year 2 rate is 0.0499 per kWh. MC Squared added a new feature so customers can now opt in
online. The department has made a strong effort to work with all businesses in town and is
focusing on business retention with the DBR Chamber of Commerce. The Village has also
trained all departments on electronic invoicing. They are also working on the new document
management system for the Village. The new system will help with FOIA requests.

Mr. Lichterman indicated commercial refuse and recycling franchising is a big initiative this
year. They have held two meetings with the business subcommittee and a public hearing is
scheduled for June 17, 2013. The Village is in contact with Bannockburn to possibly pursue a
joint RFP for commercial franchising.

Staff is working closely with CCHD and the DBR Chamber of Commerce to promote businesses
during the Lake Cook Road construction.

Staff has issued an RFP for janitorial and maintenance services for all four Village facilities.
The RFPs are due on May 31, 2013 and a contract is expected to go to the Board of Trustees on
June 17, 2013. The North Shore Electrical Aggregation Consortium is working on their second
initiative, electric vehicle charging stations. Proposals for this project are due on June 7, 2013.

Staff has negotiated a lease with U.S. Bank for the northeast corner park parcel. The 15-year
lease began April 1, 2013. The Public Works department and a local contractor have made
substantial safety improvements to the park. The next step is preparing design plans for
consideration by the Village Board.

The Fine Arts Commission has been working on planning the Fine Arts Festival. The Preview
Party will take place on May 31, 2013, and it the Fest will open to the public on June 1, 2013 and
June 2, 2013. Mr. Lichterman reported the event has expanded with an evening concert and
Board of Trustees Meeting
May 20, 2013
Page 4 of 8

local restaurants will serve food and beverages at the event. There will also be live
entertainment until 9 p.m., on June 1. Mr. Lichterman noted the DBR Chamber of Commerce
has been very supportive and has done a great job in recruiting local restaurants and coordinating
the evening concert.

The Family Days Commission is working on the 50th year of Family Days. Fireworks will take
place on July 3 at Brickyards Park. The Family Days brochure will be mailed in June and will
describe all of the festivities on July 4th. The 19th season of the Farmers Market begins on June
8, 2013 and runs through October 12, 2013.

The Sustainability Commission appointed a new chairman. They are reviewing their mission
and goals for the future. They will set two 12-month goals and two 24-month goals.

The IT department has replaced and updated a lot of equipment throughout the Village. They
also updated the Village information channel on cable to a more modern design with emergency
notice capabilities. The Wastewater Reclamation Facility project has been demanding and is
substantially complete. Equipment was transferred from the previous administration building to
the new building along with fiber optics, firewalls and new printers.

Trustee Seiden noted the electrical aggregation increase was not substantial. He thinks it is
wonderful and residents are getting a break on their electric bills. Mayor Rosenthal asked how
new residents opt-in. Mr. Lichterman noted the new resident can call MC Squared or visit
northshoreelectricityaggregation.com.

                        REQUEST FOR BOARD ACTION

                                                      Agenda Item: 13-53


Subject:       Report and Recommendation of the Plan Commission re: Request
               for an amendment to the Special Use/Planned Unit Development
               and to amend Ordinance O-06-56 for Congregation B'nai Jehoshua
               Beth Elohim (BJBE) to correct a discrepancy in the number of
               students allowed in the 1141 classroom building; to allow an
               additional 225 religious school students, on Sundays only, to be
               accommodated throughout the entire BJBE facility; and to install a
               building connection between the 1141 and 1181 buildings.

Action Requested:           Approval for Recommendation

Originated by:              Plan Commission

Referred to:                Mayor and Board of Trustees


Summary of Background and Reason for Request:

Congregation B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim (BJBE), located at 1141, 1181, and
1201 Lake Cook Road in the Deerfield Business Center is requesting an
amendment to their Special Use/Planned Unit Development and to amend
Ordinance O-06-56 to correct a discrepancy in the number of students allowed in
the 1141 classroom building; to allow an additional 225 religious school students,
on Sundays only, to be accommodated throughout the entire BJBE facility; and to
install a building connection between the 1141 and 1181 buildings.

Reports and Documents Attached:

Recommendation
Public Hearing Minutes 5/9/13
Workshop Minutes 5/9/13
Aerial Photo
2006 Background Information
Petitioner's Materials


Date Referred to Board: June 3, 2013

Action Taken: __________________________________________
                                                                                APPROVED


                                   RECOMMENDATION

TO: Mayor and Board of Trustees

FROM: Plan Commission

DATE: May 9, 2013

RE: Request for an amendment to the Special Use/Planned Unit Development and to
amend Ordinance O-06-56 for Congregation B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim (BJBE) to correct
a discrepancy in the number of students allowed in the 1141 classroom building; to allow an
additional 225 religious school students, on Sundays only, to be accommodated throughout
the entire BJBE facility; and to install a building connection between the 1141 and 1181
buildings.

We transmit for your consideration a recommendation adopted by the Plan Commission of
the Village of Deerfield on the request of the petitioners for a amendment to the Special
Use/Planned Unit Development and to amend Ordinance O-06-56 for Congregation B'nai
Jehoshua Beth Elohim (BJBE) to correct a discrepancy in the number of students allowed in
the 1141 classroom building; to allow an additional 225 religious school students, on
Sundays only, to be accommodated throughout the entire BJBE facility, and install a
building connection. The Plan Commission held a public hearing on May 9, 2013. At that
public hearing, the petitioners presented testimony and documentary evidence in support of
the request. A copy of the public hearing and workshop minutes are attached.

In support of its request, the Plan Commission makes the following findings of fact and
conclusions:

                                 FINDINGS OF FACT

Subject Property

The subject property consists of the Deerfield Business Center, which is a 10.5 acre
development. Originally approved in 1983 as a Planned Unit Development (Ordinance O-
83-12), the property contained six (6) single-story office buildings at 1101, 1121, 1141,
1161, 1181, and 1201 Lake Cook Road. Each office building was 20,957 square feet in
area for a total of 125,742 square feet in six office buildings.

In 2006, Congregation B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim (BJBE) received approval for an
amendment to a Special Use/Planned Unit Development for the Deerfield Business Center,
a Text Amendment, and a Special Use with a parking variation to allow a religious institution
at 1141, 1181 and 1201 Lake Cook Road. The 1181 and 1201 buildings have been
renovated for BJBE, and the petitioners plan to convert the 1141 building to the previously
approved classroom space at this time.
In 2004, the Village granted approval of the Chicagoland Jewish High School and in 2005
the Village granted approval for the Greek elementary and middle school on the parcels
immediately to the east of the subject property.

Surrounding Land Use and Zoning

North: (across Lake Cook Road): R-3 Single Family Residential District ­ single
    family homes
South: Eden's Spur
East: I-1 Office Research, and Restricted Industrial District ­ Hellenic American Academy
   (Socrates Greek American School), and Chicagoland Jewish High School
West: I-1 Office, Research, and Restricted Industrial District ­ Textura

Proposed Plan

Correct Discrepancy in 2006 Special Use Approval

The petitioners are requesting approval to amend their Special Use/Planned Unit
Development approval for the property and to amend Ordinance O-06-56 dated December
19, 2006, which approved the Special Use/Planned Unit Development. Specifically, the
petitioners are requesting to correct a discrepancy in Ordinance O-06-56 regarding the
number of students permitted in the classrooms in the 1141 Lake Cook Road building. In
2006, the petitioner's floor plan and project summary indicated a maximum of 475 students,
but their written response to the Special Use standards indicated a maximum capacity of
380 students. Ordinance O-06-56 was written to allow 380 students, but the floor plan
attached as an exhibit to the ordinance shows 475 students and their written project
description shows 475 students. Attached are these 2006 documents. The petitioners
would like to amend Ordinance O-06-56 to correct a discrepancy to allow a maximum of 475
students in the 1141 building classrooms instead of 380 students. The petitioner's current
floor plan for the 1141 classroom building would accommodate up to 475 students, as
originally contemplated in 2006.

Special Use Amendment to Allow 225 Additional Religious School Students in the
BJBE Facility on Sundays

BJBE would also like approval to allow an additional 225 religious school students, on
Sundays only, to be accommodated throughout the entire BJBE facility. The current Special
Use ordinance limits the number of students in the facility in the 1141 Lake Cook Road
building as indicated above. The petitioners are requesting to amend the Special Use for the
property to reflect the requested changes to allow 225 religious school students on Sundays
only.

The petitioners plan also plan to install the link (connection) between buildings 1141 and
1181, which was approved in 2006. The petitioners have indicated the building link will be
consistent with the approved 2006 building elevation plans, except the door to the west will
be eliminated (the door to the east will remain). Attached are the 2006 building elevation
plans showing the proposed link. Other than installing the previously approved building link,

                                              2
the petitioners are not proposing any changes to the site plan, landscape plan, building
elevations or lighting plan.

Access

No changes to the site access are proposed. Access to and from the Deerfield Business
Center PUD is from the signalized intersection at Lake Cook Road and Pine Street.

BJBE uses the existing Deerfield Business Center driveways for access and all BJBE traffic
circulates around the synagogue in a one-way clockwise direction. BJBE has a dedicated
drop-off in front of the 1181 Lake Cook Road building, which is the main entrance to the
synagogue.

Traffic and Parking Study

The petitioners retained Gewalt Hamilton Associates to conduct a traffic and parking study.
The study indicates that peak times for BJBE's Sunday operations would be the drop -off
time period from 9 am to 10 am, and the pick-up time period from 11 am to noon (page 2).
Gewalt Hamilton observed traffic at BJBE's site and at Caruso School, where BJBE's
religious school currently takes place. The traffic consultant believes that the proposed 700
students on Sundays can be accommodated on the BJBE site. The additional students on
BJBE's site on Sundays would result in an additional 450 trips during each of the peak
periods (page 3). The petitioner's traffic consultant provided a detailed explanation of how
the drop-off and pick-up work at the public hearing; pages 2 and 3 of the public hearing
minutes explain how the traffic flows and how the drop-off works. The traffic consultant also
examined the available parking and found that for the most part, the additional parking
demand can be accommodated on BJBE's site. The 10 am peak hour will exceed current
BJBE parking capacity (see Exhibit 10), but BJBE has permission to use 40 parking spaces
in the Deerfield Business Center on Sundays and these additional 40 spaces would
accommodate that extra parking demand (page 5).

Zoning Conformance

The subject parcel is part of an existing PUD which is known as the Deerfield Business
Center. PUDs are a Special Use in the I-1, Office, Research, and Restricted Industrial
District. The petitioners are seeking an amendment to their Special Use/Planned Unit
Development approval for the property and to amend Ordinance O-06-56 dated December
19, 2006, which approved the Special Use/Planned Unit Development to allow 380 students
in the 1141 building classrooms. The petitioners are seeking to change the number to 475
students as explained earlier in this memo. The petitioners are also seeking approval to
allow an additional 225 religious school students, on Sundays only, to be accommodated
throughout the entire BJBE facility. The total number of students to be accommodated in
the religious school on a Sunday will not be 700 (475 in the 1141 building and 225
throughout the BJBE facility = 700 students).




                                              3
Parking

Below is how the parking for BJBE and the office buildings were calculated in 2006.

BJBE:

Required: The Zoning Ordinance requires one (1) parking space for each four (4) seats for a
place of worship. A child care facility requires one (1) parking space for each teacher and
employee, plus one (1) parking space for each ten (10) students.
The total seating capacity of the sanctuary is 600 persons (422 in the main seating area and
178 in the balcony) and the seating capacity of the chapel is 100, for a total seating capacity
of 700 persons (600 in the sanctuary and 100 in the chapel = 700) which would require 175
spaces. The petitioner's materials indicate the early childhood center will serve
approximately 35 children from six months to four years of age and there would be 15
teachers/staff. The 35 children would require 3.5 parking spaces (35/10 = 3.5) plus 15 for
the teachers/staff for a total of 18.5 spaces. BJBE would require 194 parking spaces (175
for the place of worship plus 18.5 for the childcare for a total of 193.5 = 194 spaces).

Provided: A total of 160 spaces are provided for BJBE. A variation was granted in 2006 for
the number of parking spaces as 194 are required on site, and 160 are provided on the
BJBE property, a shortage of 34 parking spaces.

BJBE and the owner of Deerfield Business Center (3 remaining office building in this
development) have a parking agreement which was a requirement of the 2006 Special Use
approval. This parking agreement will allow for use of the Deerfield Business Center
parking lots for 40 cars during non-business hours, and on weekends from 8:00 a.m. to 1:00
p.m. BJBE's parking agreement with the Deerfield Business Center to use 40 spaces in
their parking lot results in a total of 200 spaces for BJBE (160 on site and 40 off-site at the
adjacent office buildings in this PUD).

Office Buildings:

Spaces required for the remaining three (3) office building in this PUD (1101, 1121, or 1161
Lake Cook Road) on the site: The three (3) buildings are each 20,957 according to the site
plan approved in 1983 and would require 252 parking spaces (62,871 / 250 = 251.48 =
252).

Provided: There are 275 spaces provided for the three remaining office buildings at the
north end of the site.

Deerfield Business Center PUD:

Required parking spaces for both uses (BJBE and the three office buildings) in this PUD:
446 spaces (194 for proposed BJBE, plus 252 for the three remaining office buildings).




                                               4
Parking spaces provided for both uses in this PUD: A total of 435 spaces are provided on
the entire site (160 spaces on the BJBE portion of the property, and 275 spaces on the
office portion of the property).

                                      CONCLUSIONS

Correct Discrepancy in 2006 Special Use Approval

The Plan Commission is in favor of correcting the discrepancy in the number of students
allowed in the religious school that exists in the 2006 approval as described above.

Special Use Amendment to Allow 225 Additional Religious School Students in the
BJBE Facility on Sundays

Compatible with Existing Development

The Plan Commission believes that the proposed expansion of the religious school to add
225 students throughout the BJBE facility on Sundays only is planned so that it will be
compatible with existing development in the area and will not impede the normal and orderly
development and improvement of surrounding properties. The Plan Commission believes
that the proposed religious school will have minimal impact on surrounding properties. The
Plan Commission believes the religious school is a good use of the property and will be an
asset to the Village. There is a need for the proposed expanded religious school in the
community and the religious school use is well planned.

Lot of Sufficient Size

The Plan Commission believes the lot is of sufficient size for the proposed religious school.
The petitioners are not proposing to expand the size of the buildings on this campus. The
only exterior change will be the installing a link between two buildings that was previously
approved in 2006. The Plan Commission believes the property is suitable for the proposed
expanded religious school use on Sundays, and will not create a negative impact on
surrounding properties.

Traffic

The Plan Commission believes that the proposed Sunday religious school will not have an
adverse impact on the surrounding properties. They do not believe that the proposed
religious school should significantly increase traffic volumes in the area. The property
should not have any problem accommodating the traffic generated by the religious school.
The drop-off and pick-up will continue to function on the east side of the BJBE facility. The
Plan Commission believes the traffic flow (the one way operation continues) will work well.
BJBE has a good working relationship with Chicagoland Jewish High School. The Plan
Commission recommends that BJBE continue to work with the Chicagoland Jewish High
School on traffic matters should there be any issues that arise with traffic flow and parking
on the site as a result of the Sunday school religious classes. The Plan Commission
believes it would be very beneficial to BJBE to continue working with CJHS to have the gate

                                              5
between their properties opened on Sundays to allow parents to exit the site and return
directly to the traffic light at Lake Cook Road and Pine Street.

Parking and Access

The Plan Commission believes that the parking will work for the Sunday religious Sunday
school. There are currently 160 parking spaces on the BJBE property and Also, BJBE can
utilize 40 more parking spaces on the Deerfield Business Center property during non-
business hours and the weekends from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. The existing vehicular access
points into the BJBE facility parking lot will not be changed as a result of the Sunday
religious school. The existing vehicular access points on this property and the drop-off area
will not be changed as a result of the additional 225 religious school on Sundays.

Effect on the Neighborhood

The Plan Commission believes that the expansion of the religious school on Sundays to
include 225 religious school students will not be significantly or materially detrimental to the
health, safety and welfare of the public or injurious to other property or improvements in the
neighborhood, nor will it diminish or impair property values in the surrounding areas. The
Plan Commission believes that the proposed additional 225 religious school student on
Sundays will not have an adverse impact on surrounding properties and is an appropriate
location for this activity. The Plan Commission believes this expanded religious school will
work well on the property.

Adequate Facilities

Adequate facilities are already being provided for this site.

Adequate Buffering

The Plan Commission believes that the existing buffering is adequate.

                                    RECOMMENDATION

Accordingly, it is the recommendation of the Plan Commission that Congregation B'nai
Jehoshua Beth Elohim (BJBE) request for an amendment to the Special Use/Planned Unit
Development and to amend Ordinance O-06-56 to correct a discrepancy in the number of
students allowed in the 1141 classroom building; to allow an additional 225 religious school
students, on Sundays only, to be accommodated throughout the entire BJBE facility; and to
install a building connection between the 1141 and 1181 buildings, be approved.

Ayes: (5) Berg, Bromberg, Moyer, Shayman, Shapiro
Nays: (0) None

Respectfully submitted,
Dan Shapiro, Chairman
Deerfield Plan Commission

                                 PLAN COMMISSION
                               VILLAGE OF DEERFIELD

The Plan Commission of the Village of Deerfield held a Public Hearing at 7:30 P.M. on
May 9, 2013 at the Village Hall, 850 Waukegan Road, Deerfield, Illinois.

Chairman Shapiro called the meeting to order.

Present were:        Dan Shapiro, Chairman
                     Larry Berg
                     Alan Bromberg
                     Jim Moyer
                     Stuart Shayman

Absent:              Elaine Jacoby

Also present:        Jeff Ryckaert, Principal Planner
                     Kathleen LéVeque, Associate Planner

Public Comment on a Non-Agenda Item

There was no public comment from the audience.

Public Hearing on the request for an amendment to the Special Use/Planned Unit
Development and to amend Ordinance O-06-56 for Congregation B'nai Jehoshua Beth
Elohim (BJBE) to correct a discrepancy in the number of students allowed in the 1141
classroom building; to allow an additional 225 religious school students, on Sundays
only, to be accommodated throughout the entire BJBE facility; and to add a connection
between 1141 and 1181 buildings.

Staff confirmed that notice was published in the Deerfield Review on April 18, 2013 and
the petitioner submitted proof of notification.

Lawrence Freedman, Attorney with Ash, Anos, Freedman & Logan, LLC representing
BJBE, explained the petitioners are requesting to amend the Special Use Planned Unit
Development approved in 2006. The three changes that the petitioner is seeking and/or
clarifying are:
    1. A discrepancy in the original ordinance in reference to the number of students
        allowed in the 1141 Lake Cook Road building. The testimony to the Plan
        Commission at that time, and in an exhibit, referred to 475 students. The body of
        the ordinance refers to 380 students. The petitioner would like to clarify that the
        ordinance should state 475 students.
    2. The petitioner requests to allow an additional 225 religious school students on
        Sundays only. These students will be dispersed throughout the entire facility
        whereas previously Sunday school students were limited only in the 1141 Lake
        Cook Road building.
Public Hearing: BJBE
May 9, 2013
Page 2

   3. There is a door shown in the original approved plans in the ordinance linking the
      1141 and 1181 Lake Cook Road buildings. The petitioner would like to eliminate
      the door to the west.

Mr. Freedman summarized the points in a letter from BJBE Director of Education Sandy
Robins that was submitted to the Plan Commission. This letter outlined the Sunday
usage and gives the Plan Commission a basis for which to evaluate the operation.
          The onsite weekday program will remain unchanged except for moving the
             students into new classrooms in the 1141 Lake Cook Road building.
          The Sunday morning religious school of approximately 700 students is
             currently being serviced at 1141 Lake Cook Road and Caruso Middle
             School. This plan will eliminate the Caruso Middle School operation and
             consolidate all programming at the BJBE site.
          On Sundays, BJBE does not have and is not planning to have preschool
             or prayer services on site. There will be some adult education programs
             on Sundays servicing between 35-65 people and occasional special
             events which may necessitate modifying a particular program so it is
             compatible.
          Most of the students are carpooled and dropped-off/picked-up. Most
             parents do not stay for most of the programs. Drop-offs all occur at
             approximately 9:30am and pick-ups begin to occur around noon.

In another letter from the Chicagoland Jewish High School submitted to the Plan
Commission, Mr. Freedman noted that they are currently in discussions with the
adjacent High School property to provide access through their parking lot. This will
allow for ease of access and some additional (when/if needed) parking in an overflow
situation. The petitioner will continue to provide traffic personnel during the drop-off and
pick-up periods and other activities on Sundays.

Bob Hamilton, P.E., Traffic Consultant, Gewalt Hamilton Associates, Inc., reviewed and
summarized the parking and traffic study that was done for this project. Mr. Hamilton
noted that this was an unusual study being that it was for Sunday mornings and typically
the on-street traffic is very low. Due to the location of this facility, roadway
configuration, and the adjacent properties, the only people impacted in any substantial
way by the traffic activity are the people doing the traffic activity. There are no
residential neighbors in close proximity, virtually no one in the nearby office building.
The adjacent High School and Greek school to the northeast have limited activities on
Sundays. The goal in this area is to make the traffic activity efficient. The fact that this
is a very cohesive volunteer group, traffic issues of this type tend to be self-regulating
and traffic monitors can have a tremendous impact.

Traffic circulation during arrival and departure is like many grade schools in that the
students are not the ones driving; instead it is their parents, older siblings,
grandparents, etc. In this case, Mr. Hamilton noted that the traffic is a consistent
system and he does not see a problem with it. Traffic will increase substantially due to
Public Hearing: BJBE
May 9, 2013
Page 3

the students at Caruso coming to this location. The traffic study was done in the spring
and was based on a per student basis as if all 700 students were in attendance every
week. Mr. Hamilton reviewed the traffic circulation on the site plan noting that inbound
traffic enters from the south leg of Pine Street from a dedicated right-turn bay into the
BJBE site and proceeds across the front (east side) of the BJBE building. Currently, all
drop-off operations are very efficient and occur at the east door. The traffic study
suggests that the petitioner work with the High School to open up their gate on Sunday
mornings. This option increases efficiency and imposes no burden on the High School.

The study also looked at the direction from which vehicles enter and exit. Mr. Hamilton
noted that they anticipated and over allocated vehicles coming to and from the west,
partly because they don't know the volume of parents that pick-up and deliver to both
the 1141 building and Caruso school. The arrival period or peak period will be
approximately 20-25 minutes, and that will work well. Mr. Hamilton noted that the
bigger issue is the departure period from the school. The current plan is to have the
students leave through the east entrance in a one or two lane approach when there is a
traffic monitor. The alternative is to have dismissal at the opposite door having the
younger children dismissed at one door and older students at another door. For
security reasons, there is a substantial number of parents that park and walk-in to pick-
up their children. This is particularly true for kindergarten through third grades. The
study recommends that this indoor pick-up process does not change. Mr. Hamilton said
that the possibility of opening up access through the High School for vehicles to exit
would be a nice alternative. He also finds that traffic assistance or monitors are
effective and recommend that they continue to be used.

Mr. Hamilton noted that they studied parking at the site and at Caruso and prorated it in
the study on a per student basis. Parking demand is driven by teachers and staff and
with the exception of the peak hours all parking demands can be handled within the
BJBE parking lot. The 1-hour peak period overflow can be accommodated in the
overflow parking lot to the north of the site. If there is an agreement with the High
School, overflow can be accommodated at High School. Overall, there is adequate
parking on the site and available on site. Commissioner Berg asked if the remainder of
the Deerfield Business Center parking lot to the north is restricted to other tenants. Mr.
Freedman stated that there is a covenant that allows BJBE to utilize 40 parking spaces
in the Deerfield Business Center parking lot. This parking is off-site and is in addition to
the BJBE on-site parking. Mr. Freedman clarified that an agreement with the adjacent
High School for additional parking is in addition to the BJBE parking and the off-site
parking. Mr. Freedman noted that an agreement with the High School would be
overflow parking if necessary. Commissioner Shayman asked if there is only one
session of classes that occur on Sundays. Mr. Freedman stated that there is only one
drop-off and one pick-up time. Mr. Hamilton added that if BJBE finds that it is getting
too tight the drop-off can be off-set and staggered since peak period occurs within a 30
minute period. Dismissal is already slightly staggered as it exists. Mr. Freedman also
noted that the petitioner is well prepared to adjust programming if accommodations
need to be made in the event that parking gets to tight. Chairman Shapiro asked the
Public Hearing: BJBE
May 9, 2013
Page 4

petitioner why they think they need the High School parking. Mr. Freedman does not
think that they need the High School parking and with the additional 40 off-site parking
spaces the petitioner is well within their margin of error to meet their parking needs.
Chairman Shapiro asked Mr. Hamilton that if the High School parking was not included,
would it have any influence to his testimony especially if the petitioner had a big event.
Mr. Hamilton said no, but it would depend on the size of the big event. He stated that
the traffic and parking study estimated that all 700 students would be in attendance, and
the parking lot can handle the demand. Chairman Shapiro asked if the current parking
could accommodate a High Holiday. Mr. Freedman noted that the parking requirement
for BJBE was based upon the capacity of the sanctuary. Mr. Freedman noted that if
there were a need for parking during High Holidays, there is already an understanding
in place with the High School that the High School would accommodate overflow
parking.

Commissioner Bromberg wanted clarification on the location of the gate operated by the
High School and when it would be open. Mr. Freedman noted that the benefit of
keeping the gate open for their operations would be for easier access and circulation.
Mr. Hamilton noted that keeping the gate open allows for a more direct access to the
traffic signal. Commissioner Bromberg asked if there was a stacking issue. Mr.
Freeman stated that there no stacking issues. He also noted that since 2006, the High
School and BJBE have co-existed in a very friendly way and there have been many
accommodations and he doesn't anticipate an issue going forward. Mr. Freedman
commented that this also holds true for the Greek School.

Commissioner Bromberg asked if current enrollment was 700 students and if there are
plans for growing the program. Mr. Freedman stated that taking into account the 1141
building and Caruso, the current enrollment is 700 students. Sandy Robbins, Director
Education, BJBE, commented that they will certainly welcome new members and
depending on what is approved they will do whatever they need to do to make the work
within their maximum student numbers whether it means using shifts or staggering
classes. Mr. Freedman clarified they are still limited by the seating capacity so if BJBE
is fortunate to grow, the maximum number of students at any given time would still be
700.

Commissioner Berg asked if the traffic circulation flow in the plan was the same as the
current traffic flow for the site. Mr. Hamilton noted that the only change would be the
crossover through the High School. Under the current traffic flow pattern,
Commissioner Berg asked if there were any stacking problems on the Frontage Road
waiting for the traffic signal on Lake Cook Road. Mr. Hamilton commented that a big
percentage of vehicles go to the west on the Frontage Road, probably to avoid that
situation, and he didn't believe there was a stacking issue on the Frontage Road. Mr.
Hamilton stated that the biggest constraint was the signal time.
Public Hearing: BJBE
May 9, 2013
Page 5

Mr. Freedman added that he has submitted to the Plan Commission his responses to
the Special Use Standards for the ordinance and wanted to make sure that it was part
of their presentation and part of the public record.

Commissioner Bromberg asked the petitioner to point out the door in the link that will be
taken out of the plan. Roy Splansky, real estate specialist for BJBE, commented that
the original plan showed two points of egress from the building link. From a security
standpoint the petitioner decided it was best not to have access from the west side of
the link. The door on the east side of the link is for emergency access or alternatively
a point of entrance. If there was an event happening within the larger programming this
would allow children to enter directly into the school building without going through the
main entrance. The building link does not exist currently and the west door would be
eliminated from the plan.

Commissioner Berg motioned to close the Public Hearing and Commissioner Moyer
seconded the motion.

Respectfully submitted,
Daniel Nakahara

                                     PLAN COMMISSION
                                   VILLAGE OF DEERFIELD

The Plan Commission of the Village of Deerfield held a Workshop Meeting at 7:30 P.M. on May
9, 2013 at the Village Hall, 850 Waukegan Road, Deerfield, Illinois.

Chairman Shapiro called the meeting to order.

Present were: Dan Shapiro, Chairman
                    Larry Berg
                    Alan Bromberg
                    Jim Moyer
                    Stuart Shayman

Absent:               Elaine Jacoby

Also present:         Jeff Ryckaert, Principal Planner
                      Kathleen LéVeque, Associate Planner

Discussion of recommendation for Congregation BJBE

Chairman Shapiro asked the petitioner what would the expected timeline be for an agreement
with the High School. Mr. Freedman would guess 60 days. He noted that they have been
talking to the High School and if something can be formulated it will be done in the near future.
Chairman Shapiro asked the petitioner if there would be any objection if any approvals from the
Plan Commission or the Village Board were contingent on that approval for access from the
High School. Chairman Shapiro is concerned about access. Mr. Freedman did not favor this
because the petitioner feels that the High School approval is not needed for parking or for
access. Approval from the High School enhances the plan but is not needed for the plan to go
succeed. Commissioner Shayman does not think the access through the High School is a
major part of the traffic study. Chairman Shapiro believes approval from the High School would
be helpful. Chairman Shapiro agrees with Mr. Freedman but would like to see petitioner pledge
to use their best efforts to get the approval. Mr. Freedman stated that they will use their best
efforts because it would make the plan work better.

Commissioner Berg motioned to approve the request for an amendment to the Special
Use/Planned Unit Development and to amend Ordinance O-06-56 for Congregation B'nai
Jehoshua Beth Elohim (BJBE) to correct a discrepancy in the number of students allowed in the
1141 classroom building; to allow an additional 225 religious school students, on Sundays only,
to be accommodated throughout the entire BJBE facility; and to add a building connection
between 1141 and 1181 buildings.

Commissioner Bromberg seconded the motion.

The vote was as follows:
Ayes (5): Berg, Bromberg, Moyer, Shayman, Shapiro
Nays (0): None

This recommendation will go before the Village Board on Monday, June 3, 2013.

                             13.11-D SPECIAL USE: STANDARDS



A.     Compatible with Existing Development.

        The nature and intensity of the activities involved and the size, placement and design of any
structures proposed will be so planned that the Special Use will be compatible with the existing
development and will not impede the normal and orderly development and improvement of
surrounding property.

         Congregation B 'N ai . Jehoshua Beth Elohim ("BJBE") proposes to develop a religious
institution on a site of approximately 4.3 acres located at the property commonly known as 1141,
1181, and 1201 Lake Cook Road, south of the intersection of Lake Cook Road and Pine Street in
the Village ofDeer:field. The synagogue and related activities will include four (4) pre-kindergarten
classrooms in Phase I of the development, and an additional nineteen (19) after-school!Sunday
school classrooms in Phase II. The site development will be constructed in two (2) phases, with the
first stage to include the conversion of the buildings located at 1181 and 1201 Lake Cook Road into
a sanctuary, social hall, general offices, multi-purpose rooms and a kitchen. The second phase of
development will entail the conversion of the building located at 1141 Lake Cook Road into
nineteen (19) after-school!Si:mday school classrooms. The second phase is contemplated to take
place in 2009. The total building area after completion ofboth phases will be 71,380 square feet.
The sanctuary will seat up to 601 people and the chapel will seat up to 110 people. After
completion of Phase I, the school will have a maximum capacity of 80 pre-school students who will
utilize the facilities on weekday mornings, with teachers/staff support of 15. After completion of
Phase II, there will be a maximum capacity of 380 students after school on weekdays and during
Sunday school, with teachers/staff of 50. The property is part of a twelve (12) acre Planned Unit
Development ("PUD"), which is currently zoned I-1 Office, Research, Restricted Industrial District.
Accordingly, BJBE seeks an amendment to the PUD to provide for a special use permit for a
religious institution and appropriate text amendments with respect thereto.

        The proposed use is compatible with the rest of the PUD and particularly with the adjacent
portions thereof. To the east is the 4.97 acre Hellenic American Academy of Chicagoland and the 7
acre Chicagoland Jewish High School site, construction of which was recently commenced. To the
north is an office complex. The only residential property within the general area of the PUD is
located north of Lake Cook Road which provides a natural barrier to the PUD. There is no other
underdeveloped or undeveloped property in the immediate area which will be effected by the
proposed religious institution. The surrounding uses are not only compatible with the proposed use,
but the owners of such surrounding uses have agreed to mutually cooperate in providing use of
parking to accommodate peak periods occasioned by holidays and other particular needs occasioned
by the unique demands of any of the particular facilities. The synergies of the neighboring facilities
promote not only inter-cultural relationships, but an efficient use of neighboring properties.
B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim (BJBE)
Project Summary                                                                                           Sept. 12, 2006

The concept presented in these drawings is for the adaptive use of the three buildings 1141, 1181, and 1201 at the
Deerfield Business Center off Lake Cook Road for the B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim (BJBE) synagogue. This scheme is
the result of a master planning process with the building committee at BJBE and Finegold Alexander+ Associates Inc.
(FA+A), and we are pleased to present this to the Village of Deerfield planning commission for review and comment.

The design reflects the goals and programming needs for BJBE, and marries the qualitative and quantitative vision for the
project to transform the existing one-story office buildings to create a place of worship, assembly and education for the
synagogue. The specifics of the plans include:

    ·   Building 1181 will be renovated and expanded to accommodate a new double-height sanctuary with balconies to
        accommodate up to 600 people. The sanctuary will have a clerestory roof "lifting" to the east to admit natural light
        into the worship space.
    ·   Building 1181 will contain the Village C.enter with a new roof monitor added on top to admit natural light into the
        space. The Village court enhances opportunities for community gathering and meeting, and serves also as a pre-
        function reception area. In addition, program functions related to a central administration office core, chapel,
        library, multi-purpose rooms, bride's room, gift shop, and support spaces for toilets, coatroom, and storage are
        proposed.               '
    ·   The Village Center would open up to the existing landscape courtyard, as a central gathering and orienting space:
        in effect, an "Indoor/Outdoor Village Center".
    ·   Building 1201 will be renovated to include a new high ceiling multi-use social/cultural space large enough to
        accommodate up to 900 people on High Holy Days or 400 in banquet style seating. In addition, this building will
        also include a kitchen, storage, multipurpose rooms, and Pre-K Classroom wing. The Pre-K Classroom wing
        consists of 4 classrooms, and will accommodate up to 80 kids. These classrooms will connect directly to an
        outdoor playground space that can accommodate up to 50 kids at one time.
    ·   Building 1141 will be renovated for the Religious Day School. It consists of 19 classrooms and support spaces,
        and will accommodate up to 475 students. By locating the classrooms in this wing, it allows the school to have it's
        own identity, while connected to the rest of the synagogue through a new school entry and galleria link added to
        the east side of building 1181.
    ·   The three existing buildings of 63,282 GSF + 8.098 GSF new construction = 71,380 GSF Total.

The landscape and site plan are also proposed with modifications, which include:

    ·   A new entry Galleria link and drop-off is proposed in front of building 1181, which creates a main arrival entry
        point for BJBE. This drop-off will provide handicap parking spaces adjacent to main entry plaza.
    ·   New landscape design is proposed at the front of building 1181, with a proposed walled-in sacred garden
        surrounding the sanctuary. Existing landscaping will be preserved and enhanced where required around new
        entries and egress points.
    ·   The playground will be fenced in for control and security, outside the Pre-K classroom wing.
    ·   A new auto entry point is proposed between the New Jewish High School and our site to the northeast.
    ·   The existing 220 on-site parking spaces will reduce to 163 in the new master plan layout.
    ·   The site is 4.33 acres or 188,615 GSF, resulting in a 0.40 FAR ratio.

The proposed materials cladding the exterior renovations and additions will complement the existing one-story office
buildings, which largely consist of concrete aggregate panels and aluminum storefront windows. The Sanctuary is
proposed to be clad in precast concrete panels with a lead-coated copper roof with clerestory windows. The Social Hall is
proposed with lead coated copper panels, with larger storefront windows in metal frames at the base. The mechanical
screens, which will conceal the larger rooftop unit!:? adjacent to the sanctuary and social hall, will be metal. Finally the new
entry/galleria link is proposed as a precast concrete frame, extending full height and length along the east side of building
1181, joining to the school wing in building 1141 to create a gracious entry link and portal for the temple.

This design concept preserves what is best about the existing context, while building for the future of BJBE.

                                                 Re:    Ordinance No. 0-06-56 Approving of
                                                        Special Use for Religious Institution at
                                                        1141, 1181, and 1201 Lake Cook Road for
                                                        B'Nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim Synagogue
                                                        and Childcare Facility
                                                        Our File No. 13-50

     Dear Jeff:

             Please be advised that I represent Congregation B'Nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim, the owner
     of the property which is the subject of the captioned special use.

             The Congregation is requesting that the Village clarify a discrepancy which we recently
     noticed in the captioned Ordinance. Section 4C provides that the 1141 Lake Cook building as
     renovated would have a maximum total capacity of380 students. This appears to be the result of
     a clerical error and is in fact contrary to an exhibit attached to the Ordinance in the form of a
     Project Summary prepared by the project architect, Finegold Alexander+ Associates, Inc., dated
     September 12, 2006, which specifically provides that the renovated facility at 1141 Lake Cook
     Road would accommodate up to 475 students. Testimony given before the Plan Commission at
     the time ofthe approval of the special use was consistent with the 475 maximum capacity rather
     than the 380. Accordingly we are asking that Section 4C be clarified to reflect a maximum
     enrollment of 475 students.

              In addition, the Congregation is seeking an Amendment to the Special Use/PUD to allow
     up to an additional 225 students, on Sundays only, to be accommodated throughout the entire
     facility and not just limited to the building at 1141 Lake Cook Road. The Congregation is also
     requesting that the Final Development Plan attached to the Ordinance as Exhibit "B" be amended
     to reflect the minor modifications to the proposed plan of development which are set forth in the
     modified plan which we are delivering directly to you by separate transmission.

As is the current situation at Caruso, the vast majority of parents have carpools
arranged and drop off their students without entering the building at 9:30 am and pick
them up at noon, again without entering the building. To help facilitate egress for drop
off and pick up (if necessary), we are in discussions with the Chicagoland Jewish High
School to utilize a portion of their parking lot for additional parking as well as the
school road for exiting to Lake Cook Road. In those

discussions, there will be a contingency plan for those times when CJHS has larger
Sunday morning programming. BJBE will make alternative arrangements to either
have off-site programming for some classes (museum tours, cemetery visits) or will
schedule split drop off/pick up times.
The current Caruso site has many more challenges for traffic management in that it is
within a residential neighborhood and has only one point of ingress and egress. Traffic
from either direction must be stopped to allow the other to cross over. We do not have
this issue at our building. The office building is generally not in use and the high school
is not in session. BJBE currently utilizes traffic personnel at Caruso to facilitate the
traffic flow and will continue to do so at the temple on Sundays.
Our traffic personnel will help direct traffic such that a portion of the cars will circulate
and exit through Deerfield Business Center (DBC) and a portion will exit through
CJHS. BJBE's site has 150 parking spaces with an additional 40 spaces within the
office building per the Declaration between BJBE and DBC.
We are very excited to complete the BJBE learning center and have a thriving
Jewish educational and spiritual experience for a few hours on Sunday
mornings within our 70,000 square foot campus at 1201 Lake Cook Road. We will
continue to work with the community and our neighbors as we have done since
making Deerfield our home in 2009.
Thank you for your assistance in the zoning modification process.
Sincerely,

                       SPECIAL USE CRITERIA FOR REQUESTED
                            AMENDMENT TO 0-06-56 BJBE


1. Compatible with Existing Development
   The nature and intensity of the activities involved and the size, placement and design of any
   structures proposed will be so planned that the Special Use will be compatible with the
   existing development and will not impede the normal and orderly development and
   improvement of surrounding property.

           The requested amendment to allow an additional 225 religious school students on
           Sundays only will be compatible with the existing development and will not impede
           normal and orderly development and improvement of surrounding property in that
           there are no proposed changes in the approved site plan, landscape plan, building
           elevations, or lighting plan, and as concluded by Petitioner's traffic consultant:

               (a) The adjacent roadways can accommodate the additional anticipated Sunday
                   school traffic by continuing and supplementing a number of the traffic
                   operations that were recommended when the site was originally improved;
                   and

               (b) The projected parking demand can be accommodated on-site along with the
                   additional office park spaces which are provided by covenant.

2. Lot of Sufficient Size
   The size of the lot will be sufficient for the use proposed.

           Inasmuch as both access and parking can be accommodated, as indicated by
           Petitioner's traffic consultant, the size of the lot will be sufficient for the proposed
           use.

3. Traffic
   The location of the Special Use within the Village will be such that adverse effects on
   surrounding properties will be minimal, particularly regarding the traffic generated by the
   Special Use.

           As concluded by Petitioner's traffic consultant, the adjacent roadways can
           accommodate additional anticipated Sunday school traffic by continuing and
           supplementing a number of the traffic operations that were recommended when the
           site was originally approved, such that there will be no adverse effects on surrounding
           properties, particularly regarding the traffic generated by the Special Use as amended.

4. Parking and Access
   Parking areas will be of adequate size for the particular use and properly located, and the
   entrance and exit drives will be laid out so as to prevent traffic hazards and nuisances.
           As concluded by Petitioner's traffic consultant, the entrance and exit drives as
           currently constructed are laid out as to prevent traffic hazards and nuisances
           notwithstanding the proposed increase in an additional 225 religious school students
           on Sundays only. It is further concluded by Petitioner's traffic consultant that parking
           areas will be of adequate size for the Special Use as proposed to be amended
           inasmuch as the projected parking demands can be accommodated by on-site parking
           along with additional office park spaces provided by covenant.

5. Effect on Neighborhood
   In all respects the Special Use will not be significantly or materially detrimental to the health,
   safety and welfare of the public or injurious to the other property or improvements in the
   neighborhood, nor will it diminish or impair property values in the surrounding area.

           The Special Use has been in operation since its approval in 2006, and has operated
           with no deleterious effect on the neighborhood or surrounding area. Based upon
           Petitioner's traffic consultant's conclusions that both access and parking demand will
           not be negatively impacted by the proposed modification to the Special Use, the
           Special Use, as amended, will not significantly or materially be detrimental to the
           health, safety, and welfare of the public or injurious to other property or
           improvements in the neighborhood, nor will it diminish or impair property values in
           the surrounding area.

6. Adequate Facilities
   That adequate utilities, access roads, drainage and/or other necessary facilities have been or
   are being provided.

           The proposed increase in Sunday school students will have no impact whatsoever on
           existing utilities, drainage, or other facilities. As concluded by Petitioner's traffic
           consultant, existing access roads can accommodate the additional anticipated traffic
           by continuing and supplementing a number of the traffic operations which were
           recommended when the site was originally approved. Accordingly, adequate utilities,
           access roads, drainage and/or other necessary facilities have been or are being
           provided.

7. Adequate Buffering
   Adequate fencing and/or screening shall be provided to ensure the enjoyment of surrounding
   properties, to provide for the public safety or to screen parking areas and other visually
   incompatible uses.

           The proposed amendment to the Special Use does not require any changes to the
           buffering which was approved and provided pursuant to the original Special Use,
           such that adequate fencing and/or screening is provided to insure enjoyment of
           surrounding properties and to provide for public safety and to screen parking areas
           and other visually and incompatible uses without any modifications thereto.

Amendment to Special Use for the BJBE property
Village of Deerfield


To Whom It May Concern:
Ms. Sandy Robbins of B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim has (BJBE) has asked me to write a letter of
recommendation for the temple and it is with pleasure that I do so.
Ms. Robbins and the temple have rented significant amounts of space from Deerfield Public Schools District
109 since 2006 for religious education classes for both weekday evenings and their Sunday morning program
(the last few years their use was Sunday mornings only). She, her teachers and students have been excellent
partners in using this community space while public school is out of session. They treat our classrooms and
teachers' belongings respectfully. BJBE always had traffic management personnel in place and we did not have
any issues with traffic flow within the site or with the surrounding neighborhood.
I understand that the Deerfield Plan Commission and Village Board are meeting to discuss an Amendment to
Special Use for the BJBE property and I hope you will consider this letter in your considerations.
Sincerely,




Greg Himebaugh

On behalf of Deerfield Office Center LLC, I have reviewed the materials submitted by Congregation B'nai  
Jehoshua Beth Elohim,  "BJBE" related to their request to amend the zoning to increase the number of 
students to 700 on Sundays only.  I have also reviewed the Traffic Planning Study completed by Gewalt 
Hamilton Associates dated May 8, 2013. 
 
Since the completion of BJBE's first phase BJBE administrative staff and personnel have consistently 
managed the traffic and parking needs in accordance with the Deerfield Business Centers Declaration of 
Covenants, Easements and Restrictions.   This includes the hiring of extra traffic personnel for special 
events such as holidays and funerals.  If past practices are any indication of the future I am confident 
BJBE will effectively manage the parking and passage of vehicles with the increased number of students 
on Sundays.
