TRAFFIC PLANNING STUDY
To:          Ms. Arlene Mayzel
             Congregation B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim

Copy:        Roy Splansky ­ Venture One Real Estate
From:        Daniel P. Brinkman, P.E., PTOE
Date:        May 8, 2013
Subject:     Congregation B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim
             1201 Lake Cook Road
             Proposed Education Program Consolidation
             Deerfield, Illinois

                SECTION 1 PROJECT CONTEXT AND SUMMARY STATEMENT

GEWALT HAMILTON ASSOCIATES, INC. (GHA) has investigated the traffic planning and parking
requirements of the above referenced project. Congregation B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim (BJBE)
proposes to expand its current on-site Sunday School program by bringing those students currently
utilizing space at Caruso Middle School back to the site.

Our study findings are discussed below and various recommendations are offered for your consideration.
Exhibits referenced in the text are centrally located in the Technical Addendum at the end of this report.

Briefly summarizing, we believe that the adjacent roadways can accommodate the additional anticipated
Sunday School traffic by continuing and supplementing a number of the Traffic Operations that were
recommended when the Temple site was originally approved. Furthermore, projected parking demands
can be accommodated by BJBE's on-site and agreed to shared parking supply. Key elements to
successfully managing the additional traffic and parking include:

      Continued coordination with adjacent religious schools (Hellenic American Academy and the
      Chicagoland Jewish High School) to minimize overlap of significant activities and special events.
      Peak Traffic for Sunday School occurs when the majority of the adjacent office space is at minimal
      operations.
      Continue to seek agreements to accommodate additional on and off site overflow parking.
      Maintain current one-way flow around BJBE site and seek use of CJHS connection and driveway to
      separate exiting traffic.
      Sunday School and primary worship services are not concurrent.
                                                                              B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim
                                                                                    1201 Lake Cook Road
                                                                                            Deerfield, IL
                          SECTION 2 BACKGROUND INFORMATION

Exhibits 1 and 2 ­ Site Location Map and Site Context

Exhibit 1 identifies the location of Congregation B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim (BJBE), which is
comprised of three buildings in the Deerfield Business Center (1141, 1181, and 1201 Lake Cook Road)
and utilizes the 1201 Lake Cook Road address. The Deerfield Business Center is made up of a total of
six buildings located on approximately 10.5-acres at the southwest corner of the Pine Street intersection
with Lake Cook Road in the Village of Deerfield, Illinois.

Approximately 100 feet south of Lake Cook Road, there is an internal intersection that serves the office
development to the west, the Hellenic American Academy located at 1085 Lake Cook Road to the east
and the south leg provides access to both Congregation BJBE and the Chicagoland Jewish High School
(CJHS). All inbound BJBE traffic accesses the site from a point approximately 350 feet south of the
frontage road intersection and circulation around the BJBE buildings is one way clockwise.

Exhibit 2 provides an aerial photo of the surrounding uses for context.

Exhibit 3 ­ Photographic Inventory

Exhibit 3 provides a photo inventory of current operations at the internal Frontage Road intersection as
well as the BJBE entrance and drop off areas.

Exhibit 4 ­ Existing Traffic Volumes

On Sunday April 21, 2013 GHA conducted peak period (7:00 am to 2:00 pm) traffic counts at the
Frontage road intersections with Pine Street, the Deerfield business Center driveways and the BJBE /
CJHS driveway split. Two resultant peak hours were observed associated with the predominant drop-off
/ pick-up movements in lieu of parents staying on-site with their children. The "inbound" peak occurred
from 9:00 to 10:00 am and the "outbound" peak hour occurred from 11:00 am to 12:00 pm. Those traffic
volumes are illustrated in Exhibit 4. While we present and discuss hourly volumes the true peaks of
these two movements are much shorter, with the inbound peak only lasting between 15-20 minutes and
the outbound peak lasting between 25-30 minutes.

Observations were also conducted by GHA at Caruso Middle School on Sunday May 5, 2013 to
quantify the impact of moving the Sunday school program from Caruso to the 1201 Lake Cook site.
Similar, shortened peak periods were observed at Caruso.

No unusual delays occurred during the counts such as foul weather (e.g. heavy snowfall or rain), road
construction, or emergency vehicle activity that would adversely affect the volumes or travel patterns.

Traffic count data summaries can be found in Appendix I.

Exhibit 5 ­ Existing Parking Occupancy

Concurrently with our Sunday traffic observations, GHA conducted hourly parking occupancy counts in
the Deerfield Business Center, the Hellenic American Academy lot and the CJHS parking lot. Exhibit 5
illustrates the parking lot designations as well as summarizes the parking occupancy by hour and the
                                                              Gewalt Hamilton Associates, Inc. ­ Page 2
                                                                                B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim
                                                                                      1201 Lake Cook Road
                                                                                              Deerfield, IL
peak occupancy during our observation period. As can be seen, while HAA and CJHS had some limited
activities, the Deerfield Business Center was almost vacant and the CJHS parking demand peaked at 80
vehicles on site during the 10-11:00 am hour.

The following tabulates the supplemental parking observations at Caruso School which were conducted
on Sunday May 5, 2013.

    Hour Beginning            North Lot            South Lot             Total            BJBE

         8:00                       2             10 (4 busses)           12                 6
         9:00                      47             7 (3 busses)             54               30
         10:00                     81             21 (3 busses)           102               30
         11:00                     99             27 (3 busses)           126               30
         12:30                     36             16 (3 busses)           52                15

Notes: Portions of parking demand associated with athletic field use. Special BJBE program on site in
conjunction with athletic field use resulted in offsite parking on adjacent residential streets. BJBE
demand represents typical operations of ±30 teachers and staff.

                      SECTION 3 PROJECT TRAFFIC CHARACTERISTICS

Exhibit 6 ­ Building Plan

Included as Exhibit 6 is the April 15, 2013 site plan prepared by Finegold Alexander and Associates,
Inc. (FAA) depicting the planned internal renovations to the 1141 building to accommodate the
additional students that will be relocated from Caruso School.

Exhibit 7 ­ Project Traffic Characteristics

Traffic Generations

Part A of Exhibit 7 tabulates the observed traffic volumes for the current Sunday Peak Periods at BJBE
as observed by GHA on Sunday April 21 2013 as well as the subsequent observations at Caruso School
on Sunday May 5, 2013. Traffic volumes at both locations exhibited distinct "inbound" and "outbound"
peaks which have been tabulated separately. As can be seen, the "inbound" and "outbound" peaks were
observed between 9:00 to 10:00 am and 11:00 am to 12:00 pm respectively. These periods coincide with
the beginning and ending times of the Sunday school program from 9:30 am to 12:00 pm.

The total number of inbound and outbound trips during the two peak hours was utilized to determine an
average trip rate for the total number of attendees at the two sites. We feel that this represents a
conservative approach to projecting traffic volume for a larger group because: 1) parents with children
in multiple age groups / classes would have been counted at both locations, 2) the trips at the Temple
site also include traffic activities associated with other adult oriented programs and worship that occur
concurrently with Sunday School.

Part B. of Exhibit 7 utilizes the above referenced average rate to project traffic volumes out to the
ultimate 700 student capacity of the BJBE campus on Lake Cook Road. The increased student
attendance at BJBE is expected to generate approximately 450 additional trips during each of the peak
                                                             Gewalt Hamilton Associates, Inc. ­ Page 3
                                                                                B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim
                                                                                      1201 Lake Cook Road
                                                                                              Deerfield, IL
hours. As noted above, this volume is likely overstated, but we believe that it allows us to analyze the
maximum potential impacts of the planned consolidation of the education program.

Trip Distribution

Part C of Exhibit 7 summarizes the observed directional distribution of BJBE traffic. We observed that
slightly more traffic arrived and departed to and from the west along Lake Cook Road and the frontage
road than to and from the east. After years of being prohibited, traffic is now permitted to travel north
and south across Lake Cook Road at Pine Street. Due to the current separated programs, it is possible
that the ultimate distribution could be different as parents make a single stop in Deerfield vs. potentially
two stops due to the current separation of the education program.

                                     SECTION 4 EVALUATION

Exhibits 8 & 9 ­ Sunday School Traffic Assignments

Traffic generated by the proposed consolidation of BJBE Sunday School classes was "assigned" to the
adjacent roadways based on the project characteristics (see Exhibit 7) and the site's access system and is
illustrated in Exhibit 8. BJBE traffic was then combined with the Existing Traffic volumes (see Exhibit
4) to yield the Total Traffic assignment, which is presented, in Exhibit 9.

Exhibit 10 ­ Parking Calculations

The current BJBE site provides approximately 149 parking spaces. There is an agreement with Deerfield
Business Center to utilize an additional 40 and ongoing discussions with CJHS to utilize some of their
189 spaces for overflow.

In GHA's original analyses of parking demands for BJBE, the maximum parking demand on site was
expected to occur on Friday evenings and holidays when the full congregation attends services in the
sanctuary. During the week programs were expected to have a maximum of 100 attendees. Therefore
parking demand for the original development was based on the seating capacity of the Chapel space
(approximately 711).

Using the Place of Worship calculation (1 space per 4 seats) parking demand / requirement was
established at 178 spaces (1 space / 4 seats = 711/4 = 177.75). While not met on-site it was proposed
that BJBE would work with adjacent properties to make arrangements for overflow parking when those
uses are not at peak operations.

Our observed Peak Demand for parking at BJBE on Sunday was 80 spaces. Of the various activities that
occurred at Caruso School, the typical parking demand for Sunday School is approximately 30,
primarily teachers and adult assistants for the education programs. These combined observations result
in an average parking demand of 0.23 spaces per attendee (almost exactly the same as the 1 space per 4
seats of the worship area calculations). While we are aware of no current plan to add significant staff for
the consolidation and expansion of the on-site education program, if parking demand increased at the
average rate of 0.23 spaces per attendee to 700 attendees total an additional 52 spaces would be
required.



                                                               Gewalt Hamilton Associates, Inc. ­ Page 4
                                                                                 B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim
                                                                                       1201 Lake Cook Road
                                                                                               Deerfield, IL
Exhibit 10 includes three separate tables which provide:

Part A ­ Observed parking demand in the study area at BJBE as well as supplemental demand of Sunday
         School programming at Caruso.

Part B ­ Projected additional demand of net increase to 700 students at 0.23 spaces per student average
         as observed.

Part C ­ Future Parking demands in Study area. As can be seen there is only one hour that parking is
         expected to exceed demand of the on-site BJBE supply of 149 spaces. However the anticipated
         demand does not exceed the additional 40 spaces available to BJBE in the Deerfield Business
         Center.

Exhibit 11 ­ Recommended Traffic Operations

Exhibit 11 notes key operational recommendations to allow the existing site and surrounding roadways
to accommodate the anticipated increases in traffic associated with consolidation of the Sunday School
program

1. Continue to seek and utilize cross parking agreements for overflow parking at peak times.
2. Utilize traffic personnel to coordinate internal intersection operations at south end of drop off lane.
3. Utilize CJHS cross access as additional site exit for drop off / pick up maneuvers during peak
   periods
4. Maintain one-way circulation pattern on site
5. Consider alternate drop-off pick up locations if necessary

While we believe our analyses has conservatively considered the maximum traffic and parking impacts
on site, should congestion and parking concerns arise, BJBE could always consider staggered class start
and end times to reduce the intensity of the short traffic peaks.

Note that all of the following recommendations from the original study have been completed:

   Extend the westbound left turn lane from its current length of 150 feet to 300 feet. [CCHD]
   Modify existing traffic signal timing and phasing at the Lake Cook / Pine Street intersection.
   [CCHD]
   Widen the south leg of the frontage road intersection to provide two northbound lanes. [CJHS]
   Coordinate with CJHS to consider a one way (right turn only) connection near the BJBE building
   entrance. [BJBE]
   Consider a second, gated connection between the BJBE and CJHS sites to allow easier cross access
   for shared parking arrangements and provide both sites with an alternate emergency access. [BJBE]



                                                                Gewalt Hamilton Associates, Inc. ­ Page 5
                                                                            B'nai Jehoshua Beth Elohim
                                                                                  1201 Lake Cook Road
                                                                                          Deerfield, IL

                        REQUEST FOR BOARD ACTION

                                                        Agenda Item: 13-54


Subject:       Report and Recommendation of the Plan Commission re: Request
               to rezone the property at 780 Saunders Road from R-1 Single
               Family Residential District to C-2 Outlying Commercial District, for
               an amendment to the Comprehensive Plan and a Special Use for a
               restaurant ­ Health O Wealth, Inc.

Action Requested:           Approval for Recommendation

Originated by:              Plan Commission

Referred to:                Mayor and Board of Trustees


Summary of Background and Reason for Request:

The petitioners are requesting approval of a rezoning for the property located at
780 Saunders Road from R-1 Single Family Residential District to C-2 Outlying
Commercial District, for an amendment to the Comprehensive Plan, and a
Special Use for a restaurant ­ Health O Wealth, Inc.

Reports and Documents Attached:

Recommendation
Public Hearing Minutes 4/11/13
Workshop Minutes 4/11/13
Workshop Minutes 2/28/13
Workshop Minutes 12/13/12
Zoning Map
Aerial Photos
Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use Map and Bicycle Routes Map
Letters from Lake County DOT and Deerfield-Bannockburn Fire Department
Petitioner's Materials
Correspondence from Neighbors


Date Referred to Board: June 3, 2013

Action Taken: __________________________________________
                                                                               APPROVED


                                   RECOMMENDATION

TO: Mayor and Board of Trustees

FROM: Plan Commission

DATE: April 11, 2013

RE: Public hearing on the request to rezone the property at 780 Saunders Road from R-1
Single Family Residential District to C-2 Outlying Commercial District, for an amendment
to the Comprehensive Plan and a Special Use for a restaurant ­ Health O Wealth, Inc.

We transmit for your consideration a recommendation adopted by the Plan Commission of
the Village of Deerfield on the request of the petitioners for a rezoning of the property at
780 Saunders Road from R-1 Single Family Residential District to C-2 Outlying
Commercial District, for an amendment to the Comprehensive Plan, and a Special Use for
a restaurant. The Plan Commission held a public hearing on April 11, 2013. At that public
hearing, the petitioners presented testimony and documentary evidence in support of the
request. A copy of the public hearing and workshop minutes are attached.

In support of its request, the Plan Commission makes the following findings of fact and
conclusions:

                                  FINDINGS OF FACT

Subject Property

The subject property consists of the property at 780 Saunders Road. The property is
zoned R-1 Single Family Residential and is approximately 32,700 square feet in area (100
feet wide and 327 feet deep) and is currently developed with a single family home.

Surrounding Zoning and Land Use

North: Village of Riverwoods ­ commercial properties (bank with a drive-thru and a gas
 station with convenience store)
South: I-1 Office, Research and Restricted Industry ­ Parkway North Center
East: I-1 Office, Research and Restricted Industry ­ Parkway North Center
West (across Saunders Road): Village of Riverwoods ­ single family homes

Proposed Plan

The petitioners have purchased the property at 780 Saunders Road and propose to
redevelop it. They are seeking approval to rezone the property from R-1 Single Family
Residential to C-2 Outlying Commercial. They propose to develop the site with a single
building to be used for a restaurant and a parking area. The proposed restaurant will be
3,000 s.f. in area and will have a 2,000 s.f. outdoor deck area for dining. The restaurant
building will be located in the southwest corner of the site. Vehicular access will be from a
driveway on Saunders Road. The proposed parking area will be located on the north and
east of the restaurant and will contain 33 parking spaces in including 2 handicapped
spaces. Traffic flow will be in a counterclockwise direction through the site. There will be
no vehicular connections to the adjacent Parkway North Center property or bank property.
The petitioner's site plan shows a pedestrian path connecting to the existing Parkway
North Center walking trail to the east. The petitioners' plans show a future connecting
pathway leading to Saunders Road, subject to Lake County coordination.

The proposed restaurant will be called Health O Wealth and the restaurant will have a
mission of promoting wellness, health, and nutrition. The petitioners project their annual
sales to be between $750,000 and $1 million. The proposed restaurant will sell freshly
prepared casual meals and prepackaged foods. The petitioners have provided a sample
menu which includes items such as smoothies, wraps, paninis, salads, soups, and
espresso bar drinks. The proposed restaurant will be open from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m., with the
peak time being noon. The petitioners anticipate the restaurant will have 10 employees,
with a maximum of 4 to 5 employees working at one time, and will expect a maximum of
20 to 30 patrons at one time. The petitioners have indicated they anticipate the
restaurants business to be about 60% carry out and 40% dine in. The petitioner's
materials indicate they anticipate deliveries and loading to occur between 5 a.m. and 6
a.m.

The entrances to the restaurant building are located off the outdoor deck. Patrons enter
the deck area and can then access the restaurant. The floor plan shows the interior of the
restaurant containing a cash register area, a seating and retail area, an office, a storage
area, and restrooms. The floor plans for the proposed restaurant show that in the winter
the petitioners will have the tables and chairs located indoors and in the summer, a portion
of the tables and chairs will be moved outdoors. The overall seating capacity of the
restaurant will not increase with the outdoor seating area.

The proposed exterior materials for the restaurant building are shown on the petitioner's
elevation drawings. A metal screen will wrap most of the building and the outdoor deck,
and this metal screen can serve as a support for a green wall. A structural steel element
will support the metal screen. Behind the metal screen will be translucent wall panels.
The south wall of the restaurant building which separates it from the deck will be high
efficiency glazed telescoping wall panels. The metal screen will be on the north side of the
restaurant building, the south side of the deck, as well as the northern portion of the east
and west elevations. The southern portion of the east elevation will be open and a ramp
will lead to the outdoor deck. The southern portion of the west elevation will have a
screening wall made from reclaimed wood or environmentally responsibly material and a
ramp where patrons can enter. The outdoor deck and ramps will be made with reclaimed
wood or a rapidly renewable material. The outdoor deck will contain bike racks.
The petitioner's materials indicate that there are several green features for the building
including the possibility of creating a green wall on the metal screen which wraps the
building, the use of reclaimed or rapidly renewable wood and the use of some
environmentally responsible materials, use of low VOC materials inside the building, and a



                                              2
stormwater recharge basin on-site. Also, the packaging for their products will be 100%
biodegradable.

Access

Lake County has jurisdiction over Saunders Road. The Lake County Division of
Transportation has granted full access for the proposed restaurant at 780 Saunders Road.
The letter from LCDOT is included with the petitioner's materials.

Zoning Conformance

Rezoning

The subject property is currently zoned R-1 Single Family Residential. In order to allow
the proposed redevelopment of the parcel with a restaurant, the property has to be
rezoned to the appropriate zoning district which is C-2 Outlying Commercial District.
Attached are the standards for rezoning.

Special Use

The petitioners are seeking approval of a Special Use for the proposed restaurant.

Staff has inquired with the petitioners about the possibility of a condition being placed on
the property that designates the use for this property for retail or restaurant only. If the
proposed restaurant left the property, the petitioner would be required to replace the use
with another use that generated sales tax for the Village. The petitioners have indicated
that they would agree to such a restriction as a condition of approval.

Minimum Yards

Front Yard (to west)
Required: 50 feet
Proposed: 25 feet to the building (variation needed)
           18.6 feet to the outdoor dining deck (variation needed)

Rear Yard (to east)
Required: 10 feet
Proposed: 148.4 feet for the building
           140.3 feet to the outdoor dining deck

Side Yards (to north and south)
Required: 12 feet
Proposed: 42.9 feet from the building to the north property line
           6.9 feet from the building to the south property line for the outdoor deck dining
           area (variation needed)




                                              3
Maximum Building Height

The maximum building height allowed for a commercial PUD in the C-2 Outlying
Commercial District is 35 feet. Mechanical appurtenances can exceed the maximum
building height by no more than 12 feet in height. The petitioner's elevation drawings show
the highest point on the building is the metal screen, which reaches a height of 21 feet.

Screening of Mechanicals

Any rooftop mechanicals would need to be screened from view. The petitioners have
indicated to staff that no rooftop mechanicals are proposed at this time, and no ground
level HVAC units are proposed.

Maximum Lot Coverage

Allowed: The maximum lot coverage is 30% of the lot.
Proposed: 18.06% lot coverage.

Required Parking

Based on the anticipated 40 percent dine-in and 60 percent carry-out, a total of 35 parking
spaces are required for the restaurant, and a total of 69 parking spaces are required when
the proposed outdoor dining area is included in the parking calculation (dine-in: 3,000 s.f. x
.40 = 1,200 / 60 = 20; plus carry-out: 3,000 s.f. x .60 = 1,800 / 120 = 15; plus outdoor
dining: 2,000 s.f. / 60 = 33.3 = 34; 20 + 15 + 34 = 69 parking spaces).
The site plan shows there are 33 parking spaces provided including 2 handicapped
spaces. Variation needed for parking spaces.

The Zoning Ordinance indicates that outdoor seating is counted toward required parking
unless the Village believes the outdoor seating area will not have an adverse impact on
parking, and then the area of the outdoor seating area would not be counted in the
required number of parking spaces for the restaurant. The petitioners have indicated that
they believe that when the weather is nice, the outdoor dining area will attract patrons who
would otherwise dine inside. They do not believe the outdoor dining area will generate
additional parking demand. If outdoor dining is added to the required parking, 34 more
spaces would be need to be added (2,000 / 60 s.f. for a sit-down restaurant = 33.3 = 34
spaces). The parking requirements for a restaurant can be increased or decreased up to
25 percent by the Board of Trustees upon the recommendation of the Plan Commission.

The petitioners have hired TADI to conduct a traffic and parking study. The petitioner's
consultant conducted traffic counts on Saunders Road and determined that the peak times
are weekday mornings from 7:45 to 8:45 a.m. and weekday evenings from 4:30 to 5:30
p.m. The morning traffic consists of 73% of vehicles traveling southbound, and the
evening traffic consists of 75% of vehicles traveling northbound. Exhibit 2 in the traffic
study shows existing traffic counts at the peak times. The study references the ITE
manual to determine trip generation for the proposed restaurant. Table 2 shows the



                                              4
anticipated site-generated traffic projections for the restaurant. It is anticipated that during
the morning peak hour there will be 20 trips in and 15 trips out, for a total of 35 trips.
During the evening peak hour it is anticipated that there will be a 20 trips in and 10 trips
out, for a total of 30 trips. Daily the restaurant is anticipated to have a total of 380 trips.
The petitioners expect the restaurant to be operational by the year 2014 and have
predicted the traffic impacts for the year 2019. They have applied a 3% annual growth to
existing traffic volumes according Lake County DOT guidelines. Exhibit 2 shows the
predicted traffic counts for the year 2019, including the traffic generated by the restaurant.
The petitioners have conducted a level of service delay analysis at the intersection of the
Saunders Road and the restaurant's driveway. The Lake County DOT has granted full
access for the proposed restaurant driveway. The proposed restaurant is not anticipated
to cause significant delays on Saunders Road, but delays are expected for customers
making left turns out of the restaurant. The petitioners anticipate that typically only one
vehicle will be queued to exit the restaurant site. The petitioners believe that access to the
site will be adequate to serve the restaurant.

TADI examined the proposed on-site parking and circulation. Vehicles will navigate
counterclockwise through the site. The two easternmost parallel parking spaces have
been removed in order to accommodate turning vehicles circulating the site. TADI
recommends that 3 or 4 parallel parking stalls be designated and signed for employee
parking.

Screening of Parking Lots

Required: Permanent peripheral screening at least five (5) feet high shall be constructed in
side and rear yards adjacent to parking areas. This screening may consist of a planted
earth berm, densely planted evergreen shrubs or trees, or a combination of both. In side
and rear yards, the screening shall be so located and constructed as to not interfere or
conflict with the use of any utility easements or utility installations existing or planned to be
installed in these easement areas.

Proposed: The petitioner's site plan shows plantings along the north and south (side) yards
and the east (rear) yard to screen the parking area. The site plan indicates that the
plantings are five feet high as required and that they will consist of densely planted
evergreen shrubs or trees.

Location of Parking Spaces

Required: Parking spaces must be located at least 5 feet from the property line in
commercial districts.

Proposed: The site plan shows the following dimensions for the parking lot to the lot line:
 North: 5 feet from the property line
 South: 10.2 feet from the property line
 East: 6 feet from the property line
 West: approximately 18 feet from the property line



                                                5
Size of Parking Spaces

90 degree parking spaces:
Required: 9 feet by 19 feet
Proposed: 9 feet by 19 feet

Parallel parking spaces:
Required: 8.5 feet by 23 feet
Proposed: 8.5 feet by 23 feet

Drive Aisle Widths

Aisle widths for 90 degree parking spaces:
Required: 24 feet
Proposed: 24 feet

Aisle widths for parallel parking spaces:
Required: 24 feet for two-way aisles; 12 feet for one-way aisles
Proposed: 24.5 feet for the two-way aisle; 12.5 feet for the one-way aisle

Loading

Required: The proposed restaurant building is below the square footage threshold where
the Zoning Ordinance has specifications for required loading areas. According to Article
8.03-G of the Zoning Ordinance, where buildings are less than the minimum square
footage required for off-street loading facilities, such facilities shall be provided with
adequate receiving facilities with vehicular access to the property.

Proposed: A specific loading area is not shown on the site plan. The petitioners have
indicated that the loading will occur between 5 and 6 a.m., before the restaurant is open to
customers, so they do not anticipate conflicts between the loading and customer traffic.
The TADI traffic and parking study also examined loading and includes a turning analysis
for 30 foot truck. The petitioner's consultant recommends that all loading, delivery and
refuse collection occur during non-business hours.

Stormwater Detention and Utilities

The petitioners have been working with the Village Engineers regarding stormwater, water
service, and sanitary sewer service. The property is under the threshold for size and
impervious coverage where the petitioners would have to provide stormwater detention on
site. The petitioners have elected to provide stormwater recharge basins with natural
plantings located at the southeast corner of the site, as shown on the site plan. This will
allow stormwater to filter back into the ground. The roof drains discharge into the south
side yard swale in order to allow for the stormwater to infiltrate and recharge into the
ground.




                                             6
The adjacent Parkway North property is served by Village water. The petitioner's Site
Utilities Plan indicates there are two options for water service connection, which will be
determined based on conversations with Parkway North Center. One option is to connect
to a water main located in Deerfield Road right-of-way, about 200 feet north of the subject
property. The other option is to connect to a water main located about 150 feet southeast
of the subject property.

The property will need a sanitary sewer connection, which is shown on the plan as coming
off Deerfield Road. In this area of the Village, sanitary sewer connections are provided
through Lake County's special service area #5 (SSA #5). The petitioners are working with
Lake County to connect to SSA #5.

Bike Racks

The Zoning Ordinance requires that where appropriate, all developments in the
commercial districts have to provide for bicycle storage, and safe and smooth internal
circulation. The petitioners' plans show that bike racks will be provided on the deck area.

In 2010, Deerfield Road was designated a regional bike corridor by the Northwest
Municipal Conference. In the last couple years, an underpass was created for bikes and
pedestrians to cross under the Tollway ramp on the north side of Deerfield Road, and
further west on Deerfield Road a new bike path and bridge over the Des Plaines River
were created by Lake County. Deerfield Road is also part of Deerfield's bike route in the
Village's Comprehensive Plan (see attached Deerfield Bike Route Map from the
Comprehensive Plan).

Trash/Refuse Area

Required: The petitioners are required to screen the trash/refuse area.
Proposed: A composting area will be provided east of the restaurant building. The
petitioner's plans indicate the composting area will be screened. The trash and recycling
area will be located inside the building, and which can be accessed from doors on the
north side of the building. The recycling and composting is part of the restaurant's
reduced/zero waste approach and provide an educational opportunity for customers and
employees.

Landscaping

The petitioner's plans show the proposed landscaping along the western property line in
front of the building and near the ground sign. Landscaping is also shown along the south
and north property lines.




                                             7
Signage

Wall Signs

The content of the signs can contain the name of the business and a logo.

Number:

   Permitted: For each use occupying a ground floor, one (1) sign facing a public street,
   public right-of-way, or parking area.

   Proposed: One sign on the west wall for the proposed restaurant facing Saunders
   Road. The sign will contain the logo and name of the restaurant, Health O Wealth.

Area:

   Permitted: The Zoning Ordinance allows 8 percent of the area of the wall or 80 square
   feet for a front and rear wall sign whichever is greater, and 4 percent of the area of the
   wall or 40 square feet for a side wall sign, whichever is greater.

   Proposed: The size of wall signs is measured by placing a box is placed around all the
   sign elements. The proposed west (front) wall sign will be 2' in height by 24' in length
   for a total of 48 s.f.

Location:

   Permitted: Wall signs may be located on the outermost wall of the principal building
   fronting a public street, public right-way, easement for access or parking area.

   Proposed: The proposed wall sign will be located on the west wall facing Saunders
   Road.

Height:

   Permitted: Wall signs may not project higher than the parapet line of the roof or more
   than 30' above curb level, whichever is lower.

   Proposed: The petitioner's plans show the top of the wall sign is about the level of the
   roof deck at 16 feet high on the building. The petitioners have indicated that the wall
   sign and logo will be located below the roof deck.




                                              8
Ground Sign

The content of the ground sign can contain the name of the business and a logo.

Number:

   Permitted: No more than one (1) ground sign per zoning lot.

   Proposed: One ground sign along Saunders Road.

Area:

   Permitted: The maximum surface area shall not exceed thirty-two (32) square feet for
   each exposed face.

   Proposed: The proposed ground sign will be 5' 6" wide by 3'11" high for a total area of
   21.5 s.f.

Location:

   Permitted: Ground signs may be located in a required front, side or year yard but shall
   not extend over any lot line.

   Proposed: The petitioner's plans show the ground sign is located in the front yard and
   that it is not extending over the lot line.

Comprehensive Plan

The Village's future land use map in the Comprehensive Plan (an advisory document that
guides growth in the Village) indicates that this property should be office/research use. In
order to allow commercial development, the Comprehensive Plan would have to be
amended to allow commercial development on this parcel. Attached is the Future Land
Use from the Comprehensive Plan.

Appearance Review Commission (ARC)

If the property is rezoned to the C-2 Outlying Commercial District, the petitioners will have
to seek ARC approval of the proposed building, landscaping, and signage.

Board of Zoning Appeals (BZA)

As this is a non-PUD property, any variations must be considered by the Board of Zoning
Appeals (BZA). The petitioners held a public hearing with the BZA on May 7, 2013.




                                              9
                                     CONCLUSIONS

Request for a map amendment to rezone the subject property from R-1 Single
Family Residence to C-2 Outlying Commercial District.

The Plan Commission has reviewed the criteria for a rezoning and believes that the
petitioners have presented evidence to warrant a rezoning of the subject property. The
Plan Commission believes that a rezoning is appropriate given the existing surrounding
uses in the area. Properties to the north of the subject property are developed commercial
uses in the Village of Riverwoods. The Plan Commission believes the proposed rezoning
would permit a well planned development that will be compatible with the surrounding
properties. The Plan Commission believes the proposed restaurant will coexist well with
the other land uses in the area. The subject property is currently zoned R-1 Single Family
District. The Plan Commission believes the requested rezoning of the property from R-1
Single Family District to C-2 Outlying Commercial will be a suitable zoning district for the
proposed use. The property is being rezoned to the appropriate district for a restaurant.
The Plan Commission believes the rezoning of this property will permit a well planned
development in a suitable zoning classification. The Plan Commission believes that the
subject property is unsuitable and inappropriate for a single family home. The Plan
Commission believes the trend of development in the general area has been commercial
and not residential. Sales and property tax revenue to the Village would be greater if the
property was to be developed commercially.

Amendment to Comprehensive Plan

The Plan Commission believes the requested amendment to the Comprehensive Plan is
appropriate and they are in favor of the change. They believe the proposed commercial
use is an appropriate use of this property and believe the petitioners have submitted a
well-planned commercial use for this property.

Special Use for Proposed Restaurant:

Compatible with Existing Development

The Plan Commission believes that the proposed restaurant will be compatible with
existing development and should not impede the orderly development and improvement of
surrounding properties. They believe the proposed restaurant is a good and appropriate
use of the property and will be compatible with the existing development in the area. The
property to the north is a commercial area, and property to the south and east is office.
The property is adjacent to a busy four lane road. The Plan Commission believes the use
will not have an adverse impact on the area. The property was previously used as a single
family residence which the Plan Commission believes is not an appropriate use for this
parcel which is an isolated residential use.




                                            10
Lot of Sufficient Size

The Plan Commission believes the subject property is of sufficient size for the proposed
restaurant use. The Plan Commission believes that the property is suitable for the
proposed use and will not create a negative impact on surrounding properties. They
believe the proposed commercial use of the property is appropriate and the proposed
restaurant is well planned.

Traffic

The Plan Commission believes that the proposed use should not create traffic problems on
the subject property and should not have an adverse impact on surrounding properties.
The Plan Commission heard testimony from the petitioner's traffic consultant and they
believe the proposed use should not significantly increase traffic volumes in the area.
Saunders Road already carries a significant amount of traffic, and the additional traffic
generated by the restaurant would have minimal impact on the area. A large percentage
of the business will be from drivers already passing by on the roadway. The Plan
Commission believes that the proposed restaurant will have minimal traffic impact on the
surrounding properties. They believe the traffic generated by the proposed restaurant will
not have an adverse impact on the area. The Plan Commission also believes the traffic
will flow well on the site.

Parking and Access

The Plan Commission believes that parking will be adequate for the proposed restaurant.
They believe the proposed restaurant should not create a parking problem in the area.
They are a couple spaces short of the requirement, but the Plan Commission believes
there will be plenty of spaces for the day to day operations of the restaurant. The
petitioners have indicated that restaurant employees can park at the nearby Mobile gas
station. The Plan Commission does not believe there is a need to count the outdoor dining
area in the required parking count. The petitioners have indicated that when the outdoor
dining area is open, tables and chairs from inside the restaurant will be moved outside, so
there will not be an increase in the seating capacity of the restaurant. The seating capacity
for the restaurant is 60 people. The carry-out customers will be in and out of the restaurant
in a short amount of time creating a quick turn over in the parking lot.

The Plan Commission believes that the means of ingress and egress can safely handle the
traffic generated by the proposed restaurant. The Plan Commission believes that the full
access point on Saunders Road will be able to safely handle the traffic generated by the
development. The petitioners have been working with the Lake Cook Highway
Department (which has jurisdiction over Saunders Road) and they have granted the
restaurant parcel full access to Saunders Road. The Plan Commission is pleased there will
be a pedestrian connection to the Parkway North Center development allowing office users
easy access to the restaurant.




                                             11
Effect on Neighborhood

The Plan Commission believes the proposed restaurant should not be significantly or
materially detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare of the public or injurious to the other
property or improvements in the neighborhood nor should it diminish or impair property
values in the surrounding area. The restaurant parcel is connected by a sidewalk to the
Parkway North Center allowing the office development patrons easy walking access to the
restaurant. The Plan Commission believes the proposed use will not have an adverse
impact on surrounding properties. The Plan Commission the proposed use should not be
problem for the neighboring properties and that it will not be intrusive on the residential
properties across the street. The Plan Commission believes that the proposed restaurant
will be a good use and will be an asset to the Village. The restaurant use will generate
sales tax for the Village. The petitioners have indicated that if the restaurant should leave
the property at some point in the future, they are agreeable to restricting future uses on the
property to uses that generate sales tax.

Adequate Facilities

Adequate facilities (utilities, access roads, drainage facilities) will be provided on the
subject property for the restaurant.

Adequate Buffering

The Plan Commission believes that the proposed buffering on the subject property is
adequate. They petitioners have created a new landscape plan for the subject property
that contains a variety of plantings and landscaping screening will be provided around the
perimeter of the parking lot.

                                    RECOMMENDATION

Accordingly, it is the recommendation of the Plan Commission the petitioner's request to
rezone the property at 780 Saunders Road from R-1 Single Family Residential District to
C-2 Outlying Commercial District, for an amendment to the Comprehensive Plan, and a
Special Use for a restaurant (Health O Wealth, Inc.) with outdoor seating, as submitted,
with the condition that there be a use restriction on the property limited to a retail or
restaurant, be approved.

Ayes (5): Berg, Bromberg, Moyer, Nadler, Shayman
Nays (1): Shapiro

Motion passes

Respectfully submitted,
Dan Shapiro, Chairman
Deerfield Plan Commission

Public Hearing on the request to rezone the property at 780 Saunders Road from R-1
Single Family Residential District to C-2 Outlying Commercial District, for an
amendment to the Comprehensive Plan and a Special Use for a restaurant with outdoor
seating ­ Health O Wealth, Inc. (Anil and Upasana Abbott)

Staff confirmed that notice was published in the Deerfield Review on March 21, 2013
and the petitioner submitted proof of notification.
Public Hearing
April 11, 2013
Page 2

Brett Webster, Project Manager with Shive-Hattery, introduced Anil and Upasana
Abbott, owners of 780 Saunders Road as well as civil engineer, Jason Doland of Doland
Engineering, Dave McCallum, Landscape Architect, McCallum Associates and Peter
Lemon, Traffic Engineer, TADI Traffic Engineers.

Mr. Webster addressed the minor changes to the site plan since the last workshop
meeting. The changes included the elimination of 2 parallel parking stalls on the
northeast corner of the site to allow for more space for the counterclockwise turning
movement at this corner of the parking lot. Another change was moving the trash
enclosure to the inside of the building. Mr. Webster commented that the petitioner is
striving to have a zero waste facility but it is not a perfect science so the little trash that
may result and all of the recyclable materials will be in this trash enclosure. This is not
a traditional trash enclosure and likewise there will not be a loading area for the
enclosure. Mr. Webster does not envision a full-size refuse truck to service this site
because of the minimal trash volume that will be generated. He displayed a truck
circulation movement on the site based on a 30' truck. A 30' truck would be able to
move throughout the site but would have to make a 3-point turn maneuver at the east
end of the site. Mr. Webster noted that it would be unusual for a truck this size or larger
to have to come onto this site but if they need to be on the site it would be arranged to
be there after normal work hours.

Mr. Webster noted that they have begun to investigate the building and site signage. A
wall sign will be on the building's west elevation. The ground sign that is being
requested is also at the west elevation.

Upasana Abbott, owner of 780 Saunders Road, restated the mission of their company is
to inspire wellness and healthy living and to promote health through balanced nutrition
in order to live fulfilling lives. Mrs. Abbott is a food scientist and has been in this
profession for 30 years. She is very passionate about their business and will bring
knowledge and expertise in healthy and fresh foods. The concept of this restaurant is to
serve healthy and fresh food to live a healthy lifestyle. The building will be eco-friendly
and they will strive to be a zero-waste facility. Mr. Anil Abbott has 30 years of
experience in the food and retail business with the goal of providing excellent customer
service. Mr. Abbott owns the adjacent Exxon Mobile gas station franchise at the
southeast corner of Saunders and Deerfield Road. The Abbott's are concerned with
being a good neighbor to residents and businesses in the community.

In response to the petitioner's request for an amendment to the Comprehensive Plan,
Mr. Webster noted significant changes have taken place since the subject property was
placed in the present R-1 Single Family Residential zoning classification. The
properties to the north, south and east have moved away from residential uses and are
more aligned with the nature of this proposed business. The Village of Deerfield will
also gain the sales tax benefit from the redevelopment of this property as a restaurant
as allowed in the C-2 Outlying Commercial zoning district.
Public Hearing
April 11, 2013
Page 3

In response to the rezoning standards, Mr. Webster reiterated that there are commercial
and office uses to the north, south and east parcels of the subject property. There is
residential development to the west of the subject property across Saunders Road. The
subject property's R-1 Single Family Residential zoning is not suitable to the proposed
restaurant use. The petitioner is requesting the zoning be amended to the C-2 Outlying
Commercial District zoning classification to provide suitability for the proposed
restaurant use.

The future trend of the properties to the east of Saunders Road is office and research
as identified in the Village of Deerfield's Future Land Use Map from the Comprehensive
Plan. Mr. Webster commented that the size of this parcel does not lend itself to office
uses. To the north and outside of the Village boundaries, the trend is commercial
development. Mr. Webster noted significant changes that have taken place since this
property was placed in the R-1 Single Family Residential zoning district and have
evolved of the commercial nature. It is the petitioner's contention that a small restaurant
use is suited for the rezoning of this parcel.

Mr. Webster addressed the Special Use Criteria:

Compatible with Existing Development

The petitioner is proposing a single-story, low-rise restaurant with landscaping
surrounding the building. The building position will connect to existing pedestrian and
bike pathways and is a compatible way to develop this parcel.

Lot of Sufficient Size

The size of the lot will be sufficient to the building that is proposed. The lot adequately
accommodates the parking required for a proposed restaurant anticipated to have 60%
carry-out customers and 40% dine-in customers.

Traffic

The location of the Special Use within the Village will be such that adverse effects on
surrounding properties will be minimal, particularly by the traffic generated from the
Special Use. As stated in the traffic study, the proposed seating capacity of the
restaurant is 60 seats and one of the lightest volume capacities that are addressed by
traffic standards. The petitioners believe that there will be no impact on traffic
generated from this business.

Parking and Access

The petitioner's feel that they have designed a safe and compact parking lot which can
handle the capacity and types of movements for its patrons and their employees. Mr.
Webster commented that even in spite of their adequate parking needs, the petitioner
Public Hearing
April 11, 2013
Page 4

plans to have their employees parking on their adjacent commercial property on the
corner of Saunders and Deerfield Roads. The full-access drive on Saunders Road is a
safe driveway. There will be some delays for left turn movements out of the driveway
but not of significant concern. The petitioner believes that parking and access meets
the Special Use standards.

Effect on the Neighborhood

In all respects, the petitioner believes that this restaurant use is not be significantly or
materially detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the public or injurious to the
other property or improvements in the neighborhood nor diminish property values in the
area. The petitioner hopes that this development can be seen as an improvement to
the immediate neighborhood.

Adequate Facilities

Preliminary engineering has been reviewed and coordinated with the Village Engineers
to ensure that adequate facilities are being provided to this property and for the
intended building use.

Adequate Buffering

The site and landscaping plan are showing that they are complying with all of the
Village's standards to ensure adequate buffering.

Village Center District

This standard does not apply as this parcel is outside of the Village Center District.

Peter Lemon, Traffic Consultant, TADI, noted that the scope of their study focused on
two main areas; the access driveway and a site plan review from a transportation
standpoint.

Traffic counts were taken at the site along Saunders Road. Peak periods were 7:00AM-
9:00AM and 4:00PM ­ 6:00PM. Based on the size of the restaurant traffic generation
projections were formed. Chairman Shapiro asked if the size of the restaurant was
based on the square footage or the seating capacity and if so, was there a difference.
Mr. Lemon confirmed that it was based on the square footage but generally there is not
a difference between the square footage and the seating capacity. Mr. Lemon noted
that more studies have been done on square footage and therefore that measurement
provides a larger sample size.

Traffic generation projections were taken from the Institute of Traffic Engineers Manual.
This size of restaurant generates 35 trips per hour during the morning peak period. The
trips were broken down by 25 inbound trips and 10 outbound trips. The afternoon peak
Public Hearing
April 11, 2013
Page 5

period would generate 30 trips per hours, with 20 inbound and 10 outbound trips. The
outbound trips were divided evenly with 5 vehicles going south onto Saunders Road
and 5 vehicles going north on Saunders Road.

By overlaying the site generated traffic at the driveway with the traffic counts going north
and south on Saunders Road. Mr. Lemon studied capacity analysis to see the delay for
inbound traffic, specifically the critical movements which were the southbound left turns
into the site and the outbound left turn out of the site. Operation is characterized
according to the amount of control delay at each approach and quantified into a level of
service (LOS). The LOS quantifies and categorizes a driver's ease of movement and
delays as a result of intersection control and resulting traffic queuing. Based on this
data, LOS was good with a LOS of A & B during the morning peak periods. A LOS E
was found for outbound traffic turning left onto Saunders Road during the afternoon
peak period. Mr. Lemon commented that this diminished LOS is just beyond the LOS
threshold of what is typically expected. This LOS is not uncommon for the minor leg
approach with an arterial roadway, such as Saunders Road. This traffic movement will
have to rely on gaps in traffic flow created by adjacent signalized intersections along
Saunders Road at Deerfield Road and Parkway North. The 10 outbound vehicles
generated during this peak period would be divided evenly with 5 vehicles going south
(making a left turn) and 5 vehicles going north (making a right turn) on Saunders Road.
This will not impact a large number of vehicles and the delays that the motorists will
experience will happen on the restaurant site. Mr. Lemon reiterated that their study is
based on Lake County granting full access at the driveway. This was confirmed with
Lake County Traffic Engineers.

The second component of this study was traffic circulation on the site. Circulation on
the site will be in a counterclockwise movement. Mr. Lemon commented that turning
movements for passenger vehicles at the northeast corner was tight and recommended
the elimination of the 2 eastern most parallel parking stalls. The petitioner incorporated
the removal these stalls in their site plan. The circulation study took a conservative
approach to loading and delivery vehicles by using a 30' truck to circulate through the
site. The circulation path illustrated some overlap with parking spaces so the petitioner
will have to work with the vendors to make sure these delivery vehicles access the
property outside of normal work hours so as to not conflict with parked vehicles.

Another recommendation by the traffic study was to designate employee only parking at
the western end of the site to keep the most convenient spaces for patrons. Mr. Lemon
commented that the petitioner has mentioned that there is an opportunity for employees
to park offsite on their adjacent property to the north. Offsite employee parking will
create more opportunity for visitors to park.

Based on the site plan review, their recommendations have been incorporated into the
site plan and Mr. Lemon is comfortable with the circulation options on the site. The
outbound left turn traffic delay is minor and will have little impact on traffic due to
Public Hearing
April 11, 2013
Page 6

queuing taking place on site and the low traffic generation for this type of restaurant
use.

Commissioner Nadler noted that outbound left turners will have to cross two lanes of
traffic going north and asked the maximum number of employees on site at any time.
Mr. Abbott stated that during peak periods there will be three employees. They plan to
have employees park at their adjacent Exxon Mobile gas station.

Chairman Shapiro asked how the Fire and Police Departments have reacted to the site
plan. Mr. Webster referenced a letter submitted from the Fire Department. The Fire
Department reviewed the site plan and their only concern is an ambulance circulating
through the site. Mr. Webster noted that a 22' ambulance would have trouble
negotiating the turn at the northeast corner of the site if a vehicle was parked in that
corner. The ambulance would have to back up once to get through this turn. The Fire
Marshal did not have a problem with this issue and submitted a letter of approval stating
that based on the revised site plan dated 3/30/13 , they did not foresee any issues for
access to this site for emergency vehicles.

Commissioner Berg asked the petitioner if Saunders Road was 4 or 5 lanes wide at the
proposed driveway entry. Mr. Lemon commented that there are 4 lanes plus the
tapering of the left turn lane to Deerfield Road. Mr. Lemon also commented that
southbound traffic on Saunders is heavier in the morning peak period and heavier
northbound in the afternoon peak period. Mr. Lemon noted that the volumes are such
that less than half of the peak traffic is northbound in the morning and less than half of
the peak traffic is southbound in the afternoon peak period. Mr. Lemon expects that this
is due to Tollway access.

Commissioner Moyer asked if there will be adequate directional signage on site. Mr.
Webster commented that they intend to paint directional arrows into the pavement as
well as a one-way directional sign in curbed, landscaped parking island. There is also
an opportunity to put up "do not enter" signs to direct the counterclockwise circulation.
Commissioner Moyer thought that having painted arrows in the pavement is nice feature
but will not work during snow fall. Commissioner Moyer asked if there were concerns
regarding a fire truck accessing the site. Mr. Webster stated that the Fire Department
did not mention any concerns with a fire truck on the site. Mr. Webster did not speak to
the Fire Department directly on this subject but noted that there is a fire hydrant north of
the parcel and another to the south. The Fire Department was satisfied with the
proximity of the hydrants. Commissioner Moyer is concerned with a fire truck accessing
the site as well as vehicles turning left and going southbound during peak hours. Mr.
Lemon acknowledged that there will be some challenges turning left during peak
periods but the adjacent traffic signals will provide traffic gaps and the low number of
vehicles projected to make this movement (5) is low. The traffic study also expects no
more than 2 vehicles queuing, on site, at a time during these delays. Commissioner
Shayman asked Mr. Lemon is he had an idea of how much time would pass between
gaps. Mr. Lemon mentioned that the traffic signals cycling is approximately a minute in
Public Hearing
April 11, 2013
Page 7

each direction. The average delay time that they witnessed during their traffic counts
was 43 seconds with most of the delay due to exiting vehicle turning left onto Saunders
Road.

Commissioner Moyer asked Mr. Ryckaert if it was possible to restrict left turns out of the
site at certain times. Mr. Ryckaert noted that Saunders Road is under the jurisdiction of
Lake County Highway Department and they have granted full-access. Mr. Lemon noted
that Lake County did their own analysis of the traffic conditions before they granted full
access.

Commissioner Nadler asked the petitioner if they were aware the Village could place a
restriction on the property that would allow only commercial or retail use on this parcel.
Mr. and Mrs. Abbott were aware of the restriction and did not have an issue with the
zoning restriction. Chairman Shapiro clarified that if this proposal were to be
recommended to the Board there would be an ordinance that would restrict this parcel
to remain as a sales tax generating property. The ordinance would be recorded against
the property and the restriction would stay with the property. Mr. & Mrs. Abbott
understand this aspect and did not have an issue with the restriction.

Jason Doland, civil engineer, Doland Engineering, noted that the challenge from a site
civil standpoint is threefold; getting water into the site, removing waste off the site, and
dealing with stormwater in a way that will not adversely affect the neighboring parcels.

Mr. Doland noted that they have two options for obtaining water; one option is
approximately 200' north and another 150' southeast of the site. Both water mains are
on Parkway North Center property and they have verbal agreements for accessing
these water mains. Sanitary sewer is readily accessible in the right-of-way adjacent to
the site.

Mr. Doland is very conscious of stormwater management. While there is a storm sewer
on the adjacent Parkway North property that receives stormwater runoff from this
property, they will promote the infiltration of ground water recharge with basins on site
as opposed to letting water flow slowly from the property. Mr. Doland noted that there
are recharge basins to the east and south of the property that will not only stop the
storm water but also take out pollutants before they get down stream.

From a site civil standpoint these challenges have been addressed and they are ready
to take these issues to final design. Commissioner Shayman asked if this was reviewed
by Village Engineers. Mr. Doland stated that this plan has been shared with Village
Engineers and they were comfortable with the plan.

Dave McCallum, landscape architect, McCallum Associates, described a landscape
plan that meets the intent and requirements of Village Code as well as provides an
attractive setting for the restaurant and the streetscape. The landscape plan will have 5'
high evergreens adjacent to the parking lot to the north and south intermixed with
Public Hearing
April 11, 2013
Page 8

native, 4" caliper shade trees. The native shades tree will be of a mixed variety.
Adjacent to the outdoor patio/deck will be a combination of native grasses and shrubs.
The southeast corner (stormwater recharge area) will be treated like a bio-swale rain
garden with a variety of different sedges and perennials that will take the stormwater
and cleanse it before it continues on its way. The front of the building will be a
combination of shade trees, ornamental ground cover, evergreen shrubs and perennial
flowers. The right of way will be landscaped with sod.

Mr. Webster displayed and presented the site lighting. The LED light fixture is 3' in
length and a foot wide and provides control of the projected light. One of the light pole
fixtures will have a shield preventing light from being projected toward the back of the
fixture and Saunders Road. The other two light pole fixtures will be in the landscaped
parking islands. The three parking lot light poles meet Village requirements for
illuminating this type of parking lot. Any lighting needed for pedestrians will be on the
building. The site lighting plan will have a zero foot-candle level around the periphery of
the site as required by Village site lighting ordinance. Commissioner Shayman asked
how the building itself and the signage will be illuminated. Mr. Webster commented that
the signage is internally illuminated. The wall sign on the west elevation will be
internally illuminated and controlled to be turned off at the end of the business day as
required by Village ordinance. The building itself is a combination of glass walls and a
screen and will have some illumination when lights are on inside the building. The
interior building illumination will be diminished due to the nature of the building
materials. There will be lighting on the deck which will be suspended from the roof
structure. Due to the horizontal covering over the deck the light fixture will not be visible
from outside of the building. Commissioner Shayman asked if there will be screening
on the south side of the deck. Mr. Webster noted that a metal fabric will act as a
screening but will have a fair amount of translucency but will not be transparent. A
vertical garden can be grown or installed on this fabric.

Following the petitioner's presentation, Chairman Shapiro opened the meeting to public
comments.

Paul Tuszynski, member of the Thorngate Homeowner's Association and Village of
Riverwoods Zoning Board of Appeals, but spoke as a Riverwood's resident. Mr.
Tuszynski asked the petitioner if the existing fence will remain or if it will be torn down.
Mr. Abbott commented that that one side of the fence belongs to the adjacent bank and
the south side fence belongs to Parkway North. Mr. Tuszynski is concerned about the
vehicle lights coming from the parking lot and about the height of the driveway as
vehicles exit the property. He wonders if the vehicle lights will hit the first row of homes
across from the subject property. Mr. Doland stated that the county requires that this
driveway will be a street level. Mr. Tuszynski wanted to know hours of operation. Mr.
Abbott stated that the hours will be 7:00AM ­ 10:00 PM. Mr. Abbott stated that he is
willing to work with his neighbors and if there are any problems that arise they are more
than willing to listen and work things out.
Public Hearing
April 11, 2013
Page 9

Chairman Shapiro wanted clarification on the number of employees that will work at the
proposed restaurant. Mr. Abbott noted that the total number of employees for this
business will be 10 but 5 or less employees will only be working at one time.

David Schrieber, president of the Thorngate Homeowner's Association, was asked by
their board to speak on this redevelopment. Mr. Schrieber stated that Mr. and Mrs.
Abbott have been very forthcoming to himself and their association about wanting to
work with their board about any concerns. Based on Thorngate's recent HOA meeting,
their board is not in favor of the commercialization development of a restaurant across
the street from the Thorngate community. Mr. Schrieber noted that Thorngate is a very
private residential community and the Thorngate Board is very concerned about vehicle
lights coming into their community as vehicles are coming down the proposed
restaurant driveway as they exit the site. The Thorngate Board also anticipates an
increase in vehicular accidents and traffic delays from the vehicles entering and exiting
the site. Mr. Schrieber asked the Village Board to consider his comments and reiterated
that the Thorngate community is against any commercial development in close
proximity or across the street from their subdivision.

Mark Finch, Thorngate resident for 12 years, owns the home that backs up to the Exxon
Mobile gas station across Saunders Road. Mr. Finch feels that the Deerfield Road and
Saunders Road intersection is very dangerous and has seen many accidents take place
there especially due to the entry points for the Exxon Mobile gas station at that
intersection. Mr. Finch is very concerned about future development if this parcel is
rezoned for commercial use. One of the beauties of the Riverwoods community is that
it is very low key. Mr. Finch also had concerns about the Exxon Mobile gas station
signage. Chairman Shapiro noted that the Exxon Mobile station is under Riverwoods
jurisdiction. Mr. Finch had his fence heightened and reinforced because people were
cutting through his yard to get to the gas station to get a snack and believes that this will
increase again if a restaurant is built.

Commissioner Moyer asked the petitioner (who also owns the Exxon Mobile gas
station) how long the corner parcel has been a gas station. Mr. Abbott commented that
he is the second owner of the station and it has been a gas station for at least 15-18
years. Commissioner Moyer asked if the gas station was there before the Thorngate
subdivision was built. The petitioner confirmed that the gas station was there before the
Thorngate subdivision was built. Mr. Abbott also commented that he has not witnessed
a lot of accidents at that location and they are conscious about lighting at the gas
station. As for vehicle lights going into the Thorngate subdivision at their proposed
restaurant, Mr. Abbott noted that he anticipates their main business will be during lunch
hours. Mr. Abbott commented that they are committed to being a good neighbor to the
community and will always be willing to work with the community in resolving issues.

Shannon Erickson, a Riverwoods resident, has friends and a relative that live in the
Thorngate community that are excited about the proposed restaurant. He and a lot of
his neighbors believe that the proposed restaurant will be welcome improvement to the
Public Hearing
April 11, 2013
Page 10

community Mr. Erickson commented that the same people that don't want development

that the Exxon Mobile gas station has been in existence for 30 years and there are not
