                                 PLAN COMMISSION
                               VILLAGE OF DEERFIELD

The Plan Commission of the Village of Deerfield held a Workshop Meeting at 7:30 P.M.
on April 11, 2013 at the Village Hall, 850 Waukegan Road, Deerfield, Illinois.

Chairman Shapiro called the meeting to order.

Present were:        Dan Shapiro, Chairman
                     Larry Berg
                     Alan Bromberg
                     Jim Moyer
                     Robert Nadler
                     Stuart Shayman

Absent:              Elaine Jacoby

Also present:        Jeff Ryckaert, Principal Planner
                     Kathleen LéVeque, Associate Planner

Discussion on the request to rezone the property at 780 Saunders Road from R-1
Single Family Residential District to C-2 Outlying Commercial District, for an
amendment to the Comprehensive Plan and a Special Use for a restaurant with outdoor
seating ­ Health O Wealth, Inc. (Anil and Upasana Abbott)

Commissioner Berg commented that he initially thought that a restaurant was an odd
use of this space but during this process he has changed his view. Other than build
another residential dwelling, he cannot imagine a less intrusive or restrictive use of this
piece of property. Commissioner Berg noted that the property is clearly not viable as a
single family home being surrounded by commercial properties and Saunders Road to
the west. Commissioner Berg feels that the restaurant could be a good fit for the Village
and residents of both Deerfield and Riverwoods and particularly the workers in the
adjacent office buildings. Commissioner Berg likes the green components of the
building and that it will be easy to walk to the restaurant from the office buildings. He
believes the properties to the south will be developed at some point and anticipates it
will be a much higher density than the proposed restaurant.

Commissioner Moyer agrees with Commissioner Berg and noted that the sustainability
efforts are wonderful. He would love to see electric vehicle charging stations in their
plan if it is feasible. Commissioner Moyer sees an upscale and sustainable restaurant
that will fit in well with the adjacent properties.

Chairman Shapiro noted that petitioners have made remarkable progress from their first
workshop meeting but he still has significant concerns with their plan. Chairman
Shapiro commented that this commercial use will be an isolated zoning district and is
concerned about spot zoning. Chairman Shapiro is not convinced that the trend of
Workshop Meeting
April 11, 2013
Page 2

development (as indicated by the petitioner) is commercial and referenced that the
Comprehensive Plan has this parcel for office uses with respect to future zoning.
Chairman Shapiro feels that these standards for rezoning are not being fulfilled. He is
troubled with the numerous variation requests especially with the setbacks and the
parking. Chairman Shapiro is also concerned with the turning areas for vehicles on the
site particularly for larger trucks which would have to back up to mover around northeast
turn and while this has been addressed and appears to be doable, it is not ideal. He is
very concerned for the safety of the vehicles exiting this site and turning left onto
Saunders Road.

Commissioner Nadler initially had concerns from a business aspect in terms of the
viability of the site. However upon reflection and discussion, Commissioner Nadler
realizes that the Plan Commission is not there to judge whether or not a location will be
successful or not for a restaurant but rather is should be judged in terms of the
variances and zoning requests. Commissioner Nadler is greatly comforted in the fact
that Lake County Department of Transportation has approved a full access drive on
Saunders Road and gives him a vote of confidence that they have reviewed and
analyzed the access driveway. In terms of spot zoning, he is not concerned about this
aspect since it is currently spot zoned in its present residential use. Commissioner
Nadler is impressed with the petitioner's team of consultants and their dedication to
making this plan work. The variances are not a concern since the petitioner is only 2
parking spots short of the requirement. Commissioner Nadler does have personal
doubts on the success of this business because of the locational issues but he dose not
want that to cloud his view as a member of the Plan Commission. Commissioner
Nadler looks favorably on this petition.

Commissioner Bromberg is not concerned with the spot zoning. He noted that it is
important to remember that this business will be predominately for the lunch crowd and
not during evening hours. As far as left turns out of this property, he feels that there are
other areas that exhibit a worse situation. Commissioner Bromberg noted that he lives
next door to the Riverwoods Police Chief and he has discussed this intersection with
him. The Riverwoods Police Chief did not feel that this was a dangerous intersection
and in 2012 there were 8 accidents at that intersection. Commissioner Bromberg
commented that any accident is too many but this number is not significant during the
course of a year. Commissioner Bromberg initially thought that this was an unusual use
of this property but now feels that it is an excellent use of the property. He also
commented that this use would generate sales tax for the Village.

Commissioner Shayman had no issues with the zoning or the variances and feels that
they can make allowances in order to make this project work. This project is in a
location that these types of variances will not have an adverse affect on any neighboring
properties. This is a nicely laid out plan and although the left turn out of the property will
remain an issue hopefully motorists will use good sense when exiting the property.
Workshop Meeting
April 11, 2013
Page 3

Commissioner Nadler moved to approve the request to rezone the property at 780
Saunders Road from R-1 Single Family Residential District to C-2 Outlying Commercial
District, for an amendment to the Comprehensive Plan and a Special Use for a
restaurant with outdoor seating ­ Health O Wealth, Inc. as submitted, with the condition
that there be a use restriction on the property limited to retail or restaurant.

Commissioner Bromberg seconded the motion and the vote was as follows:
Ayes (5): Berg, Bromberg, Moyer, Nadler, Shayman
Nays (1): Shapiro

There being no further business to discuss the meeting adjourned.

Respectfully submitted,
Daniel Nakahara
Workshop Meeting
February 28, 2013
Page 2

Prefiling Conference #2: Rezoning and Development of 780 Saunders Road.

Brett Webster, Project Manager with Shive-Hattery, introduced Anil and Upasana
Abbott, owners of 780 Saunders Road as well as civil engineer, Jason Doland of Doland
Engineering.

Mr. Webster noted that the proposed size of the building and its deck have not changed
since the first workshop meeting, but the building did get moved. The aspects of this
project that have been addressed since the last meeting include adjusting the parking
sizes, drive aisles and rear and side yard landscaping. The landscaping design has
been adjusted but the landscaping level of detail will not be addressed in this workshop
meeting.

The main change in the site plan is the Lake County Department of Transportation
(LDOT) has asked that the right-of-way be moved 10' to the east which shifted the
building and the associated dining area 10' to the east toward the parking lot. The
petitioner is seeking a variation to the front yard setback requirement of 50'. The
petitioner interprets the current front yard setback at 25' measured from the building
structure. The petitioner noted that the staff memo recognizes this calculation at 18'6"
because it is measured from the outdoor deck structure. The petitioner is also seeking
a variation from the 12' side yard setback requirement. Staff calculates the proposed
side yard at 6.9' measured from the south property line to the outdoor deck.

Mr. Webster noted that due to the size of the lot, the same restraints exist. The parking
lot configuration will remain the same but the lot coverage has changed due to the
smaller parcel size. The requirements for lot coverage appear to be met.

Jason Doland noted that since the last meeting he has engaged in discussions with
different engineers and consultants regarding the impacts of development for this site.
Mr. Doland oriented the audience to the site recalling that the site borders commercial
property to north, Parkway North Center to the south and east and Saunders Road to
the west. The front of the building is west toward Saunders Road. Mr. Doland noted
key elements imperative to the site. The first being that the owners have been in
discussions with the Parkway North Center property managers and they have reached a
cooperative effort towards obtaining a water main tap east of the subject property. Mr.
Doland also noted that after extensive research they have located an easily accessible
sanitary sewer to service the property.

Mr. Doland is very conscious of stormwater management and believes that the best way
to protect a neighbor is to not overburden them with stormwater runoff. In this case,
they will promote the infiltration of ground water recharge as opposed to letting water
flow slowly from the property. Mr. Doland noted that there are recharge basins to the
east and south of the property that will not only stop the stormwater but also take out
pollutants before they get down stream.
Workshop Meeting
February 28, 2013
Page 3

Mr. Doland has had numerous discussions and meetings with Lake County Department
of Transportation regarding site access for the subject property. After careful and
thoughtful analysis of their roadway and trip generation attributed to the proposed
restaurant, LCDOT has provided full vehicular access to the site. There will be no
vehicle turning restrictions to or from the property.

Commissioner Moyer asked if the parking on site could be addressed. Mr. Doland
commented that parking is a calculation of the seating capacity and building square
footage and the confusing issue in this case deals with the outdoor seating and how that
area is calculated with respect to the parking. This discussion goes toward seating
capacity in the restaurant. The proposed seating capacity is 60 people and this
capacity does not change with the outdoor seating area. Commissioner Jacoby
commented that the outdoor area being available throughout the year brings the front
yard setback to 18'6" because that part of the structure extends farthest to the property
line. Mr. Webster explained that they took the front yard setback from the building and
not from the outdoor element because the outdoor element is not habitable 365 days of
the year. Commissioner Jacoby asked if the outdoor seating area was screened. Mr.
Webster noted that screen-like material is a privacy element that serves as a visual and
privacy barrier. Mr. Webster realizes that however the front yard setback measurement
is calculated a variation is needed. Mr. Webster stated that if the outdoor element
needs to be adjusted for some percentage of the variation they would welcome that
conversation with the Board of Zoning Appeals (BZA). Mr. Webster understands that
they will have to get approval from the BZA for the variations and approval from the
Appearance Review Committee regarding the appearance of their building.

Commissioner Bromberg wanted clarification of the seating in the restaurant. Mr.
Webster stated that the seating capacity will not change and there is no intent to
increase seating capacity in good weather. Mr. Webster commented that the seating
capacity is dependent on the parking and there would be no reason to increase the
seating if there is nowhere to park on the site. He also acknowledged that this
restaurant is promoting a healthy lifestyle and utilizes the walking and bike paths in the
area for their customers.

Upasana Abbott, owner of 780 Saunders Road, commented that she is a food scientist
specialist and has been in this profession for 30 years. Mrs. Abbott is currently working
as in new product development for a major food company. The concept of this
restaurant is to serve healthy and fresh food and live a healthy lifestyle. The building
will be eco-friendly, be a no-waste restaurant and the outdoor deck serves a very big
part of this restaurant concept.

Chairman Shapiro commented to the petitioner that they have made some nice changes
since the last meeting especially in the accessibility to the site. Chairman Shapiro noted
that there are still issues that have been pointed out by staff that need to be addressed.
He would like to see a traffic and parking evaluation, where loading berths would be
located on the site and review the proposed signage.
Workshop Meeting
February 28, 2013
Page 4


Mrs. Abbott commented that they have connected their restaurant to the existing
walking paths that lead to the adjacent Parkway North office buildings and are expecting
a lot of their customers to come from theses office building. Mrs. Abbott anticipates a
good portion of their business will be walk-ins and carryout/delivery service to office
buildings and alleviate the need for parking on their site.

Commissioner Bromberg noted that the anticipated hours of operation are 7:00 AM to

Prefiling Conference: Rezoning and Development of 780 Saunders Road

Brett Webster, Project Manager, Shive-Hattery, is assisting the owners on the proposed
restaurant at 780 Saunders Road. Mr. Webster has been working with staff on the
proposed rezoning, Special Use, and specific zoning requirements that pertain to this
project. The main focus of this presentation is to present the concept and some of the
challenges of the site. Additional information that Mr. Webster submitted to the
Commission at the beginning of their presentation is in response to a memorandum from
staff dated December 6, 2012, and includes a revised site plan and issues which will most
likely require variations.

Upasana Abbott and her husband Anil, owners of 780 Saunders Road, purchased the
property in the beginning of 2012. Mr. Abbott has been operating the gas station on the
corner Deerfield and Saunders Road and both he and his wife feel that they are in tune
with customer base in the area. Mrs. Abbott is a food scientist in product development and
passionate about health food. The restaurant was conceived from customer feedback that
there were no restaurants in the area that served healthy foods. The concept is to
establish a healthy food restaurant that serves freshly prepared casual meals and some
prepackaged foods. Mrs. Abbott noted that the restaurant will be eco-friendly and be a no-
waste restaurant.

Jason Doland, Doland Engineering, noted that he would be talking about four main site
civil topics related to this site from his professional perspective: site access, sanitary
sewer service, water service and stormwater management.

Mr. Doland has discussed site access with the Lake County Department of Transportation
(LCDOT). Saunders Road has a significant amount of traffic and has a dedicated left turn
lane that is twice as long as a typical left turn lane. The proposed restaurant site is at the
midway point of the dedicated left turn lane on Saunders Road. Mr. Doland commented
that he has discussed this with LCDOT and they will be involved in the process with them
to discern the safest and best way to gain access to this site. There is an enormous
amount of data research, traffic analysis and car counts that LCDOT wants to look at for
the petitioner, but only if there is at least a favorable direction from the Village on the
proposal. If there is a favorable direction, then LCDOT will address traffic counts and road
analysis.

Mr. Doland commented that depending on what the data shows the options for access to
the property could be full and unrestricted access; right-in and unrestricted out access; or
right-in and right-out access. LCDOT is ready and willing to dedicate staff hours to their
level of research so long as they can come back knowing that this project is at least a
viable project.

Commissioner Bromberg commented that access from the north will be critical to this site.
Mr. Doland noted that they will be going through the analysis with LCDOT and LCDOT will
have the decision on what type of access the petitioners get on Saunders Road. Mr.
Workshop Meeting
December 13, 2012
Page 9

Doland noted that LCDOT will analyze how much of the left turn lane is used and note
stacking during peak hours. The most important component is the stacking in the left turn
lane and if there are gaps for southbound vehicles turning left into the site.

Commissioner Nadler wanted to clarify that the petitioner is seeking more than just a right-
in, right-out access. Mr. Doland stated that they are seeking more than just a right-in,
right-out access. Commissioner Nadler asked if the bank owned the accessway north of
the subject property and if there were any conversations to work out an agreement to
share that access drive. Mr. Doland noted that they worked significantly toward shared
access with the bank, but with no success.

Mr. Doland commented that sanitary sewer service is approximately 150' to the south of
the property which may pose a challenge but it is available. There are two options for
water service. One option is approximately 600' away in the public right-of-way and the
other option is a little closer but on private property which would require easement
coordination. Mr. Doland commented that sanitary sewer and water will require LCDOT
coordination because the mains are in the right-of-way for Saunders Road.

Mr. Doland is very conscious of stormwater management and believes that the best way to
protect a neighbor is to not overburden them with stormwater runoff. In this case Mr.
Doland will be following the Lake County and Village stormwater runoff ordinance and
working with Village engineers towards final engineering documents and permit drawings
that will be developed for stormwater management purposes to encourage groundwater
recharge infiltration in lieu of runoff. Mr. Doland commented that instead of using a
restrictor plate and letting water runoff, they can use open gravel bottomed storm
chambers to allow for infiltration and to discourage conveying water as much as possible.

Chairman Shapiro referred to an aerial image of the site and wanted to clarify ownership of
the accessway north of the site. Mr. Doland confirmed that the accessway is owned by the
bank and serves as an in-only access point. A discussion ensued around this access
point. Commissioner Nadler asked Mr. Doland if there were any thoughts of deeding some
land to increase this accessway. Mr. Doland commented that swapping land for the
purpose of further widening the access point for shared use was their initial conversation
with the bank but the bank was not interested.

Chairman Shapiro commented that there are three existing curb cuts in this area (2 with
the gas station and 1 with the bank) and it may be difficult for LCDOT to create a fourth.
Mr. Doland noted that they are using the existing apron that was used for the residential
property. Commissioner Bromberg pointed out that the gas station and the bank
properties reside in Riverwoods jurisdiction.

Mr. Doland's hope is that should they receive a favorable direction on the use or its
concept then he would have a commission to go forward to further develop these details of
these previously discussed challenges. Commissioner Shayman asked that if the site is
restricted to right-in, right-out access from Saunders Road, how this impacts the concept.
Workshop Meeting
December 13, 2012
Page 10

Mr. Doland commented that at that point cost and benefit analysis would dictate to the
owners if the project is viable.

could be shortened such that the access point in the site plan could be flipped then this

helped to alleviate the traffic burden.

Commissioner Berg feels that sharing the access on Saunders Road with the bank's
entrance and possibly the bank's exit point on Deerfield Road would alleviate a lot of the
traffic issues.

Commissioner Nadler noted that restaurants are very capital intensive and expensive and
have the highest failure rate of any retail concept. Commissioner Nadler offered his
personal opinion to the petitioner based on his retail real estate background by noting that
this restaurant location, aside from access issues, poses many disadvantages to being
successful. It is his opinion that the petitioner search for a location that will be more
compatible for success. From a Plan Commission perspective, Mr. Nadler has issues with
the proposal and at this point is not looking favorably on the project.

Chairman Shapiro believes the petitioner has worked hard on a difficult site. Above and
beyond access, Chairman Shapiro and sees issues in lot coverage, parking and other
things that were mentioned in the staff report. Chairman Shapiro pointed out that he is not
in favor of the rezoning because a residential subdivision exists across Saunders Road.

Mr. Webster understands the main concerns that have been discussed and asked the
Commission if they should continue with their presentation on the architecture. Chairman
Workshop Meeting
December 13, 2012
Page 11

Shapiro commented that a discussion on the project's architecture may be premature at
this stage but welcomed the petitioner to continue with their presentation.

Commissioner Berg commented that the proposed site could be accessed from Deerfield
Road along the eastern portion of the gas station but would require an easement from the
bank.

Carlos Concepcion, Director of Operations at Shive-Hattery, discussed the proposed
architecture of the project. The architecture of the project gets its inspiration from the
business concept and mission statement dealing with wellness and healthy living. These
concepts translated architecturally into theme of light and transparency. Mr. Concepcion
displayed a variety of images that projected the design concepts and the spirit of the
restaurant. The building design reflects the issues of wellness and sustainability which will
also be seen in the use of the building materials.

The restaurant is a 3,000 square foot space which will account for 60% (1,800 square feet)
devoted to the carry-out operation and 40% (1,200 square feet) devoted to the sit down
dining operation. The restaurant will have an office space, food preparation and storage
space, seating area, two restrooms and an outdoor deck.

The outdoor deck is essentially a connection between the outdoor paths and the street and
in good weather conditions serves as an area to displace some of the seating from the
inside to the outside. The outdoor deck does not add seating for customers as it is used to
displace customers to the outside in good weather conditions. Recycled materials will be
used in constructing the building, especially the deck, and the petitioner will seek LEED
building certification. There were discussions that the square footage of the outdoor deck
would be included into restaurant space and would therefore increase the number of
parking spaces required for the site. Mr. Concepcion noted that the deck itself is an
element of circulation with the idea that it would attract bicyclists and runners/walkers and
other outdoor enthusiast to get a beverage or meal similar to a fast food operation for
pedestrians.

The parking area is proposed to be accessed from Saunders Road and contains 35
parking spaces including two handicap spaces. The traffic will flow in a counter-clockwise
direction.

The building envelope is anticipated to be primarily constructed of glass and a perforated
metal material. Mr. Concepcion displayed concept renderings of the restaurant.

Mr. Concepcion noted that there were a number of issues mostly related to parking sizes,
setbacks and drive aisle sizes that have all been addressed with recommendations by
Village staff. Mr. Concepcion noted that a lot of thought and planning has gone into this
concept and its functionality. He believes not only that this project is legitimate but will be
a significant addition to the area.
Workshop Meeting
December 13, 2012
Page 12

Commissioner Jacoby likes the idea of this project but acknowledged the challenges for
the site. The issues of fitting this restaurant on this site, parking space sizes, drive aisles
and most importantly the access for the site are going to be a challenge. Mr. Concepcion
realizes that this is not an easy site but it is a good site to work with and he foresees the
adjacent office park utilizing this restaurant.

Commissioner Bromberg feels that this property should not be zoned R-1 Residential and
agrees with most, if not all, of the comments made by Commissioner Nadler. He is not
sure it is the Plan Commission's place to decide whether or not a restaurant is successful
at this site, but more of a question as to whether it is a good use of this space.
Commissioner Bromberg feels that this could be a good use of the property aside from the
access issues. Commissioner Shayman views the access and parking as major issues for
this project. The site does not lend itself to overflow parking areas and only contains one
access point.

Mr. Abbott commented that they surveyed the surrounding offices and the neighborhood
and found that customers are looking for healthy foods and that there is a demand for a
food establishment in this area.

Chairman Shapiro asked Mr. Doland if he has enough direction from the Commission to

Mr. Webster noted that the material submitted this evening does highlight issues that have

Commissioner Nadler asked the petitioner if the property owner to the south would be

noted that they have talked to the land owner to the south and they are only willing to sell

the variances.
Workshop Meeting
December 13, 2012
Page 13

Mr. Webster acknowledged that they understand the larger issues of ease of access and
parking continue to exist and that the front setback will be a challenge. Mr. Webster
wanted to illustrate that that the interpretation of the outdoor seating area as it applies to
the parking count will not exacerbate the parking situation due to the way the business will
operate. Commissioner Bromberg likes the concept but reiterated his concerns regarding
parking and access. Commissioner Jacoby asked the petitioner if they would consider
reducing the size of the deck area and relocating it to the east end of the building.

Commissioner Berg asked the petitioner if they are thinking about increasing seating
capacity during the warmer months or just readjusting seating. Mr. Webster stated that
they would be spreading out seating and not increasing the seating. Mr. Concepcion
commented that the seating area in the restaurant will also double as a retail space with
vertical display elements. Mr. Concepcion wanted to clarify this in the floor plan so it would
not be mistaken for indoor seating and added that the area is considered as much of a
retail space as a restaurant. Mr. Concepcion was not sure if this would affect the required
parking count. Commissioner Shayman suggested that the seating for the restaurant be
restricted to conform to the parking requirements and this could be written into the
recommendation. Commissioner Bromberg likes the restaurant concept, but parking and
access are concerns. Commissioner Jacoby asked if the deck could be moved or reduced
in size. Mr. Concepcion commented that the outdoor deck is critical to the concept of this
restaurant because it reinforces the concept of healthy eating and the sustainable space.
The outdoor deck could be reduced a bit so it becomes more path-like (the outdoor area is
intended to be an extension and connection of the outdoor path and the street). The
petitioner would not like to see the outdoor deck shifted as it would suggest that it was an
optional space for the restaurant.

Commissioner Bromberg commented that in the staff memo stated that there would be a
maximum of 20-30 patrons at one time but the following paragraph describes that the floor
plan indicates seating for 40 patrons. This inconsistency will have to be cleaned up to
ensure that there is enough parking for the number of seating in the restaurant.

Mr. Webster was pleased with this discussion and thanked the Commission for their
focused attention and advice.

Chairman Shapiro suggested the petitioners could come back to the Plan Commission for
another prefiling conference.

                 Also enclosed please find a CD with the pdf files of the documents listed above.


                We offer the following explanation of site plan changes and additional documents provided to address
                Plan Commission concerns from the Workshop hearing on February 28, 2013.


                 ·      We have revised the site plan from the Feb. 28, 2013 PC Workshop meeting to address the
                        comments and concerns of the Village staff and the Plan Commission. We have a total of three
                        variations: Front Yard setback (25 feet in lieu of 50 feet), South Side Yard setback (6.9 feet in
                        lieu of 12 feet), and Parking Stall quantity (33 stalls in lieu of 35). The reduction of two parking
                        stalls provides for better traffic circulation as vehicles will have more room to maneuver around
                        the East end of the parking lot. We believe that these variations are necessary for the feasible
                        development of a building size that can accommodate a restaurant of this type.
                 ·      We have enclosed letters addressing the Comprehensive Plan Amendment request, Special
                        Use Criteria, and Rezoning Standards that address the topics to be considered.

Health O Wealth Inc.
780 Saunders Road
Deerfield, IL

Concept:
Establish a healthy food café at this location that serves freshly prepared casual
meals and some prepackaged foods.

Hours of Operation: 7AM to 10PM

Maximum Seating Capacity: 20 to 30 people

Peak Hours: Around Noon

Total Number of Employees: 10
Maximum number of employees working at one time: 4 to 5

Square Footage: 3,000 sq. ft.

Carry out vs. Sit-Down: 60% Carry Out and 40% Sit Down

Deliveries/ Loading: 5AM- 6AM

Projected Annual Sales: $750,000 to $1,000,000

Company background
Name: Health O Wealth Inc
DBA: FRESH-healthy café Franchise

                                                      Special Use Criteria
                                                      Health O Wealth Inc.
                                                      780 Saunders Road
                                                          Deerfield, IL


              1. Compatible with Existing Development

                    The nature and intensity of the activities involved in the size, placement and design of
                    any structures proposed will be so planned that the Special Use will be compatible with
                    the existing development and will not impede the normal and orderly development and
                    improvement of surrounding property.

                    Response: Health O Wealth Inc. proposes to operate a small healthy food café serving freshly
                    prepared casual meals and limited retail sales of prepackaged foods. The restaurant is
                    designed to enhance the surrounding property through the use of light, transparent building
                    materials intended to reflect the mission statement of inspiring wellness and healthy living. The
                    appropriately scaled structure is positioned on the lot so as to encourage use and access by
                    occupants of the neighboring properties via walking or cycling in addition to traditional motorized
                    vehicles. A connection to the existing pedestrian/cycling path on the adjacent property
                    emphasizes the compatibility with the existing surrounding developments.

              2. Lot of Sufficient Size

                    The size of the lot will be sufficient for the use proposed.

                    Response: The size of the lot adequately accommodates the parking required for a proposed
                    restaurant anticipated to have 60% carry-out customers and 40% dine-in customers.

              3. Traffic

                    The location of the Special Use within the Village will be such that adverse effects on
                    surrounding properties will be minimal, particularly regarding the traffic generated by the
                    Special Use.

                    Response: The size of the proposed restaurant accommodates a maximum seating capacity of
                    60 customers. The traffic impact study enclosed as prepared by TADI supports that minimal
                    traffic will be generated by this business and that adverse effects on surrounding properties are
                    anticipated to be minimal if not altogether negligible.

              4. Parking and Access

                    Parking areas will be of adequate size for the particular use and properly located, and the
                    entrance and exit drives will be laid out so as to prevent traffic hazards and nuisances.

                    Response: The parking areas provided will be adequate in size to accommodate customer and
                    delivery vehicles as illustrated by the enclosed vehicle turning diagrams. The capacity and
                    volume of supplies/waste removal required to support this business is low enough as to reduce


Project # 8121561
                                                                                                                    Page 2 of 2




                   the frequency of deliveries/loading and the size of vehicles delivering the supplies/hauling away
                   waste. Delivery/loading times will be controlled by the Owners to limit interference between
                   delivery vehicles and customer vehicles. The entrance and exit drive has been approved for full
                   access from Saunders Road by Lake County Division of Transportation per the letter provided
                   to the Village dated Feb. 21, 2013.

              5. Effect on Neighborhood

                   In all respects the Special Use will not be significantly or materially detrimental to the
                   health, safety and welfare of the public or injurious to the other property of
                   improvements in the neighborhood, nor will it diminish or impair property values in the
                   surrounding area.

                   Response: In all respects the proposed restaurant will be constructed and operated to not be
                   significantly or materially detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the public or injurious
                   to the other property or improvements in the neighborhood, nor will it diminish or impair property
                   values in the surrounding area.

              6. Adequate Facilities

                   That adequate utilities, access roads, drainage and/or other necessary facilities have
                   been or are being provided.

                   Response: Preliminary engineering has been provided to and coordinated with the Village
                   Engineers to ensure that adequate facilities are being provided. Final engineering and permit
                   documents will be provided to meet the best practices as required by the Village.

              7. Adequate Buffering

                   Adequate fencing and/or screening shall be provided to ensure the enjoyment of
                   surrounding properties, to provide for the public safety or to screen parking areas and
                   other visually incompatible uses.

                   Response: The enclosed site plan and landscape plan have been provided to and coordinated
                   with the Village Engineers to ensure that adequate buffering will be provided to meet the Village
                   requirements and ordinances.

              8. Village Center District

                   If in C-1 Village Center District: That the establishment of the Special Use will not be
                   injurious to the character of the C-1 Village Center District as a retail center for the
                   Village.

                   Response: 780 Saunders Road falls outside the C-1 Village Center District




Project No. 8121561| March 27, 2013
                                                    Rezoning Standards
                                                    Health O Wealth Inc.
                                                    780 Saunders Road
                                                        Deerfield, IL


              1. Existing Uses

                   Existing uses of property within the general area of the property in question.

                   Response: North: Village of Riverwoods- commercial properties (bank with a drive-thru and a
                   gas station with a convenience store. South: I-1 Office, Research and Restricted Industry-
                   Parkway North Center. East: I-1 Office, Research and Restricted Industry- Parkway North
                   Center. West: Village of Riverwoods- single family homes

              2. Current Zoning in Area

                   The Zoning classification of property within the general area of the property in question.

                   Response: North: Village of Riverwoods- commercial properties. South: I-1 Office, Research
                   and Restricted Industry. East: I-1 Office, Research and Restricted Industry. West: Village of
                   Riverwoods- residential.

              3. Suitability of Present Zoning

                   The suitability of the property in question for the uses permitted under the existing
                   zoning classification and the proposed classification.

                   Response: The property in question is currently zoned R-1 Single Family Residential which is
                   not suitable to the proposed restaurant use. In order to provide suitability for the proposed
                   restaurant use, the proposed classification requested is C-2 Outlying Commercial District.

              4. Trend of Development

                   The trend of development, if any, in the general area of the property in question,
                   including changes, if any, which may have taken place since the day the property in
                   question was placed in it's present zoning classification.

                   Response: The trend of development in the general area of the property (East of Saunders
                   Road) is office/research use as identified in the Village Future Land Use Map in the
                   Comprehensive Plan. To the North and outside of the Village boundaries (East of Saunders
                   Road), the trend of development is commercial use. Significant changes have taken place since
                   the property in question was placed in in the present zoning classification of R-1 Single Family
                   Residential. The East side of Saunders Road within and outside of the Village boundaries has
                   moved away from residential uses and toward generally commercial uses.




Project No. 8121561| March 27, 2013
                                                      Sustainable Design
                                                      Health O Wealth Inc.
                                                      780 Saunders Road
                                                          Deerfield, IL

                   Shive-Hattery has incorporated many environmentally friendly design practices into the Health
                   O Wealth restaurant project that directly correlates with the ideals of inspiring wellness and
                   healthy living proposed by the Owners. With guidance from the LEED (Leadership in Energy
                   and Environmental Design) program as a model, the project will be environmentally responsible
                   to its surroundings.

                   The site will be improved through several different design features. The storm water system will
                   incorporate a storm water recharge and infiltration basin to promote water infiltration and reduce
                   offsite water flow. The site lighting will be designed to reduce light trespass or pollution to
                   surrounding areas. The roof materials will be highly reflective, reducing the heat island effect on
                   the site.

                   Consideration of regional and microclimatic conditions played an important role in the selection and
                   placement of plant materials. Native and adapted plant materials were selected for their adaptability
                   to normal rainfall conditions and year round interest. Varieties of native and adapted Maples, Filberts
                   and Ironwood trees help define various uses throughout the site and provide shade to outdoor use
                   areas. Native ground layer grasses, perennials and shrubs including Sumac, Viburnum, Redcedar,
                   Prairie Dropseed, Blueflag Iris and various sedges will provide color and texture throughout the year
                   while reducing the need for supplemental watering. The storm water recharge and filtration basin will
                   be planted with native sedges and forbs.

                   In terms of building operations, HVAC, lighting and other building systems will meet energy
                   efficiency and ventilation standards to promote a healthy indoor environment. Keeping with the
                   idea of a healthy indoor environment, an environmentally friendly practice that will not be as
                   apparent is specifying the use of Low VOC (Volatile Organic Compound) emitting materials
                   (Adhesives, sealants, paints, etc.) Water use will also be reduced substantially through the use
                   of energy efficient fixtures and controls throughout.

                   A prominent practice that will be in place on the site is an intensive program to limit the amount
                   of waste being removed from the site. There will be a recycling/composting program to virtually
                   eliminate waste from entering the surrounding landfills. Not only will this be supported by the
                   Owners through the materials brought into the building (recyclable/compostable containers,
                   etc.), but the program will involve the customers with a three bin disposal setup of waste,
                   recyclable and compostable material. Composting will occur on-site and be educational to the
                   patrons that visit this establishment.

                   Alternative transportation is encouraged by the structures position on the lot so as to inspire use
                   and access by occupants of the neighboring properties via walking or cycling in addition to
                   traditional motorized vehicles. A connection to the existing pedestrian/cycling path on the
                   adjacent property emphasizes the compatibility with the existing surrounding developments.
                   Bike racks are incorporated into the buildings deck design.




Project No. 8121561| March 27, 2013
                                         Comprehensive Plan Amendment Request
                                                  Health O Wealth Inc.
                                                  780 Saunders Road
                                                      Deerfield, IL


                    The trend of development in the general area of the property (East of Saunders Road) is
                    office/research use as identified in the Village Future Land Use Map in the Comprehensive
                    Plan.

                    However, to the North and outside of the Village boundaries (East of Saunders Road), the trend
                    of development is commercial use. Significant changes have taken place since the property in
                    question was placed in in the present zoning classification of R-1 Single Family Residential. The
                    East side of Saunders Road within and outside of the Village boundaries has moved away from
                    residential uses and toward generally commercial uses.

                    Office/research uses do not generate sales tax revenue for the Village.

                    The Village will benefit from the redevelopment of this property as a commercial use by
                    collecting sales tax from proposed businesses that are allowed in the C-2 Outlying Commercial
                    zoning classification.

INTRODUCTION      

A traffic impact study was conducted for a proposed 3,000 square-foot restaurant in Deerfield, Illinois. The
restaurant is anticipated to have available seating for sixty (60) patrons. One full access driveway will be
provided for the site along Saunders Road, approximately 250 feet south of the Deerfield Road/Saunders
Road intersection. An aerial view of the study location and the surrounding roadway network is presented
in Exhibit 1.

As a part of this study, site trip generation characteristics were established for the new facility and the
future (Year 2019) traffic scenario was evaluated for the proposed access.

This report presents and documents TADI's data collection, summarizes the evaluation of traffic conditions
on the surrounding roadways, evaluates the proposed site plan, and details the potential impact of
development traffic on the adjacent roadway network.




780 Saunders Road Restaurant  Deerfield                                                                Page 2

                                              SITE LOCATION MAP
                                                       EXHIBIT 1
EXISTING CONDITIONS  

TADI conducted field observations to collect relevant information pertaining to the site, existing land uses
in the surrounding area, the adjacent roadway network, current traffic volumes and operational conditions,
lane configurations and traffic controls, and other key roadway characteristics. A detailed account of this
information and findings are as follows.


Existing Land Uses 
The subject site is located along Saunders Road approximately 250 feet south of its intersection with
Deerfield Road in Deerfield, Illinois and is currently occupied by a private residence. Immediately north of
the site is Edens Bank with access via both Saunders Road and Deerfield Road. At the southeast corner of
the Saunders Road/Deerfield Road intersection and north of the bank access, is a Mobil gas station. An
office park, Parkway North Center, is located east and south of the proposed site along Parkway North.
Although not yet fully occupied, the office park currently provides offices for Walgreens University,
Friedman Corporation, and CF Industries Holdings as well as a Marriott Suites hotel and the Parkway
Athletic Club. One office parcel within the development maintains a parking lot bordering the east side of
the subject site.

The areas north of Deerfield Road and west of Saunders Road are generally residential in use. Several
business parks are also located further south along Saunders Road including businesses such as Diners
Club International, Discover Financial Services and the United States headquarters for Takeda Global
Research & Development and Takeda Pharmaceuticals.


Existing Roadway Characteristics  
A field investigation was conducted for Saunders Road within the study area.           A description of the
roadway is summarized below.

Saunders Road is a north-south arterial roadway under the jurisdiction of the Lake County Division of
Transportation (LCDOT). At the proposed site access, the roadway provides two through lanes in each
direction and a northbound left-turn lane extending south from the intersection with Deerfield Road. The
speed limit is posted as 45 MPH within the study area. Saunders Road intersects with Deerfield Road,
approximately 250 feet north of the site, and Parkway North, approximately a quarter mile south of the site.
In addition to the five-foot sidewalk provided on both sides of the roadway, a multi-use trail runs along the
east side of Saunders Road and around the adjacent office park (Parkway North Center).

                                      




780 Saunders Road Restaurant  Deerfield                                                                 Page 4 
March 2013 
Traffic Count Data 
A manual traffic count was performed on Saunders Road adjacent to the subject site in March 2013 during
the weekday morning (7:00-9:00 AM) and evening (4:00-6:00 PM) peak periods. The resulting traffic counts
indicate that the heaviest traveled hours occurred from 7:45 to 8:45 AM and 4:30 to 5:30 PM. The existing
traffic suggests a heavy directional split with 73% of traffic traveling southbound in the AM and 75% of traffic
traveling northbound in the PM. This split is likely representative of travel to and from the office park and
properties to the south residential areas to the north and vice versa in the evening. The existing traffic data is
presented in Exhibit 2.

                                                                       EXISTING (2013)/FUTURE (2019) TRAFFIC VOLUMES
                                                                                                             EXHIBIT 2
FUTURE CONDITIONS 

This section of the report outlines the proposed development plan, summarizes site-specific traffic
characteristics, and develops future traffic projections for analysis.


Development Characteristics & Site Access 
The proposed development is planned to include a 3,000 square-foot restaurant. Access would be provided
to the site through a full access driveway on Saunders Road (Restaurant Drive). Currently, the site is
proposed to be developed as a healthy food café with 60% carry-out customers and 40% dine-in customers.
The restaurant is planned to include an outdoor patio and would utilize seasonal seating plans
accommodating a maximum of sixty (60) seats.


Trip Generation 
In order to calculate site-generated traffic projections for the proposed site, data was referenced from the
Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) manual titled Trip Generation, Ninth Edition. Trip generation
data for the appropriate ITE Land Use Code (LUC) is shown in Table 1. Copies of the ITE data are
provided in the appendix.

Table 1. ITE Trip Generation Data by Land Use1 
                                                                                       Weekday
    Land Use 
                                                                Daily                   AM Peak                 PM Peak
    HighTurnover SitDown Restaurant                           127.15                     10.81                    9.85
    (LUC 932)                                              50% in/50% out            55% in/45% out          60% in/40% out 
1
    Rates equal to the number of projected site trips per fueling station 

Based on the data shown in Table 1, site-generated traffic projections were calculated for the proposed
restaurant. In order to be conservative, reductions were not taken to account for pass-by trips. A summary
of projected site trips is provided in Table 2.

Table 2. SiteGenerated Traffic Projections 
                                                                                           Weekday
    Land Use                                   Size                                AM Peak                     PM Peak 
                                                               Daily 
                                                                             In     Out       Total    In         Out      Total
    HighTurnover SitDown 
                                         3,000 sq. ft.          380          20      15         35     20         10           30 
    Restaurant 
    Total                                                       380          20      15         35     20         10           30


 
                                            



780 Saunders Road Restaurant  Deerfield                                                                                        Page 7 
March 2013 
Directional Distribution  
After establishing the expected site traffic volumes, a projected trip distribution was derived from existing
traffic patterns in the study area and the nature of surrounding land uses. It was assumed that 40% of
traffic will travel to/from the north and that 60% will travel to/from the south. Traffic generated by the
new use was assigned to the adjacent roadway network and the proposed site access system according to
the distribution described above.


Projected Future Traffic 
The restaurant is expected to be constructed and occupied by Year 2014. Therefore, to represent a "Build + 5
Year" analysis horizon, Year 2019 is defined as the future condition analysis horizon for purposes of this
study. To account for potential growth of background traffic volumes in the area, a three percent annual
growth rate was applied to existing traffic volumes (equivalent to roughly 18 percent growth over 6 years),
consistent with LCDOT guidelines. Site-generated trips were added to the 2019 background traffic to yield
total volumes at the study intersections. The Future Scenario volumes are also illustrated in Exhibit 2.


Capacity Analysis 
Traffic volume data was analyzed with Highway Capacity Software (HCS) in order to determine the quality
of operation in the future network. Operation is characterized according to the amount of control delay at
each approach and quantified into a level of service (LOS). The LOS grades shown below, which are
provided in the Transportation Research Board's Highway Capacity Manual (HCM), quantify and
categorize a driver's discomfort, frustration, fuel consumption, and travel times experienced as a result of
intersection control and the resulting traffic queuing. LOS D is typically the minimum acceptable LOS
accepted by agencies in Illinois (including LCDOT). A detailed description of each LOS rating can be found
in Table 3.




780 Saunders Road Restaurant  Deerfield                                                                 Page 8 
March 2013 
Table 3. Level of Service Grading Descriptions1 
     Level of Service                                                      Description
                         Minimal control delay; traffic operates at primarily freeflow conditions; unimpeded movement within 
            A 
                         traffic stream. 
                         Minor control delay at signalized intersections; traffic operates at a fairly unimpeded level with slightly 
            B 
                         restricted movement within traffic stream. 
                         Moderate control delay; movement within traffic stream more restricted than at LOS B; formation of 
            C 
                         queues contributes to lower average travel speeds. 
                         Considerable control delay that may be substantially increased by small increases in flow; average travel 
            D 
                         speeds continue to decrease. 
             E           High control delay; average travel speed no more than 33 percent of free flow speed. 
             F           Extremely high control delay; extensive queuing and high volumes create exceedingly restricted traffic flow.
1
    Highway Capacity Manual 2010 

Table 4 presents the range of control delay for each LOS rating as detailed in the HCM. Because signalized
intersections are expected to carry a larger volume of vehicles and stopping is required during red time,
note that higher delays are tolerated for the corresponding LOS ratings.

Table 4. Level of Service Grading Criteria1 
                                                              Control Delay per Vehicle (s/veh) at:
     Level of Service 
                                         Unsignalized Intersections                               Signalized Intersections
            A                                      0 ­ 10                                                   0 ­ 10 
            B                                    > 10 ­ 15                                                > 10 ­ 20 
            C                                    > 15 ­ 25                                                > 20 ­ 35 
            D                                    > 25 ­ 35                                                > 35 ­ 55 
            E                                    > 35 ­ 50                                                > 55 ­ 80 
            F2                                      > 50                                                     > 80 
1
    Highway Capacity Manual 2010 
2
    All movements with a Volume to Capacity (v/C) ratio greater than 1 receive a rating of LOS F. 

Based on the HCM standards, each approach and/or movement LOS was determined for the identified
weekday morning and evening peak hours. LOS data for the study intersection is reported in Table 5.

For the purposes of this unsignalized intersection analysis, the distribution of upstream traffic at the
Deerfield Road/Saunders Road intersection was incorporated with an assumed split of 75% traveling south
through the intersection on Saunders Road and 25% making a westbound left-turn from Deerfield Road.




780 Saunders Road Restaurant  Deerfield                                                                                         Page 9 
March 2013 
Table 5. Projected Future (2019) Levels of Service1 
                                                              Weekday AM Peak           Weekday PM Peak
                                                       Delay (sec)         LOS   Delay (sec)          LOS
 Saunders Road/Restaurant Drive                     
   Southbound (Left)                                      9                A        13                B
   Westbound (Left)                                       14               B        43                E
1      Results based upon HCM 2010 Methodology. 

Analysis of the Year 2019 scenario suggests that the addition of site traffic will not cause significant delay
for Saunders Road traffic at the intersection with the site access. During the PM peak hour, the westbound
left-turn movement exiting the site is anticipated to operate at LOS E; however, the 95th percentile queue for
exiting traffic is projected to be less than one vehicle. It is not uncommon for the minor leg approach, and
particularly the left-turn movement, of a Two-Way Stop Controlled (TWSC) intersection with an arterial
roadway, such as Saunders Road, to operate below LOS D. Vehicles turning left from the minor street often
utilizes gaps in traffic flow created by adjacent upstream signalized intersections along Saunders Road at
Deerfield Road and Parkway North.


Site Access and Circulation Review 

This section describes and summarizes review of on-site vehicular circulation and outlines any related
recommendations. 

OnSite Queuing 

One access driveway is proposed for the subject site on Saunders Road. Review of projected outbound
vehicle queues, based on the capacity analysis, suggests that the 95th percentile queue projections for
vehicles exiting the site do not exceed one vehicle during either of the peak hours. Thus, exiting vehicle
queues are not expected to impact internal traffic circulation.

Parking

The proposed plan includes thirty-three (33) parking spaces Based on the Village's Ordinance, the off-street
parking requirements and calculations associated with the proposed plan are outlined below:




780 Saunders Road Restaurant  Deerfield                                                                     Page 10 
March 2013 
Table 6. Village Required Parking 
                                   Portion of          Square          Ordinance (space/square feet
        Restaurant Type                                                                               Required (spaces) 
                                   Restaurant          Footage               gross floor area)1 
            CarryOut                  60%               1,800                      1/120                     15
            SitDown                   40%               1,200                       1/60                     20
              Total                  100%               3,000                       N/A                      35
1
    Per the Village of Deerfield Zoning Ordinance Article 8.02E Required Spaces 

As shown in Table 6, the Village's off-street parking requirement for the proposed restaurant is 35 spaces.
The proposed site plan includes 33 off-street parking spaces with a requested variance allowing 33 off-street
parking spaces.

Due to lack of recirculation options for restaurant customers, TADI recommends that the western three to
four parallel parking stalls located along the north side of the site should be designated and signed as
employee parking only.

Trucks Access/Delivery 

A dumpster would be provided inside the building along the north wall. Access doors will be provided so
that the dumpster can be moved outside for collection. Vehicles expected to serve deliveries and service
vehicles are expected to be up to a thirty-foot (30') single-unit truck. AutoTURN for the design vehicle
provided by the architect indicate that the vehicle would enter, deliver products/collect refuse, and then
complete a three-point turn in the main parking area before exiting the site. The AutoTURN analysis
provided by the architect is provided in the attached appendix.

Based the anticipated truck turning patterns, the on-site truck circulation requires the use of several parking
spaces and the drive aisle. Therefore, TADI recommends that all loading, delivery, and refuse collection
must occur during off-business hours in order to avoid negatively impacting parking and circulation.

Circulation 

Vehicles would enter on the west side of the site and travel east across the north side of the proposed
restaurant. After passing the building, vehicles would make a right turn and travel through a parking drive
aisle. At the end of the parking aisle, vehicles would circulate counterclockwise around the east side of the
parking aisle, and exit after traveling back across the site.

Parking would be located on the east side of the site with parallel parking spaces along the north side of the
site. Based upon the AutoTURN analysis provided by the architect, it may be difficult for vehicles to easily
maneuver through the parking area without negatively impacting traffic circulation or conflicting with
parked vehicles. The parallel parking spaces on the east side of the site have been configured to
accommodate the vehicle turning pattern. The constraint width of the site, in combination with the
provision of parking, limits the ability for vehicles to recirculate counterclockwise again through the
parking drive aisle.



780 Saunders Road Restaurant  Deerfield                                                                                Page 11 
March 2013 
Access Site Distance 

Vertical sight distance does not appear to be an issue with any of the planned access locations, but care
should be taken with landscaping, signage, and monumentation to ensure that adequate horizontal sight
distance is provided from the stop bar locations.                           




780 Saunders Road Restaurant  Deerfield                                                            Page 12 
March 2013 
CONCLUSIONS 

Based on TADI's review of the proposed site plan and evaluation of future traffic conditions with
development of the proposed restaurant, the proposed access at Saunders Road is expected to adequately
accommodate the proposed development. To date, LCDOT has approved a full access serving the
restaurant at the proposed location on Saunders Road.

In order to limit the impacts to traffic circulation and on-site parking, all delivery/service vehicle activity
should be limited to occur only during non-business hours. Parallel parking, indicated in the proposed
plan, is configured in such a way to accommodate the counterclockwise circulation pattern for a passenger
vehicle around the east side of the site. TADI recommends that three to four of the most western parallel
parking stalls should be designated for employee only parking.

If alterations to the site plan or land uses should occur, changes to the analysis within this traffic impact
study may be necessary.

780 Saunders Road Restaurant - Deerfield                              Page 5 
1
                          Land Use: 932
                High-Turnover (Sit-Down) Restaurant

Descr iption

This land use consists of sit-down, full-service eating establishments with typical duration of stay of
approximately one hour. This type of restaurant is usually moderately priced and frequently belongs
to a restaurant chain. Generally, these restaurants serve lunch and dinner; they may also be open
for breakfast and are sometimes open 24 hours per day. These restaurants typically do not take
reservations. Patrons commonly wait to be seated, are served by a waiter/waitress, order from
menus and pay tor their mea! after they eat. Some facilities contained within this land use may also
contain a bar area for serving food and alcoholic drinks. Quality restaurant (Land Use 931 ), fast-food
restaurant without drive-through window (Land Use 933). fast-food reslaurant w ith drive-through
window (Land Use 934) and fast-food restaurant with drive-through window and no Indoor seating
(Land Use 935) are related uses.


A dd itional Data

Users should exercise caution when applying statistics during the A.M. peak periods, as the
sites contained in the database for this land use may or may not be open for breakfast. In
cases where It was conflrmed that the sites were not open for breakfast, data for the A. M.
peak hour of the adjacent street traffic were removed from the database.

Information on approximate hourly variation in high-turnover (sit.Oown) restaurant traffic is shown in
the following table. It should be noted, however, that the information contained in this table is based
on a limited sample size. Therefore, caution should be exercised when applying the data. Also, some
information provided in the table may conflict with the results obtained by applying the average rate
or regression equations. When this occurs, It Is suggested that t.he results from the average rate or
regression equations be used, as they are based on a larger number of studies.

       Vehicle occupancy ranged from 1.39 to 1.69 persons per automobile on an average weekday.
       The average for the sites surveyed was approximately 1.52.

       Five sites submitted for inclusion in this land use indicated the presence of an on-site pick-up window. From
       the limited data sample, it does not appear that the presence of a pick-up window had a significant impact
       on trip generation.

       The outdoor seating area is not included in the overall gross floor area. Therefore, the number of seats
       may be a more reliable independent variable on which to establish trip generation rates for facilities having
       significant outdoor seating .

       The sites were surveyed between the 1960s and the 2000s throughout the United States.

    Re:      'fhorngate Owners Association

    Dear Mayor Kaplan, Mayor Rosenthal and Ms. Maine:

    As the attorneys for the Thorngate Owners Association, we have been requested to contact you with
    regard to the proposed restaurant to be opened at the corner of Saunders Road and Deerfield Road.

    Please be adv.'ised, the Board of Directors for the Thorngate Homeowners Association is in opposition of
    this modification to this property. The Board believes that it will have a serious adverse impact on the
    traffic in this area, as it will lead to severe congestion and could create a safety hazard for the occupants
    using the roads. As you are aware, there is a severe back-up on Deerfield Road during rush hour, and a
    restaurant will lead to greater congestion. In addition, th{l residents fear that there will not be enough
    parking, causing further traffic problems at this already busy io.t(1rsection.

    Based on the above, the Board requests that the Village of Riverwoods deny this request. If you should
    have any questions please contact us.
