                       REQUEST FOR BOARD ACTION

                                                         Agenda Item: 13-56

SUBJECT: Report and Recommendation of the Board of Zoning Appeals RE:
Request of Health O Wealth Inc., 780 Saunders Rd., Deerfield, Illinois. The
Application Seeks Variations: (1) to reduce the minimum 50 foot front yard
setback to 25 feet (5.02-F,3,a) and (2) to reduce the side yard setback from a
minimum of 12 feet to 7 feet (5.02-f,3,b) and (3) to reduce the required number of
parking spaces from 35 spaces to 33 spaces (8.02-E,2,i) of the Deerfield Zoning
Ordinance, to allow for the construction, of a new restaurant on the subject
property as depicted in the plans provided

Action Requested: Acceptance of the BZA Recommendation_____________

Originated By: Board of Zoning Appeals______________________________

Referred To: Mayor and Board of Trustees____________________________

Summary of Background and Reason for Request:

A Public Hearing was held on May 7, 2013 to consider the petition of Health O
Wealth Inc., for variations reducing minimum front yard, side yard, and total
parking spaces.
1. A minimum front yard of 25 feet in lieu of the 50 fee specified.
2. A minimum south side, side yard of 7 feet in lieu of the required 12 feet.
Parking Variation
Be granted to permit 33 spaces, including accessible parking spaces in lieu of the
35 spaces required.
The votes were in favor of recommending the granting of the variations as
presented without restrictions.

Reports and Documents Attached:

Recommendation, Minutes, Exhibits, Map


Date Referred to Board: June 3, 2013


                                      Action Taken: _____________________
                               RECOMMENDATION


TO:          Mayor and Board of Trustees

FROM:        Board of Zoning Appeals

DATE:        May 7, 2013


SUBJECT: Front Yard, Side Yard and Parking Variation
         780 Saunders Rd. (Health O Wealth Inc.)

We transmit for your consideration recommendations adopted by the Deerfield Board of
Zoning Appeals on the petition of Health O Wealth Inc., 780 Saunders Rd. Deerfield,
Illinois. The petitioner seeks variations: (1) to reduce the minimum 50 foot front yard
setback to 25 feet (5.02-F,3,a) and (2) to reduce the side yard setback from a minimum of
12 feet to 7 feet (5.02-f,3,b) and (3) to reduce the required number of parking spaces from
35 spaces to 33 spaces (8.02-E,2,i) of the Deerfield Zoning Ordinance, to allow for the
construction, of a new restaurant on the subject property as depicted in the plans provided.

FINDINGS OF FACT

          1. The subject lot of record is zoned R-1 (Single Family Residential) and is
             currently in the Plan Commission process to be rezoned to C-2 (Outlying
             Commercial).

          2. The subject property was annexed into the Village September 14, 1994.

          3. The subject property was developed as a single family residence prior to
             annexation.

          4. The petitioner's variation requests are driven by the need to configure the site
             to accommodate the location of the new restaurant building and parking in the
             most efficient configuration on a unique site.

          5. The parcel is not part of the Parkway North Development but is contiguous to
             the Parkway North walking path on two sides.

CONCLUSIONS

          1. The requested relief from the strict interpretation of the Zoning Ordinance
             would not alter the proposed use of the property.

          2. The variations if granted would enhance public safety and improve internal
             traffic flow.

          3. The requested variations conform to the standards for variation, enumerated
             in Section 13.07-E of the Deerfield Zoning Ordinance.

          4. The variations requested, if granted will permit the parcel to be developed as
             designed, allowing the beneficial use of the land by the petitioner.
Board of Zoning Appeals Recommendation (780 Saunders Road)
Page two
May 7, 2013


   MOTIONS AND VOTES

   Front Setback Variation
   Mr. Adams made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Board of Trustees
   regarding the portion of the petition pertaining to the front variation. Ms. Scott seconded the
   motion. The motion passed by the following vote:

   AYES: Kuczek, Adams, Bezman, Scott, Speckmann (5)
   NAYS: Kessel, (1)

   Minimum Side Yard Setback Variation
   Mr. Kessel made a motion to recommend the granting of the side yard setback request.
   Ms. Scott seconded the motion. The motion passed by the following vote:

   AYES: Bezman, Kessel, Scott, Speckmann (4)
   NAYS: Adams (1)

   PARKING VARIATION
   Mr. Adams made a motion to recommend the Health O Wealth parking variation as
   presented be granted. Ms. Scott seconded the motion. The motion passed unanimously
   by the following vote:

   AYES: Adams, Bezman, Kessel, Scott, Speckmann (5)
   NAYS: None (0)


   RECOMMENDATIONS
   Therefore it is the recommendation of the Deerfield Board of Zoning Appeals that the
   following requests for variation by Health O Wealth Inc. be granted.

   Minimum Front and Side Yard Setback Variations
   1. A minimum front yard of 25 feet in lieu of the 50 feet specified.

   2. A minimum south side, side yard of 7 feet in lieu of the required 12 feet.

   Parking Variation
   Be granted to permit 33 spaces, including accessible parking spaces in lieu of the 35
   spaces required.

   Respectfully submitted,


   Robert Speckmann, Chairman
   Deerfield Board of Zoning Appeals
                                Board of Zoning Appeals

Minutes of Public Hearing                                                   May 7, 2013

A Deerfield Board of Zoning Appeals held a Public Hearing on Tuesday May 7, 2013 at
7:30 p.m. at the Village Hall Conference Room, 850 Waukegan Road, Deerfield, Illinois.
Chairman Robert Speckmann called the meeting to order at 7:30 p.m.

Ch. Speckmann indicated the Board of Zoning Appeals is advisory to the Mayor and
Board of Trustees. He explained the BZA's deliberations and recommendations would
be in front of the Trustees at their June 3, 2013 meeting. Ch. Speckmann requested the
petitioners appear at that meeting to answer any questions the Trustees may have.

Present were:
Chairman Bob Speckmann
Len Adams
Karen Bezman
Herb Kessel
Ted Kuczek (left at 8:30 pm)
Karen Scott

Absent was:
Jeff Auerbach

Also Present:
Clint Case, Enforcement Officer
Jeff Hansen, Assistant Code Enforcement Officer

Mr. Hansen confirmed the mailings were in order and the Public Hearing was properly
advertised and listed. Ch. Speckmann swore in the petitioners for both petitions and
opened the Public Hearing.

The first petition is seeking a rear yard setback variation. The petitioners, Kevin and
Claudine Harig, own the property commonly known as 260 Deerfield Road, Deerfield,
Illinois 60015. Mr. Harig indicated they propose correcting the north (rear) setback on
the lot line to reflect the existing structure. When the lot was subdivided in 1968, the
setback and structure were not taken into consideration and there is a required 50 foot
setback. They would like to have the setback corrected to make their existing house
conformant.

Ch. Speckmann noted this is a housekeeping issue, as it was not addressed in 1968
when the lot was subdivided. They did not create a rear yard that was conforming, so
the lot is not conforming at this time.
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 2 of 7

Mrs. Harig explained the issue was found as they went through the permit process.
They are looking to build out their property with an addition. Mrs. Harig indicated they
propose upgrading the electrical and plumbing as well.

Ms. Scott questioned the garage reconstruction. Ms. Harig explained the garage walls
would be torn down to allow for a roof extension, but would be reconstructed in the
same area. The garage would remain a detached garage.

Ch. Speckmann noted that the legal notice requested a rear yard of 44.44 feet, but the
documentation indicated a rear yard of 43.6 feet. He believes that would put a bend in
the back wall of the addtion. In order to create an addition with a straight wall, Ch.
Speckmann believes the actual setback should be 43 feet to allow room if the
foundation does not line up properly. He suggested the petition be adjusted to allow a
variance of 43.00 feet.

Mr. Adams questioned whether the garage would be the same size, but the opening be
changed so it opens to the east side of the property. Ms. Harig explained the garage
would be enlarged slightly to the north and the roof would overhang to allow for a
walkway. He noted the petitioner currently accesses the garage from the west side.

Mr. Adams questioned whether that existing curb cut would be closed. Ms. Harig
explained they would add a curb cut next to the neighbor's curb cut. There was a legal
document between the two deeds stipulating the easement portion of the Harig's lot,
which has the adjacent curb cut, is only for the use of the adjacent property. It is not
allowed to be shared. Ms. Harig noted there is a document stating the easement is a
sole use easement

The variation if granted would permit a 43.00 foot rear yard setback variation.

Ch. Speckmann closed the information gathering portion of the Public Hearing.

Mr. Kessel made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Mayor and Board
of Trustees to grant the variation as presented and amended. Mr. Adams seconded the
motion. The motion passed unanimously.

Ch. Speckmann reopened the Public Hearing to consider a front yard setback variation
for the property located at 780 Saunders Road.

Brett Webster, architect and project manager representing the Abbots, owners of the
property commonly known as 780 Saunders Road, indicated the existing house and
freestanding sheds on the property that would be removed to create space for a
proposed restaurant.

Mr. Webster explained the proposed restaurant is a 3000 square foot structure with an
outdoor dining area along the south property line. The parking area will be on the rear
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 3 of 7

of the site. The business will have a mix of carry-out and dine-in service. Mr. Webster
indicated the proposed restaurant features healthy dining with a zero-waste scheme.
The site has been designed for access from the office park. Patrons are also
encouraged to walk and use bicycles to access the restaurant. Ch. Speckmann asked if
an easement has been negotiated with the Parkway North office park. Mr. Webster
explained they are in process of negotiating an easement.

Ch. Speckmann asked why it is necessary to have the building closer to the street than
what is allowed in the Ordinance. Mr. Webster explained that they provided a letter
describing the requested variations along with the standards. The first standard, not a
use variation, is not applicable to the property because they are in process of requesting
a Zoning change with the Board of Trustees. The second standard is unique to the
property. Mr. Webster noted the parcel is currently zoned R-1 situated between an
office complex and the Village of Riverwoods. The parcel was not part of the large
office complex to the south and the east. Directly to the north of the parcel is a bank
with a parking lot and driveway access and then the Mobile station on the corner. The
result is this long, narrow parcel. The Comprehensive Plan recommended this property
have the same type of use as the office complex; however, the owners did not find a
way to comply as an office use. The reality of the parcel is that there is only so large of
a building that can fit on the parcel and allow for parking and landscaping. Mr. Webster
spoke with the planning staff that would prefer the parcel to be a tax-generating
business and zoned as outlying commercial. The Abbots, who operate the Mobile gas
station on the corner of Deerfield and Riverwoods Roads, believe a 3000 square foot
restaurant would be appropriate for the parcel.

Ch. Speckmann noted Lake County Department of Transportation is taking 10 feet of
property for a wider right-of-way, which if not done would result in a 35 foot setback
rather than a 25 foot setback. Mr. Webster noted that if the setback were place an
additional 25 feet from Saunders, the restaurant would have to be pushed back and the
building would have to be made smaller. Ch. Speckmann noted parking calculations,
building and plumbing codes differ for a 2000 square foot seating area (excluding the
back house area.) The current building regulations would allow one person per 15
square feet of area. Ch. Speckmann expressed concern because there would only be
50 people in a space large enough for 130. Mr. Webster explained there would include
a mix of a sit-down restaurant and selling of packaged food. Ch. Speckmann explained
the maximum number of patrons would be 50. He believes the space will seem very
empty. Ch. Speckmann questioned why the restaurant needs this much space, as the
fire department will issue a maximum occupancy. He indicated the petitioner may not
need as many variances if the restaurant size were reduced. He suggested the
petitioners look at the design and determine whether or not they really need that much
space.

Mr. Abbott explained most of their customers will be from the office complexes during
lunch and food delivery will be made available. Mr. Abbott noted they need the space
because they will be offering gluten free options which need to be prepared separately.
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 4 of 7

Ch. Speckmann noted the current floor plan does not allow adequate space for the
entire back of house area as just described. He believes reducing the dining room size
would make the petition more appropriate. Mr. Webster explained the proposed interior
layout was a preliminary scheme. Mr. Abbott would prefer to have more room to
accommodate patrons. He also indicated the employees would park at the Mobile
station. In addition, they are in discussion with the bank regarding additional parking.

Mr. Webster explained attaining a 50 foot front yard setback would be difficult to
achieve. The owners requested a variation that would allow the most flexibility to have
a long-lasting, thriving business on the parcel.

Mr. Kessel asked about the pedestrian traffic flow and the path along the eastern edge
of the property. Mr. Webster showed the path on the Parkway North property that
continues around the building. He noted there are two entrances into the restaurant,
one in the front and one in the rear.

Ch. Speckmann closed the information gathering portion of the Public Hearing. Mr.
Kessel questioned whether the Village could live with a 50% variation. Ch. Speckmann
explained the Lake County Department of Transportation is taking 10 feet, so he does
not have an issue with this variation.

Mr. Adams made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Board of
Trustees regarding the portion of the petition regarding the front yard setback variation.
Ms. Scott seconded the motion. The motion passed by the following vote:

AYES: Kuczek, Scott, Adams, Bezman, Speckmann (5)
NAYS: Kessel (1)

Ch. Speckmann reopened the Public Hearing to consider the south side yard setback
variation of seven feet for the property located at 780 Saunders Road. He assumed the
deck would be a raised deck rather than a patio. If it is a patio, the variation request
would not be necessary. Mr. Webster noted there would be steel columns extending
higher than the building roof. There will be a sunscreen and a vertical garden. Ch.
Speckmann indicated the raised deck must have a variation. Mr. Webster noted it is not
a raised deck, but it would be enclosed with a transparent structure. Code Enforcement
Officer Case indicated that if the structure has columns, it would need to be reviewed.

Ch. Speckmann indicated he neglected to ask for public comment during the front yard
setback variation request. He asked if there were any comments.

David Schreiber, 464 Pebble Beach Lane, Riverwoods, is president of the Thorngate
Homeowners Association. Thorngate is located across the street of the property, in
Riverwoods. Mr. Schreiber indicated they are against moving the building closer to the
road. Mr. Schreiber expressed concern about the lighting that will shine in the bedroom
windows of their homeowners. In addition, they feel allowing vehicles to turn
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 5 of 7

southbound onto Saunders Road will create a safety hazard. The Thorngate
Homeowner's Association requested only allowing vehicles to enter the property from
the south and exit the property going north. Trying to cut across traffic will create a
problem. Ch. Speckmann indicated Mr. Schreiber's request is outside the scope of the
Board of Zoning Appeals. He noted the Plan Commission already heard this request
and rejected it. Ch. Speckmann suggested Mr. Schreiber appear before the Mayor and
Board of Trustees.

Mr. Adams noted the lighting is typically in the parking area, which is located in the rear
of the restaurant. Mr. Schreiber noted that the ambient lighting would also disturb their
homeowners. Ch. Speckmann indicated that this is also outside the Board of Zoning
Appeals jurisdiction. Ms. Bezman noted the gas station lighting is brighter than
whatever lighting the restaurant would have. Mr. Schreiber explained the Abbotts have
changed the bulbs to make them less visible from Thorngate. He noted that if the
building were further set back, it would not make a difference to the residents of
Thorngate.

Mr. Kuczek made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Board of
Trustees regarding the portion of the petition regarding the front yard setback variation.
Mr. Kessel seconded the motion. The motion passed 5-1 with Mr. Kessel voting against
the petition.

Ch. Speckmann asked if there were any questions regarding the side yard setback
variation request. Mr. Kessel questioned what is to the south of the proposed
development. Mr. Webster explained it is an empty pad that is ready for an office
building that is pre-approved for a PUD. It is located on John Buck's property. Ch.
Speckmann spoke with Village Planner Jeff Ryckaert, who indicated that property
requires a 300 foot setback.

Mr. Adams noted the proposed outdoor deck seating would be according to the Plan
Commission recommendation and would not count against the parking requirement.
Ch. Speckmann indicated that was the recommendation of the Plan Commission. Mr.
Adams explained the proposed outdoor structure is somewhat permanent and it would
not be too difficult to further enclose the structure so it is available more than three
months a year. One of the requirements is to make the variations the minimum
necessary. Mr. Adams does not believe the proposed side yard variation represents the
minimum necessary. He believes the outdoor seating area, which was previously
described as not as important, could be made smaller. Mr. Case explained the required
side yard setback is 12 feet. They are requesting a five foot variation. Mr. Abbott
explained they are asking for the variation because they want to grow fresh vegetables
in that area as well. Mr. Webster added that the outdoor area is not solely for dining.
Although the design is not fully developed, they intend to grow plants on the vertical
screen. They also propose adding integral planting boxes and bicycle stands. Mr.
Webster noted the roof is not enclosed and the vertical wall has a horizontal canopy.
The east and west areas of the structure are open. The fresh vegetables will be used in
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 6 of 7

the restaurant. Mr. Webster noted that if the outdoor area were made narrower, it would
negatively impact the long-term success of the business. Mr. Adams indicated the
property could have many lives; however, what would happen if the property were sold.
Ch. Speckmann noted that if the business were sold, the building would remain with the
setback variations. The new business could enclose the structure or add more tables.
Ch. Speckmann noted the Village Ordinances are currently written for specific
businesses. Mr. Kessel does not believe an Ordinance could be passed specifically for
this ownership. Mr. Case explained that any restaurant would be considered a Special
Use. If the design were modified, the Special Use would need to be amended as well.
Mr. Adams believes the front yard is the minimum necessary, but the proposed side
yard is not the minimum necessary.

Ch. Speckmann asked the public if they have comments.

Jill Finch, 771 Congressional Lane, expressed concern about noise. She does not
understand why there needs to be outdoor seating until 10:00 PM. She also needs to
deal with noise from Waste Management at 5:00 AM. Ms. Finch is concerned about the
noise from food truck deliveries and additional garbage pickup. She wants to ensure
she has a commitment from the owners that their business operations will not impact
her quality of life. Ch. Speckmann closed this portion of the Public Hearing.

Mr. Kessel made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Mayor and Board
of Trustees regarding the portion of the petition allowing a seven foot side yard setback
in lieu of a 12 foot side yard setback. Ms. Scott seconded the motion. The motion
passed by the following vote:

AYES: Scott, Kessel, Bezman, Speckmann (4)
NAYS: Adams (1)

Ch. Speckmann reopened the information gathering portion of the Public Hearing to
consider the proposed minimum parking requirement variation. He explained the
number of vehicles was determined because the business includes both sit-down and
carry out services. The calculation determined 35 spaces including two handicapped
spaces would be required for the site. The proposed plan includes 33 spaces including
the two handicapped spaces. The parking includes both employee and public parking.
Ch. Speckmann indicated the more space that is used as back of the house space, the
less parking that is actually needed. Mr. Kessel noted that the proposed restaurant
could have 4000 square feet of seating, but only requires 35 parking spaces. Ch.
Speckmann explained that based on 40% of their business being sit-down, the
Ordinance requires 35 parking spaces. With 3000 square feet of area, 20 spaces would
be required. The carry out requires 15 spaces. Ch. Speckmann believes that if the
restaurant becomes a viable entity, there will not be enough parking. The petitioner is
requesting a variation of two parking spaces. Mr. Adams indicated the Board of
Trustees needs to determine whether this is a viable entity. The Board has the
discretion to count the outdoor seating.
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 7 of 7


Ch. Speckmann closed the informational gathering portion of the Public Hearing. Mr.
Adams made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Mayor and Board of
Trustees on the sole question of whether to grant a parking variance of two spaces.
Ms. Scott seconded the motion. The motion passed unanimously.

Ch. Speckmann urged the petitioner to provide a more in depth layout of the building for
review by the Mayor and Board of Trustees.


Adjournment:

There being no further business or discussion, the meeting was adjourned at 8:55 pm.

Respectfully submitted,

Jeri Cotton
Secretary

        Notice is hereby given pursuant to the Zoning Ordinance of the Village of Deerfield that a
public hearing will be held before the Village's Board of Zoning Appeals on Tuesday, May 7, 2013, at

60015.

        The purpose of the public hearing will be to consider an application (the "Application") which
has been submitted to the Village by Health o Wealth Inc. (the "Owner"), as owner of a parcel of
property located at 780 Saunders Road (the "Property"). The Property is legally described on
Exhibit "A" attached hereto.

        The Application seeks approval of: (1) variations to reduce by 2 the number of parking spaces
required to be provided for the Restaurant by Sections 8.02-E(2)(i) and (2) of the Zoning Ordinance,
Sections 5.02-F(3)(a), to reduce the front yard setback to 25 feet in lieu of 50 feet and (3),
Section 5.02-F(3)(b), to reduce the minimum side yard setback to 7 feet in lieu of 12 feet. The plans
are on file at the Village's Community Development Department at Village Hall and available for public
inspection.

       The Owner is represented by Brett R. Webster, ShiveHattery Architecture + Engineering, 3025
Highland Parkway, Downers Grove, Illinois 60515.

public hearing will be afforded an opportunity to be heard, and may submit their statements orally or in
writing or both. The hearing may be recessed to another date and time if not concluded on the
scheduled date without publication of a further notice such as this notice.

       For more details regarding the Application or if you have special accessibility needs, please
contact Clinton E. Case, Code Enforcement Supervisor, at (847) 719-7472 or ccase@deerfield.il.us.

                                                           Variation of Zoning Requirements
                                                                  Health 0 Wealth Inc.
                                                                   780 Saunders Road
                                                                       Deerfield, IL

          Description of variations:

                 A proposed Front Yard setback of 25 feet in lieu of the required setback of 50 feet in the C-2 Outlying
                 Commercial District

                 A proposed Side Yard setback (along the South property line) of 7 feet in lieu of the required setback of
                 12 feet in the C-2 Outlying Commercial District

                 Proposed 33 stall parking lot in lieu of the required 35 stall parking lot.

          Applicable Standards:

                 1.     Not a Use Variation

                        A Special Use for a Restaurant larger than 3,000 sq. ft. inclusive of outdoor dining is being
                        requested of the Plan Commission and Village Board at a Public Hearing scheduled for April 11,
                        2013.

                 2.     Unique to the Property

                        This is a residential property proposed to be Re-zoned to C-2 Outlying Commercial. The
                        property is unique in that it is at the Northwest corner of the Village adjacent to a large 1-1
                        Zoning district comprised primarily of office buildings on much larger parcels of land. The
                        property size is long, narrow and has direct access to only one right-of-way along the West
                        property line. These circumstances limit the possibilities of building size and parking lot layout.

                 3.     Not Self Imposed

                        This is a residential property proposed in the Village Comprehensive Plan to be an
                        Office/Research use. The North/South dimension of the property limits the building size and
                        parking lot layout for any type of use proposed for this property.

                 4.     Not Exclusively Monetary

                        The beneficial use of this property is restricted by the physical size which limits the possible
                        configurations of a building and a parking lot that fully comply with all provisions of the Zoning
                        Ordinance. The enclosed vehicle turning diagrams illustrate the turning clearance required at
                        the Northeast corner of the site. The striped area indicates the location of the parking stall
                        variation.




Project# 8121561


Shive-Hattery, Inc.   I 3025 Highland Parkway I Suite 140 I Downers Grove, IL 60515-5552 I 630.271.7600 I fax 630.241.4029 I shive-hattery.com   111111111111
                                                                                                                                             Page 2 of2




              5.   Minimum Adjustment Necessary

                   The variations being requested are the minimum necessary to locate a building and parking lot
                   for a commercial restaurant capable of serving customers in a comfortable and efficient
                   environment.

              6.   Not Detrimental to the Public Welfare

                   The variations being requested are minor deviations from the general purpose and intent of the
                   Zoning Ordinance. The development of the property as proposed will provide a needed use in
                   the neighborhood and add to the character of the neighborhood. The variations requested will
                   not be detrimental to the public welfare, other property, nor shall it alter the essential character
                   of the neighborhood.

              7.   Not Detrimental to the Neighborhood

                   The variations being requested will not impair an adequate supply of light and air to the adjacent
                   properties as adequate setbacks have been provided. The development of the property as
                   proposed will not create congestion in the streets as adequate parking has been provided for
                   the proposed restaurant use. The variations requested will not increase the potential damage of
                   fire or endanger the public safety. The building will be constructed to comply with the current
                   building codes enforced by the Village.

    Re:      'fhorngate Owners Association

    Dear Mayor Kaplan, Mayor Rosenthal and Ms. Maine:

    As the attorneys for the Thorngate Owners Association, we have been requested to contact you with
    regard to the proposed restaurant to be opened at the corner of Saunders Road and Deerfield Road.

    Please be adv.'ised, the Board of Directors for the Thorngate Homeowners Association is in opposition of
    this modification to this property. The Board believes that it will have a serious adverse impact on the
    traffic in this area, as it will lead to severe congestion and could create a safety hazard for the occupants
    using the roads. As you are aware, there is a severe back-up on Deerfield Road during rush hour, and a
    restaurant will lead to greater congestion. In addition, th{l residents fear that there will not be enough
    parking, causing further traffic problems at this already busy io.t(1rsection.

    Based on the above, the Board requests that the Village of Riverwoods deny this request. If you should
    have any questions please contact us.

    Sincerely,         ( /

      B.~(oge~
    Robert

                                                                                               CTH0004:00 100\1770641.1
                        REQUEST FOR BOARD ACTION


                                                             Agenda Item : 13-57

SUBJECT:      Report and Recommendation of the Board of Zoning Appeals
RE: Request of Kevin and Claudine Harig of 260 Deerfield Road, Deerfield,
Illinois, for relief from Article 4.01-F, Paragraph 3, Subparagraph e, of the
Deerfield Zoning Ordinance for their property at 260 Deerfield Road. The
variation if granted would permit the construction of a two story addition,
extending 7.0 feet into the required 50 foot minimum rear yard specified by the
Zoning Ordinance.

Action Requested: Acceptance of the BZA Recommendation_____________

Originated By: Board of Zoning Appeals______________________________

Referred To: Mayor and Board of Trustees____________________________

Summary of Background and Reason for Request:

A public hearing was held on May 7, 2013 to consider the requests of the
petitioners for a two story addition encroaching 7.0 feet into the required rear
yard producing a 43.0 foot rear yard in lieu of the minimum 50 feet.

The Gursoy subdivision created an existing non-conformity of the rear yard
setback on the north of the property. The granting of the petitioners request
would validate the existing nonconforming setback. In addition, there were no
objections to the request from nearby property owners.


Therefore, on a motion to recommend the variation be granted, the vote was 5 to
0 in favor of the request.

Reports and Documents Attached:

       Recommendation
       Exhibits
       Legal Notice
       Map

Date Referred to Board: June 3, 2013


                                        Action Taken: _____________________
                   RECOMMENDATION


TO:              Mayor and Board of Trustees

FROM:            Board of Zoning Appeals

DATE:            May 7, 2013

SUBJECT:         Rear Yard Variation- 260 Deerfield Road


We transmit for your consideration a recommendation adopted by the
Deerfield Board of Zoning Appeals on the petition of Kevin and Claudine
Harig, 260 Deerfield Road, Deerfield, Illinois. The petitioner is seeking relief
from Article 4.01-F, Paragraph 3, Subparagraph e, of the Deerfield Zoning
Ordinance for their property at 260 Deerfield Road. The variation if granted
would permit the construction of a two story addition to the existing
nonconforming structure created during the Gursoy subdivision process in
1968. The variation if granted would validate a 44.25 foot rear yard where the
existing structure would remain per the original subdivision in lieu of the
required 50 foot rear yard specified in the zoning ordinance.


FINDINGS OF FACT

1. The subject property is zoned in an R-1 district.

2. The Gursoy Subdivision was legally created in 1968.

3. The original structure was established prior to the subdivision and zoning
   ordinances being in effect.

4. The proposed addition will encroach 7.0 feet into the required 50 foot rear
   yard where the existing structure will remain.

5. The rear yard of the subject property abuts the property to the North which
   is part of the Gorsoy subdivision.
Board of Zoning Appeals Recommendation (260 Deerfield Road)
Page two
May 7, 2013


         CONCLUSIONS

         1. The requested variation is not a use variation.

         2. The existing non-conformity of the structure on the lot was created by the
            legal subdivision in 1968.

         3. The granting of the petitioners' request would validate the existing
            encroachment into the rear yard.

         4. There were no objections to the petitioners' request from nearby property
            owners.


         MOTIONS AND VOTE

         The motion was made to recommend the petitioners' request be granted:

         AYES: (5) Kessel, Kuczek, Moyer, Robbins, Scott, Speckmann

         NYES: (0)

         Motion Passed.

         RECOMMENDATION

         Accordingly, in the presence of 5 concurring votes, the Board of Zoning
         Appeals recommends the requested variation be granted to permit the
         construction of a two story addition, which would encroach 7.0 feet into the
         minimum rear yard, leaving a rear yard of 43.0 feet in lieu of the minimum 50
         feet required 50 foot.


         Respectfully submitted,

         Robert Speckmann, Chairman
         Deerfield Board of Zoning Appeals

                                Board of Zoning Appeals

Minutes of Public Hearing                                                   May 7, 2013

A Deerfield Board of Zoning Appeals held a Public Hearing on Tuesday May 7, 2013 at
7:30 p.m. at the Village Hall Conference Room, 850 Waukegan Road, Deerfield, Illinois.
Chairman Robert Speckmann called the meeting to order at 7:30 p.m.

Ch. Speckmann indicated the Board of Zoning Appeals is advisory to the Mayor and
Board of Trustees. He explained the BZA's deliberations and recommendations would
be in front of the Trustees at their June 3, 2013 meeting. Ch. Speckmann requested the
petitioners appear at that meeting to answer any questions the Trustees may have.

Present were:
Chairman Bob Speckmann
Len Adams
Karen Bezman
Herb Kessel
Ted Kuczek (left at 8:30 pm)
Karen Scott

Absent was:
Jeff Auerbach

Also Present:
Clint Case, Enforcement Officer
Jeff Hansen, Assistant Code Enforcement Officer

Mr. Hansen confirmed the mailings were in order and the Public Hearing was properly
advertised and listed. Ch. Speckmann swore in the petitioners for both petitions and
opened the Public Hearing.

The first petition is seeking a rear yard setback variation. The petitioners, Kevin and
Claudine Harig, own the property commonly known as 260 Deerfield Road, Deerfield,
Illinois 60015. Mr. Harig indicated they propose correcting the north (rear) setback on
the lot line to reflect the existing structure. When the lot was subdivided in 1968, the
setback and structure were not taken into consideration and there is a required 50 foot
setback. They would like to have the setback corrected to make their existing house
conformant.

Ch. Speckmann noted this is a housekeeping issue, as it was not addressed in 1968
when the lot was subdivided. They did not create a rear yard that was conforming, so
the lot is not conforming at this time.
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 2 of 7

Mrs. Harig explained the issue was found as they went through the permit process.
They are looking to build out their property with an addition. Mrs. Harig indicated they
propose upgrading the electrical and plumbing as well.

Ms. Scott questioned the garage reconstruction. Ms. Harig explained the garage walls
would be torn down to allow for a roof extension, but would be reconstructed in the
same area. The garage would remain a detached garage.

Ch. Speckmann noted that the legal notice requested a rear yard of 44.44 feet, but the
documentation indicated a rear yard of 43.6 feet. He believes that would put a bend in
the back wall of the addtion. In order to create an addition with a straight wall, Ch.
Speckmann believes the actual setback should be 43 feet to allow room if the
foundation does not line up properly. He suggested the petition be adjusted to allow a
variance of 43.00 feet.

Mr. Adams questioned whether the garage would be the same size, but the opening be
changed so it opens to the east side of the property. Ms. Harig explained the garage
would be enlarged slightly to the north and the roof would overhang to allow for a
walkway. He noted the petitioner currently accesses the garage from the west side.

Mr. Adams questioned whether that existing curb cut would be closed. Ms. Harig
explained they would add a curb cut next to the neighbor's curb cut. There was a legal
document between the two deeds stipulating the easement portion of the Harig's lot,
which has the adjacent curb cut, is only for the use of the adjacent property. It is not
allowed to be shared. Ms. Harig noted there is a document stating the easement is a
sole use easement

The variation if granted would permit a 43.00 foot rear yard setback variation.

Ch. Speckmann closed the information gathering portion of the Public Hearing.

Mr. Kessel made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Mayor and Board
of Trustees to grant the variation as presented and amended. Mr. Adams seconded the
motion. The motion passed unanimously.

Ch. Speckmann reopened the Public Hearing to consider a front yard setback variation
for the property located at 780 Saunders Road.

Brett Webster, architect and project manager representing the Abbots, owners of the
property commonly known as 780 Saunders Road, indicated the existing house and
freestanding sheds on the property that would be removed to create space for a
proposed restaurant.

Mr. Webster explained the proposed restaurant is a 3000 square foot structure with an
outdoor dining area along the south property line. The parking area will be on the rear
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 3 of 7

of the site. The business will have a mix of carry-out and dine-in service. Mr. Webster
indicated the proposed restaurant features healthy dining with a zero-waste scheme.
The site has been designed for access from the office park. Patrons are also
encouraged to walk and use bicycles to access the restaurant. Ch. Speckmann asked if
an easement has been negotiated with the Parkway North office park. Mr. Webster
explained they are in process of negotiating an easement.

Ch. Speckmann asked why it is necessary to have the building closer to the street than
what is allowed in the Ordinance. Mr. Webster explained that they provided a letter
describing the requested variations along with the standards. The first standard, not a
use variation, is not applicable to the property because they are in process of requesting
a Zoning change with the Board of Trustees. The second standard is unique to the
property. Mr. Webster noted the parcel is currently zoned R-1 situated between an
office complex and the Village of Riverwoods. The parcel was not part of the large
office complex to the south and the east. Directly to the north of the parcel is a bank
with a parking lot and driveway access and then the Mobile station on the corner. The
result is this long, narrow parcel. The Comprehensive Plan recommended this property
have the same type of use as the office complex; however, the owners did not find a
way to comply as an office use. The reality of the parcel is that there is only so large of
a building that can fit on the parcel and allow for parking and landscaping. Mr. Webster
spoke with the planning staff that would prefer the parcel to be a tax-generating
business and zoned as outlying commercial. The Abbots, who operate the Mobile gas
station on the corner of Deerfield and Riverwoods Roads, believe a 3000 square foot
restaurant would be appropriate for the parcel.

Ch. Speckmann noted Lake County Department of Transportation is taking 10 feet of
property for a wider right-of-way, which if not done would result in a 35 foot setback
rather than a 25 foot setback. Mr. Webster noted that if the setback were place an
additional 25 feet from Saunders, the restaurant would have to be pushed back and the
building would have to be made smaller. Ch. Speckmann noted parking calculations,
building and plumbing codes differ for a 2000 square foot seating area (excluding the
back house area.) The current building regulations would allow one person per 15
square feet of area. Ch. Speckmann expressed concern because there would only be
50 people in a space large enough for 130. Mr. Webster explained there would include
a mix of a sit-down restaurant and selling of packaged food. Ch. Speckmann explained
the maximum number of patrons would be 50. He believes the space will seem very
empty. Ch. Speckmann questioned why the restaurant needs this much space, as the
fire department will issue a maximum occupancy. He indicated the petitioner may not
need as many variances if the restaurant size were reduced. He suggested the
petitioners look at the design and determine whether or not they really need that much
space.

Mr. Abbott explained most of their customers will be from the office complexes during
lunch and food delivery will be made available. Mr. Abbott noted they need the space
because they will be offering gluten free options which need to be prepared separately.
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 4 of 7

Ch. Speckmann noted the current floor plan does not allow adequate space for the
entire back of house area as just described. He believes reducing the dining room size
would make the petition more appropriate. Mr. Webster explained the proposed interior
layout was a preliminary scheme. Mr. Abbott would prefer to have more room to
accommodate patrons. He also indicated the employees would park at the Mobile
station. In addition, they are in discussion with the bank regarding additional parking.

Mr. Webster explained attaining a 50 foot front yard setback would be difficult to
achieve. The owners requested a variation that would allow the most flexibility to have
a long-lasting, thriving business on the parcel.

Mr. Kessel asked about the pedestrian traffic flow and the path along the eastern edge
of the property. Mr. Webster showed the path on the Parkway North property that
continues around the building. He noted there are two entrances into the restaurant,
one in the front and one in the rear.

Ch. Speckmann closed the information gathering portion of the Public Hearing. Mr.
Kessel questioned whether the Village could live with a 50% variation. Ch. Speckmann
explained the Lake County Department of Transportation is taking 10 feet, so he does
not have an issue with this variation.

Mr. Adams made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Board of
Trustees regarding the portion of the petition regarding the front yard setback variation.
Ms. Scott seconded the motion. The motion passed by the following vote:

AYES: Kuczek, Scott, Adams, Bezman, Speckmann (5)
NAYS: Kessel (1)

Ch. Speckmann reopened the Public Hearing to consider the south side yard setback
variation of seven feet for the property located at 780 Saunders Road. He assumed the
deck would be a raised deck rather than a patio. If it is a patio, the variation request
would not be necessary. Mr. Webster noted there would be steel columns extending
higher than the building roof. There will be a sunscreen and a vertical garden. Ch.
Speckmann indicated the raised deck must have a variation. Mr. Webster noted it is not
a raised deck, but it would be enclosed with a transparent structure. Code Enforcement
Officer Case indicated that if the structure has columns, it would need to be reviewed.

Ch. Speckmann indicated he neglected to ask for public comment during the front yard
setback variation request. He asked if there were any comments.

David Schreiber, 464 Pebble Beach Lane, Riverwoods, is president of the Thorngate
Homeowners Association. Thorngate is located across the street of the property, in
Riverwoods. Mr. Schreiber indicated they are against moving the building closer to the
road. Mr. Schreiber expressed concern about the lighting that will shine in the bedroom
windows of their homeowners. In addition, they feel allowing vehicles to turn
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 5 of 7

southbound onto Saunders Road will create a safety hazard. The Thorngate
Homeowner's Association requested only allowing vehicles to enter the property from
the south and exit the property going north. Trying to cut across traffic will create a
problem. Ch. Speckmann indicated Mr. Schreiber's request is outside the scope of the
Board of Zoning Appeals. He noted the Plan Commission already heard this request
and rejected it. Ch. Speckmann suggested Mr. Schreiber appear before the Mayor and
Board of Trustees.

Mr. Adams noted the lighting is typically in the parking area, which is located in the rear
of the restaurant. Mr. Schreiber noted that the ambient lighting would also disturb their
homeowners. Ch. Speckmann indicated that this is also outside the Board of Zoning
Appeals jurisdiction. Ms. Bezman noted the gas station lighting is brighter than
whatever lighting the restaurant would have. Mr. Schreiber explained the Abbotts have
changed the bulbs to make them less visible from Thorngate. He noted that if the
building were further set back, it would not make a difference to the residents of
Thorngate.

Mr. Kuczek made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Board of
Trustees regarding the portion of the petition regarding the front yard setback variation.
Mr. Kessel seconded the motion. The motion passed 5-1 with Mr. Kessel voting against
the petition.

Ch. Speckmann asked if there were any questions regarding the side yard setback
variation request. Mr. Kessel questioned what is to the south of the proposed
development. Mr. Webster explained it is an empty pad that is ready for an office
building that is pre-approved for a PUD. It is located on John Buck's property. Ch.
Speckmann spoke with Village Planner Jeff Ryckaert, who indicated that property
requires a 300 foot setback.

Mr. Adams noted the proposed outdoor deck seating would be according to the Plan
Commission recommendation and would not count against the parking requirement.
Ch. Speckmann indicated that was the recommendation of the Plan Commission. Mr.
Adams explained the proposed outdoor structure is somewhat permanent and it would
not be too difficult to further enclose the structure so it is available more than three
months a year. One of the requirements is to make the variations the minimum
necessary. Mr. Adams does not believe the proposed side yard variation represents the
minimum necessary. He believes the outdoor seating area, which was previously
described as not as important, could be made smaller. Mr. Case explained the required
side yard setback is 12 feet. They are requesting a five foot variation. Mr. Abbott
explained they are asking for the variation because they want to grow fresh vegetables
in that area as well. Mr. Webster added that the outdoor area is not solely for dining.
Although the design is not fully developed, they intend to grow plants on the vertical
screen. They also propose adding integral planting boxes and bicycle stands. Mr.
Webster noted the roof is not enclosed and the vertical wall has a horizontal canopy.
The east and west areas of the structure are open. The fresh vegetables will be used in
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 6 of 7

the restaurant. Mr. Webster noted that if the outdoor area were made narrower, it would
negatively impact the long-term success of the business. Mr. Adams indicated the
property could have many lives; however, what would happen if the property were sold.
Ch. Speckmann noted that if the business were sold, the building would remain with the
setback variations. The new business could enclose the structure or add more tables.
Ch. Speckmann noted the Village Ordinances are currently written for specific
businesses. Mr. Kessel does not believe an Ordinance could be passed specifically for
this ownership. Mr. Case explained that any restaurant would be considered a Special
Use. If the design were modified, the Special Use would need to be amended as well.
Mr. Adams believes the front yard is the minimum necessary, but the proposed side
yard is not the minimum necessary.

Ch. Speckmann asked the public if they have comments.

Jill Finch, 771 Congressional Lane, expressed concern about noise. She does not
understand why there needs to be outdoor seating until 10:00 PM. She also needs to
deal with noise from Waste Management at 5:00 AM. Ms. Finch is concerned about the
noise from food truck deliveries and additional garbage pickup. She wants to ensure
she has a commitment from the owners that their business operations will not impact
her quality of life. Ch. Speckmann closed this portion of the Public Hearing.

Mr. Kessel made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Mayor and Board
of Trustees regarding the portion of the petition allowing a seven foot side yard setback
in lieu of a 12 foot side yard setback. Ms. Scott seconded the motion. The motion
passed by the following vote:

AYES: Scott, Kessel, Bezman, Speckmann (4)
NAYS: Adams (1)

Ch. Speckmann reopened the information gathering portion of the Public Hearing to
consider the proposed minimum parking requirement variation. He explained the
number of vehicles was determined because the business includes both sit-down and
carry out services. The calculation determined 35 spaces including two handicapped
spaces would be required for the site. The proposed plan includes 33 spaces including
the two handicapped spaces. The parking includes both employee and public parking.
Ch. Speckmann indicated the more space that is used as back of the house space, the
less parking that is actually needed. Mr. Kessel noted that the proposed restaurant
could have 4000 square feet of seating, but only requires 35 parking spaces. Ch.
Speckmann explained that based on 40% of their business being sit-down, the
Ordinance requires 35 parking spaces. With 3000 square feet of area, 20 spaces would
be required. The carry out requires 15 spaces. Ch. Speckmann believes that if the
restaurant becomes a viable entity, there will not be enough parking. The petitioner is
requesting a variation of two parking spaces. Mr. Adams indicated the Board of
Trustees needs to determine whether this is a viable entity. The Board has the
discretion to count the outdoor seating.
Board of Zoning Appeals
May 7, 2013
Page 7 of 7


Ch. Speckmann closed the informational gathering portion of the Public Hearing. Mr.
Adams made a motion to send a favorable recommendation to the Mayor and Board of
Trustees on the sole question of whether to grant a parking variance of two spaces.
Ms. Scott seconded the motion. The motion passed unanimously.

Ch. Speckmann urged the petitioner to provide a more in depth layout of the building for
review by the Mayor and Board of Trustees.


Adjournment:

There being no further business or discussion, the meeting was adjourned at 8:55 pm.

Respectfully submitted,

Jeri Cotton
Secretary

                                  REQUEST FOR BOARD ACTION
                                                                       Agenda Item: 13-59
Subject:       Report and Recommendation regarding 2 Waukegan Road (Shell) request for Limited
               Area Groundwater Use Restriction Ordinance
Action Requested:     Accept Report and Recommendation
Originated By: Director of Public Works and Engineering
Referred To:    Mayor and Board of Trustees
Summary of Background and Reason for Request:
We have received a request from 2 Waukegan Road (Shell) to institute a Limited Area Groundwater Use
Restriction Ordinance (LGWO) that is specifically in accordance with the Illinois Environmental
Protection Agency (IEPA) requirements. The Village of Deerfield Municipal Code requires that "No new
wells may be established and used for the supply of potable water in any area of the village". ((Ord. 0-99-
24, 5-3-1999) - Section 23-6A.).

The ownership of 2 Waukegan (Shell), True North Energy, LLC, recently submitted their executed
documents for this property and indicated their desire for the village to complete their process to approve
a LGWO. In April 2012 we requested authorization from the Board to retain the services of AECOM to
review and provide recommendations on this request. AECOM has now completed their evaluation (see
attachment). Their report states that they concur with the LGWO with the boundary as shown on Exhibit
A in the document. This would address potential and actual groundwater impacts. If approved by the
Board of Trustees, this ordinance will be submitted to the IEPA as part of the Site Remedial Action Plan.
We recommend that the Board accept the AECOM report and approve the LGWO for the subject
property.

Due to the fact that the Village has underground utilities within the potential contamination area we
requested the property owner and business to enter into a Supplemental Agreement with the Village. This
document was prepared by the Village of Deerfield Attorney. It outlines responsibilities of the owner/
business and the village, especially if the village needs to make an underground utility repair or
excavation. This agreement provides for ownership's reimbursement to the village for engineer and
attorney expenses. The Supplemental Agreement includes two attachments, a Highway Authority
Agreement and the LGWO. The Highway Authority Agreement also includes updated soil and
groundwater impact maps and analytical results. The agreement is attached and presented to you for your
review and approval.

We recommend that the Board accept the AECOM report and approve the Supplemental Agreement for 2
Waukegan Road (Shell), Deerfield, Illinois, including the Highway Authority Agreement and the Limited
Area Groundwater Use Restriction Ordinance.

Reports and Documents Attached:
-AECOM Report, dated May 29, 2013
-Supplemental Agreement including the Highway Authority Agreement and the Limited Area
Groundwater Use Restriction Ordinance

Date Referred to Board: June 3, 2013                         Action Taken: ______________________

Subject:    Summary Letter for
            Shell Station # 1917
            2 Waukegan Road, Deerfield, Illinois
            AECOM Project No. 60266708


Dear Ms. Little:

AECOM Technical Services, Inc. (AECOM) has prepared this summary letter of our review of
environmental documents associated with the above-referenced site. We understand that the
owner of the above referenced site is seeking closure for the site through the Illinois Environmental
Protection Agency's (IEPA) Leaking Underground Storage Tank (LUST) Program. In order to
facilitate this closure they are requesting the Village of Deerfield (the Village) implement an
institutional control (groundwater use restriction ordinance) as further protection from the
environmental impacts associated with the site. The purpose of this review is to assess the
feasibility of site closure using institutional controls, including a groundwater ordinance.

AECOM reviewed environmental documents provided by the Village. These documents include the
following:

    1.   Corrective Action Plan, URS, dated May 16, 2013
    2.   Tiered Approach To Corrective-Action Objectives Supplemental Agreement
    3.   Highway Authority Agreement
    4.   Limited Area Groundwater Ordinance

Based on the review of the above documents, the gasoline station located at 2 Waukegan Road in
Deerfield, Illinois has experienced a release of unleaded gasoline that has impacted subsurface soil
and groundwater. Gasoline constituents including benzene, ethylbenzene, toluene and xylenes
(BETX) and methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE) have been detected in the subsurface at the site. In
response to the release of gasoline, LUST incident # 20080899 was assigned to the site.

As part of the site closure, URS on behalf of True North Energy, LLC, is proposing to address the
gasoline impacts using institutional controls. The owner of the property will be required by the IEPA
to implement the institutional controls below to address these impacts. Except for the LGWO as
discussed below, approval of the following institutional controls is within the jurisdiction of the IEPA.
For purposes of this letter, AECOM has assumed that the IEPA will require compliance with all of
these items before issuing a No Further Remediation (NFR) letter.
AECOM                                        Summary Letter                                 Shell Station #1917              2
                                                                                            2 Waukegan Road, Deerfield, IL




The IEPA has established cleanup standards that need to be meet for both soil and groundwater
before a No Further Remediation (NFR) letter can be issued for the site. These standards are
provided in 35 Illinois Administrative Code (IAC) 742. There are three sets of Tier 1 standards; one
for residential properties, one for commercial/industrial properties and a third for potential
construction worker protection in case of future excavation work on the site. Each of the Tier 1
standards includes three sets of cleanup objectives for the different exposure routes; inhalation, soil
ingestion and groundwater ingestion. Initially the soil and groundwater concentrations are
compared to Tier 1 standards which are in look up tables. If any of the Tier 1 objective values are
exceeded then Tier 2 calculations can be performed.

Inhalation Exposure Route

Based on the URS report, benzene concentrations in on-site soil exceed the Tier 1 Residential soil
remedial objectives (SROs) in 35 IAC 742 for inhalation. The Tier 1 Construction Worker Inhalation
Exposure SROs have also been exceeded by the detected concentrations of benzene,
ethylbenzene and xylenes in the soil.

In order to further assess the inhalation exposure, URS conducted Tier 2 calculations using site
specific data. A comparison of the maximum concentrations detected to the Tier 2 SROs indicates
that the residential inhalation and construction inhalation SROs have been met. Based on the
comparison, institutional controls at the site are not required to address the inhalation exposure
route.

However, if the inhalation SRO exceedances extend off-site beneath Lake Cook Road, then the
proposed Highway Authority Agreement (HAA) would need to be implemented to obtain closure.
This would require the Cook County Highway Department as the "Highway Authority" to approve of
the proposed HAA. The IEPA will need to make a determination whether the HAA is required for
closure of the site.

Soil Ingestion Exposure Route

Based on the URS report BETX and MTBE concentrations in on-site soil are below the SROs for
soil ingestion. Therefore, no institutional controls are needed to address the soil ingestion
exposure route.

Groundwater Ingestion Exposure Route

           Soil Component of Groundwater Ingestion

The concentrations of benzene, ethylbenzene, xylenes and MTBE in the on-site soil exceed the Tier
1 Soil Component to Groundwater Ingestion SROs. URS calculated Tier 2 equations to
demonstrate the potential for these petroleum constituents to leach from the soil into the
groundwater. Based on the calculations the soil impacts could adversely impact the groundwater
beneath the site. However, additional calculations performed by URS indicated that the potential
groundwater impacts from the soil will attenuate before migrating off-site.




K:\PROJECTS\60266708\500_Submittals\60266708_SummaryLetter_ShellStation1917_05-29-13.docx
AECOM                                        Summary Letter                                 Shell Station #1917              3
                                                                                            2 Waukegan Road, Deerfield, IL




           Groundwater Component of Groundwater Ingestion

The detected groundwater concentrations of benzene and MTBE at the site have the potential to
migrate off-site before the impacts would dissipate to concentrations below the Class II
Groundwater Remedial Objectives.

AECOM has reviewed the proposed Limited Area Groundwater Use Restriction Ordinance (LGWO)
and concurs that LGWO would effectively address the petroleum groundwater impacts, if approved
by the IEPA. The proposed ordinance will need to meet the requirements from 35 IAC 742.1015.
In addition to the use of the LGWO, the IEPA will require written notifications to adjacent properties
within the area of use restriction, which could be potentially be impacted by the gasoline release.

General Closure Requirements

In order to exclude exposure routes utilizing the institutional controls above, 35 IAC 742.300
requires the following:

     1. A demonstration that the sum of the concentrations of all organic contaminants of concern
        do not exceed the attenuation capacity of the soil as determined under Section 742.215;

     2. A demonstration that the concentrations of any organic contaminants of concern remaining
        in the soil shall not exceed the soil saturation limit as determined under Section 742.220;

     3. A demonstration that the soil which contains contaminants of concern shall not exhibit any
        of the characteristics of reactivity for hazardous waste as determined under 35 Ill. Adm.
        Code 721.123;

Based on the URS report, these three exclusion criteria have been demonstrated.


AECOM appreciates the opportunity to provide consulting services for the Village of Deerfield.
Please feel free to contact the undersigned if you have questions regarding this letter.

Sincerely yours,




Steven T. Newlin                                                      Steve Kornder
Senior Project Manager                                                Senior Project Geochemist
